description: This course describes how to monitor and operate a cloud with Microsoft System Center 2012 R2. It focuses on how to manage and administer a cloud environment, and it describes how you can monitor key infrastructure elements and applications that run within a cloud. This course will help you to acquire the skills required to deploy and configure System Center 2012 R2 for Cloud and Datacenter monitoring. In addition, how to use System Center Virtual Machine Manager, Service Manager, and Operations Manager to coordinate end-to-end service monitoring, and fabric and application monitoring is covered. If you are new to operating a private cloud, or have been managing one and want to update your skills, then this course will show you how.

In addition, how to use System Center Virtual Machine Manager, Service Manager, and Operations Manager to coordinate end-to-end service monitoring, and fabric and application monitoring is covered. If you are new to operating a private cloud, or have been managing one and want to update your skills, then this course will show you how.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam give a general overview of what to expect in the upcoming 70-246, Monitoring and Operating a Private Cloud series. They cover topics like who is the intended audience, what the scope of the series will cover, and what are some specific topics that will be addressed.

episodes.description: In this episode, Cherokee and Adam begin discussing the cloud computing computing model. First, Adam explains several System Center components. Next, they begin exploring different deployment methods including private, public or even hybrid solutions. Tune in to learn how System Center Roles support your infrastructure.
episodes.title: Introduction to the Cloud Model
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.175
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.175 --> 00:00:02.278
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.278 --> 00:00:05.819
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.819 --> 00:00:08.233
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:11.845
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.845 --> 00:00:14.153
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to your Monitoring and

7
00:00:14.153 --> 00:00:15.733
Operating a Private Cloud series.

8
00:00:15.733 --> 00:00:17.743
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

9
00:00:17.743 --> 00:00:22.700
In this episode, we'll be looking an
introduction to the private cloud model.

10
00:00:22.700 --> 00:00:25.160
And with us today,
we have Mr Adam Gordon in studios.

11
00:00:25.160 --> 00:00:26.500
Thank you for joining us, Adam.

12
00:00:26.500 --> 00:00:28.287
>> Hello, how do?

13
00:00:28.287 --> 00:00:29.067
Nice to see you.

14
00:00:31.099 --> 00:00:32.539
I don't know, whatever.

15
00:00:32.539 --> 00:00:34.140
Nice to be here, hello.

16
00:00:34.140 --> 00:00:37.525
So, I thought we'd talk about private
cloud, introducing private cloud and

17
00:00:37.525 --> 00:00:41.245
the idea of private cloud is what we're
gonna focus on, at least right now.

18
00:00:41.245 --> 00:00:45.755
We will talk much more broadly throughout
the various episodes that we're

19
00:00:45.755 --> 00:00:48.030
putting together around the 72 46.

20
00:00:48.030 --> 00:00:51.250
Part one if you will of the MCSE
private cloud certification.

21
00:00:51.250 --> 00:00:56.530
About System Center but we're gonna focus
on the monitoring certainly with SCOM but

22
00:00:56.530 --> 00:01:00.270
also focus on the hosting of
the private cloud fabric so the SCVMM,

23
00:01:00.270 --> 00:01:02.940
System Center Virtual Machine Manager
piece.

24
00:01:02.940 --> 00:01:06.470
We're gonna be taking look at how
those two products in particular

25
00:01:06.470 --> 00:01:09.920
are used together to be able to form
the basis, the bedrock if you will or

26
00:01:09.920 --> 00:01:13.240
the baseline for how we build out
the private cloud in the organization,

27
00:01:13.240 --> 00:01:14.440
or throughout the enterprise.

28
00:01:14.440 --> 00:01:17.010
We're gonna start by talking
a little bit about what cloud is.

29
00:01:17.010 --> 00:01:21.120
The cloud model conceptually has
been around for a while now.

30
00:01:21.120 --> 00:01:24.790
When we think about cloud, and we think
about what a private cloud, a public

31
00:01:24.790 --> 00:01:29.810
cloud, a hybrid cloud, even a community
cloud maybe, yet we used terminology in

32
00:01:29.810 --> 00:01:34.870
thought processes that we don't always
necessarily define very strictly but

33
00:01:34.870 --> 00:01:38.470
rather, we use them based on what
we think those definitions, maybe.

34
00:01:38.470 --> 00:01:41.030
And we're gonna walk you through
what those definitions are here in

35
00:01:41.030 --> 00:01:41.980
just a minute.

36
00:01:41.980 --> 00:01:46.010
But, when we think of cloud,
we're really thinking today

37
00:01:46.010 --> 00:01:51.250
of the mixture and
the configuration, the management,

38
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:55.650
the oversight, and the usage of two
distinctly different technologies.

39
00:01:55.650 --> 00:01:59.711
The idea of virtualization which has
formed the underlying foundation of what

40
00:01:59.711 --> 00:02:01.689
we think of as cloud computing today.

41
00:02:01.689 --> 00:02:05.999
And then the ability to be able
to use network infrastructure,

42
00:02:05.999 --> 00:02:09.985
typically with some sort of
software defined interface or

43
00:02:09.985 --> 00:02:13.640
software defined management
thought process.

44
00:02:13.640 --> 00:02:17.430
Trying to abstract and
remove the human from the mix if you will.

45
00:02:17.430 --> 00:02:22.340
Defining and automating processes so that
we can replicate them and make sure that

46
00:02:22.340 --> 00:02:27.850
they are done correctly with minimal time
and effort and we can scale massively.

47
00:02:27.850 --> 00:02:31.330
And t his is what the primary driver for
software definition is.

48
00:02:31.330 --> 00:02:34.866
In terms of what it does for us in the
organization and across the enterprise.

49
00:02:34.866 --> 00:02:39.514
And so when we think of bringing
software defined, networking, storage,

50
00:02:39.514 --> 00:02:43.945
configuration management, software
defining up and down the stack and

51
00:02:43.945 --> 00:02:48.592
data center and we bring that to bear
along with virtualization, we develop

52
00:02:48.592 --> 00:02:52.832
the stack process that ultimately
becomes the defined as the cloud.

53
00:02:52.832 --> 00:02:58.300
And what we think of as the cloud today
is really the extension of traditional

54
00:02:58.300 --> 00:03:03.001
on-prem privately managed,
privately hosted infrastructure

55
00:03:03.001 --> 00:03:07.872
into either a co-hosted model where
we essentially pay somebody or

56
00:03:07.872 --> 00:03:12.742
ask a third party-provider or
a cloud source provider Microsoft,

57
00:03:12.742 --> 00:03:18.110
for instance, Amazon,
VMware whoever the provider may be.

58
00:03:18.110 --> 00:03:21.980
We ask them to host our private
infrastructure on our behalf

59
00:03:21.980 --> 00:03:25.620
dedicated to us,
that would be a hosted private cloud.

60
00:03:25.620 --> 00:03:28.990
We ask our own IT teams to
host that infrastructure,

61
00:03:28.990 --> 00:03:33.690
the traditional model we've always used,
but we simply rebrand it as private cloud.

62
00:03:33.690 --> 00:03:37.064
This would be the internal networks,
the LANs that we know of,

63
00:03:37.064 --> 00:03:41.490
the internal data center infrastructure,
our messaging platforms,

64
00:03:41.490 --> 00:03:46.180
our file servers, our data servers,
our web servers, all the stuff we know and

65
00:03:46.180 --> 00:03:49.760
we have, but, we just look at
it from a different perspective.

66
00:03:49.760 --> 00:03:51.490
We don't really change anything.

67
00:03:51.490 --> 00:03:55.790
We may underlying that architecture change
the thought process and use virtualization

68
00:03:55.790 --> 00:04:00.060
to host some of those machines but
in general it's the same concept, right?

69
00:04:00.060 --> 00:04:03.475
It's just that we are now using a new
marketing slogans to refer to it, right?

70
00:04:03.475 --> 00:04:05.739
>> And
the physical placement of those machines.

71
00:04:05.739 --> 00:04:09.620
>> Well, the physical placement in
the sense that they're still in the data

72
00:04:09.620 --> 00:04:10.170
center.

73
00:04:10.170 --> 00:04:12.560
They really haven't changed
in the physical placement.

74
00:04:12.560 --> 00:04:16.787
Can also now, really refer to not just,
hey, are they sitting in a rack, right,

75
00:04:16.787 --> 00:04:20.283
hypothetically where it would have
been for decades in many cases or

76
00:04:20.283 --> 00:04:24.146
sitting at data centers as for standing
machines if they were mainframes or

77
00:04:24.146 --> 00:04:25.343
midframe computers.

78
00:04:25.343 --> 00:04:29.640
But rather, are they running now as guest
operating system instances where we

79
00:04:29.640 --> 00:04:32.340
commonly referred to as virtual machines?

80
00:04:32.340 --> 00:04:36.865
Are they running as guest OS instances on
one or more of those rack-mounted pizza

81
00:04:36.865 --> 00:04:40.669
boxes or blades or whatever they
may be sitting in that data center?

82
00:04:40.669 --> 00:04:45.629
What we've essentially done is swapped out
the physical back-end infrastructure and

83
00:04:45.629 --> 00:04:49.583
we've collaborated in such way would
various technology vendors and

84
00:04:49.583 --> 00:04:52.746
coordinated all of these
technology coming together.

85
00:04:52.746 --> 00:04:58.171
So that now we can use that infrastructure
to scale the number of machines we run for

86
00:04:58.171 --> 00:05:02.170
this particular organization or
for this enterprise.

87
00:05:02.170 --> 00:05:04.980
And we go from having a one to one ratio.

88
00:05:04.980 --> 00:05:09.680
One resource, one server let's say,
running one application workload with

89
00:05:09.680 --> 00:05:12.980
one operating system dedicated
to a certain thought process.

90
00:05:12.980 --> 00:05:14.520
So I need an exchange server.

91
00:05:14.520 --> 00:05:16.838
Well, let me go build that CAS,
that client access server.

92
00:05:16.838 --> 00:05:21.169
Let me go build that back-end
where my database is gonna be.

93
00:05:21.169 --> 00:05:23.901
Let me go build the directories server,
the domain controller and

94
00:05:23.901 --> 00:05:26.948
those are one-off machines essentially,
right, physical machines.

95
00:05:26.948 --> 00:05:30.541
Instead, what we see now,
we have what we call a host and

96
00:05:30.541 --> 00:05:34.220
then I'm sure most of you if
not all of you know that.

97
00:05:34.220 --> 00:05:38.590
And the host is gonna simply be that
back-end machine that we often think about

98
00:05:38.590 --> 00:05:42.000
perhaps since running
Server 12 R2 with Hyper-V.

99
00:05:42.000 --> 00:05:44.990
Maybe it's running Server
16 with Hyper-V or

100
00:05:44.990 --> 00:05:46.490
whatever operating system we're running.

101
00:05:46.490 --> 00:05:49.150
It doesn't necessarily
have to be a Microsoft OS.

102
00:05:49.150 --> 00:05:51.615
But, in this case, cuz we're
talking about Microsoft technology,

103
00:05:51.615 --> 00:05:53.132
we're gonna assume it's a Microsoft OS.

104
00:05:53.132 --> 00:05:56.644
So let's say,
we're running Server 12 R2 with Hyper-V,

105
00:05:56.644 --> 00:05:58.439
that's gonna become our host.

106
00:05:58.439 --> 00:06:01.727
And then that host through Hyper-V,
through abstraction,

107
00:06:01.727 --> 00:06:06.024
through the hypervisor layer is gonna be
able to run multiple virtual machines,

108
00:06:06.024 --> 00:06:10.764
guest operating system that represent this
exchange server, this domain controller,

109
00:06:10.764 --> 00:06:12.780
this file and print server.

110
00:06:12.780 --> 00:06:17.600
But they're running as configuration
files and VHDX files that represent

111
00:06:17.600 --> 00:06:22.360
data from a storage network and with
networking and with all the things we need

112
00:06:22.360 --> 00:06:26.890
associated with it, through a common host,
and that's how we create private clouds.

113
00:06:26.890 --> 00:06:31.040
We simply do that with our inside,
internal to the data center,

114
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:34.440
owned by us private infrastructure
management solution.

115
00:06:34.440 --> 00:06:37.780
And System Center is gonna be
able to as a suite of products

116
00:06:37.780 --> 00:06:41.325
allow us to do all the things necessary to
be able to spin this infrastructure up but

117
00:06:41.325 --> 00:06:46.040
we can do it totally on-prem,
we can do it in combination

118
00:06:46.040 --> 00:06:50.410
with a cloud provider,
have them host it, have us manage it.

119
00:06:50.410 --> 00:06:54.533
We can use tools from the on-prem site,
System Center Ops Manager, for instance.

120
00:06:54.533 --> 00:06:59.226
Other tools in the System Center suite to
be able to link to that cloud fabric that

121
00:06:59.226 --> 00:07:02.935
Microsoft or
another providers giving us some monitor.

122
00:07:02.935 --> 00:07:06.265
We can monitor from the cloud side, we
can monitor from the data center's side.

123
00:07:06.265 --> 00:07:07.555
We could do that either way.

124
00:07:07.555 --> 00:07:09.588
So private clouds can be created and
hosted,

125
00:07:09.588 --> 00:07:12.382
right your point about location
in either place, Cherokee.

126
00:07:12.382 --> 00:07:13.706
It really wouldn't matter where it is.

127
00:07:13.706 --> 00:07:17.022
The goal is that we just have to
figure out what's most cost-effective

128
00:07:17.022 --> 00:07:21.050
first of all, is it cheaper for us to
build it ourselves or host it ourselves?

129
00:07:21.050 --> 00:07:26.030
Or is it cheaper for us and essentially
pay as you go monthly fee model, right?

130
00:07:26.030 --> 00:07:29.994
Hey, I want this, this and this,
I need five machines, configured this way,

131
00:07:29.994 --> 00:07:31.957
with this infrastructure backing it.

132
00:07:31.957 --> 00:07:35.206
Mr and Mrs call provider,
how much is that gonna cost me?

133
00:07:35.206 --> 00:07:38.866
>> Right, that's what I mean, the host
operating system being one of your

134
00:07:38.866 --> 00:07:42.415
internal resources versus outsourcing
it to one of those providers.

135
00:07:42.415 --> 00:07:45.716
>> Right, yes, so
whatever it would be, wherever we go,

136
00:07:45.716 --> 00:07:49.676
the smart administrator is gonna
be doing cost benefit analysis.

137
00:07:49.676 --> 00:07:53.341
But also doing a risk assessment right on
top of that to understand the security

138
00:07:53.341 --> 00:07:57.231
implications and the BCDR, Business
Continuity Disaster Recovery applications

139
00:07:57.231 --> 00:07:59.695
Of what we're gonna do and
how we're gonna do that.

140
00:07:59.695 --> 00:08:01.670
So we're gonna be thinking
about those things and

141
00:08:01.670 --> 00:08:03.418
trying to understand them as we go.

142
00:08:03.418 --> 00:08:06.820
We're also gonna be talking about
the fact we may have hybrid clouds where

143
00:08:06.820 --> 00:08:09.580
we are hosting certain resources locally.

144
00:08:09.580 --> 00:08:13.990
We're hosting other resources at the data
center provider and we are gonna co-mingle

145
00:08:13.990 --> 00:08:18.020
that thought process and again manage
through and across the cloud interface.

146
00:08:18.020 --> 00:08:19.615
But however we get there,

147
00:08:19.615 --> 00:08:24.411
the idea of the cloud model is really
this idea blending these hosting models.

148
00:08:24.411 --> 00:08:27.389
And we'll talk about what they are and
define them in a minute but

149
00:08:27.389 --> 00:08:29.996
infrastructure as a service,
it's what they call IS.

150
00:08:29.996 --> 00:08:34.290
Platforms as a service, what they call PS,
software as a service, or SaaS.

151
00:08:34.290 --> 00:08:39.260
These are the three accepted,
well thought-out, well-defined, and

152
00:08:39.260 --> 00:08:42.600
what we would call universal
cloud service models.

153
00:08:42.600 --> 00:08:45.280
There are many other as
a service models today.

154
00:08:45.280 --> 00:08:48.630
You can come up with almost
anything as a service, and

155
00:08:48.630 --> 00:08:53.476
drop it into the vernacular and the
vocabulary matrix of hey, this is cloud.

156
00:08:53.476 --> 00:08:56.990
We have DB as a service or
DBaaS, database as a service.

157
00:08:56.990 --> 00:08:59.630
You have DRAS, DR as a service.

158
00:08:59.630 --> 00:09:00.208
>> Security as a service.

159
00:09:00.208 --> 00:09:03.421
>> SAC right so CCAS, SAC as a service or
security as a service,

160
00:09:03.421 --> 00:09:05.560
you've got all sorts of things.

161
00:09:05.560 --> 00:09:08.796
Desktop is a service, so
we traditionally would,

162
00:09:08.796 --> 00:09:11.745
you'll think of that as a form of VDI,
right.

163
00:09:11.745 --> 00:09:16.985
So we have all those kind of
infrastructure and software and managerial

164
00:09:16.985 --> 00:09:20.425
overlays with regards to defining what
something as a service looks like.

165
00:09:20.425 --> 00:09:24.005
But the only three that
are universally accepted today

166
00:09:24.005 --> 00:09:26.390
with regards to
the standardized definition.

167
00:09:26.390 --> 00:09:31.100
That one or more vendors are not saying,
this is what call this offering.

168
00:09:31.100 --> 00:09:34.190
Use this definition, but
rather everybody agrees, hey,

169
00:09:34.190 --> 00:09:38.170
when you define platform as a service,
it's this, these three.

170
00:09:38.170 --> 00:09:41.580
IaaS, PaaS and SaaS are the only three
that really fall into that category.

171
00:09:41.580 --> 00:09:45.540
So we're gonna show you the standard
formalized definitions for

172
00:09:45.540 --> 00:09:47.342
those from NIST, actually.

173
00:09:47.342 --> 00:09:49.920
Talk about where they come from, give
you a little bit of background on that.

174
00:09:49.920 --> 00:09:54.180
We're also gonna talk about
the idea behind, just in general,

175
00:09:54.180 --> 00:09:59.170
how cloud gets implemented through the
Microsoft stack in using System Center.

176
00:09:59.170 --> 00:10:01.260
Walk you through all these
moving parts and pieces.

177
00:10:01.260 --> 00:10:04.670
So if we could start just by taking
a quick look right here for a moment.

178
00:10:04.670 --> 00:10:09.029
Wanna bring my machine up and show you
couple of the things that we're gonna be

179
00:10:09.029 --> 00:10:12.800
able to do with regards to looking
at the Microsoft private cloud.

180

00:23:30.396 --> 00:23:32.145
So we have a lot of
different capabilities,

481
00:23:32.145 --> 00:23:33.668
just depending on what we're doing.

482
00:23:33.668 --> 00:23:36.478
>> Yeah, well I think that's about it for
this particular episode.

483
00:23:36.478 --> 00:23:38.368
Did you have any other final thoughts?

484
00:23:38.368 --> 00:23:40.256
>> Well, you already told them that
there's nothing else I can say, so

485
00:23:40.256 --> 00:23:41.050
it would be inappropriate.

486
00:23:41.050 --> 00:23:43.977
>> [LAUGH] I'm giving you an opportunity.

487
00:23:43.977 --> 00:23:44.666
>> Inappropriate for

488
00:23:44.666 --> 00:23:47.380
me to say something now because
you've already said we're done.

489
00:23:47.380 --> 00:23:50.440
I do actually have just one other thing
quickly, which is to remind you if you're

490
00:23:50.440 --> 00:23:52.563
watching this episode, and
just to give you a preview.

491
00:23:52.563 --> 00:23:55.482
That we are gonna be doing a whole series
of episodes that will follow this, and

492
00:23:55.482 --> 00:23:56.956
hopefully you will take a look at them.

493
00:23:56.956 --> 00:23:59.701
With hands-on installation of
all the different aspects of

494
00:23:59.701 --> 00:24:02.820
the System Center Suite,
we're gonna go through the products, and

495
00:24:02.820 --> 00:24:04.600
we're gonna implement each one.

496
00:24:04.600 --> 00:24:08.036
Show you how to install them, and
walk through the installation of those

497
00:24:08.036 --> 00:24:10.638
particular products and
show you how to stand them up.

498
00:24:10.638 --> 00:24:13.705
So we'll stand up SCOM,
we'll send up Virtual Machine Manager,

499
00:24:13.705 --> 00:24:17.780
we'll take a look at Orchestrator, stand
that up, take a look at service manager.

500
00:24:17.780 --> 00:24:19.817
So we're gonna go through and set up and

501
00:24:19.817 --> 00:24:24.016
configure how all these products are going
to be out of the box kind of installed,

502
00:24:24.016 --> 00:24:27.076
and given to you so
you can start monitoring and managing.

503
00:24:27.076 --> 00:24:30.210
And then based on that,
we'll have a good platform to build on.

504
00:24:30.210 --> 00:24:32.787
So as we continue talking about
how to actually operate and

505
00:24:32.787 --> 00:24:35.942
monitor your private cloud,
you'll have seen all the moving parts and

506
00:24:35.942 --> 00:24:38.887
you'll understand what all those
references are we keep using for

507
00:24:38.887 --> 00:24:41.539
all these products that you may or
may not have seen before.

508
00:24:41.539 --> 00:24:44.161
So I invite you to go take a look at
those if you haven't had a chance,

509
00:24:44.161 --> 00:24:47.005
because you've been watching our
episodes in order up until now.

510
00:24:47.005 --> 00:24:50.555
They're gonna be coming up after this, and
if you have already seen them, well good

511
00:24:50.555 --> 00:24:53.811
for you cuz you're an over-achiever and
we like that, that's important.

512
00:24:53.811 --> 00:24:56.221
>> Well, thank you Adam for
providing a framework and

513
00:24:56.221 --> 00:24:59.191
foundational understanding of
what the Cloud concept is, and

514
00:24:59.191 --> 00:25:03.310
also those tools that you provided us
with all links and extra information.

515
00:25:03.310 --> 00:25:06.797
But like Adam promised, we do want
you guys to stay tuned because we

516
00:25:06.797 --> 00:25:10.058
have some hands-on demonstrations
coming up very shortly.

517
00:25:10.058 --> 00:25:11.786
So make sure you hang around for that.

518
00:25:11.786 --> 00:25:13.809
Otherwise, we're gonna go ahead and
sign off for this show.

519
00:25:13.809 --> 00:25:15.748
Remember, I'm your host Cherokee Boose.

520
00:25:15.748 --> 00:25:16.715
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

521
00:25:16.715 --> 00:25:18.478
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

522
00:25:18.478 --> 00:25:20.616
>> Take care, everybody.

523
00:25:20.616 --> 00:25:26.613
[MUSIC]

524
00:25:26.613 --> 00:25:29.871
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee look at using System Center Virtual Machine Manager. They show how to create custom run as accounts and user roles.
episodes.title: Configuring a Private Cloud Environment
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.140
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.140 --> 00:00:01.873
I'm your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:01.873 --> 00:00:02.495
>> [INAUDIBLE]
>> Live from San Francisco.

4
00:00:02.495 --> 00:00:06.122
>> [INAUDIBLE]

5
00:00:06.122 --> 00:00:08.244
[MUSIC]

6
00:00:08.244 --> 00:00:08.744
>> You're watching ITProTV.
>> Welcome ladies and gentlemen to your

7
00:00:08.744 --> 00:00:13.585
monitoring and operating a private
cloud series. I'm your show host

8
00:00:13.585 --> 00:00:18.144
Cherokee Boose.
In this episode,

9
00:00:18.144 --> 00:00:20.193
we'll looking at how to configure and
operate a private cloud environment.

10
00:00:22.030 --> 00:00:24.460
And with us today we have Mr.
Adam Gordon in studios.

11
00:00:24.460 --> 00:00:26.340
Thank you for joining us Adam.

12
00:00:26.340 --> 00:00:27.750
>> Hello everybody,
hope you're doing well.

13
00:00:27.750 --> 00:00:30.980
We're gonna be talking about and
continuing our conversations with regards

14
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:34.740
to how to set up, as Cherokee was saying,
configuring private cloud environments.

15
00:00:34.740 --> 00:00:37.920
Remember private cloud with regards
to what we're talking about here

16
00:00:37.920 --> 00:00:40.490
is primarily gonna be focusing
around the use of system center

17
00:00:40.490 --> 00:00:44.060
virtual machine manager to
do our cloud fabric for us.

18
00:00:44.060 --> 00:00:47.180
Think of that as being our blank
canvas that we're going to paint

19
00:00:47.180 --> 00:00:51.040
our beautiful virtual environment,
the cloud, upon.

20
00:00:51.040 --> 00:00:54.550
We're gonna be doing that with
a number two fine line paintbrush.

21
00:00:54.550 --> 00:00:55.720
>> Lots of happy trees.

22
00:00:55.720 --> 00:00:56.390
>> Lots of happy trees.

23
00:00:56.390 --> 00:00:58.230
We're gonna be taking a look
at all that in a little bit.

24
00:00:58.230 --> 00:01:01.360
We are gonna take you into the console,
show you a little bit more about VMM.

25
00:01:01.360 --> 00:01:05.075
If you haven't seen the episodes where
we did the System Center installation

26
00:01:05.075 --> 00:01:07.470
walk-through on all
the different suite of products,

27
00:01:07.470 --> 00:01:09.690
you probably wanna go back to
take a quick look at that.

28
00:01:09.690 --> 00:01:12.550
We did a pretty extensive
walk-through of how to install and

29
00:01:12.550 --> 00:01:17.180
configure all the various components
in System Center, VMM was among them.

30
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:19.860
Showed you how to stand that product
up and make sure it was working.

31
00:01:19.860 --> 00:01:24.320
We also talked about and stood up SCOM,
System Center Ops Manager.

32
00:01:24.320 --> 00:01:27.060
And we will be referring to that
product and occasionally go ahead and

33
00:01:27.060 --> 00:01:28.910
take a look there for
the monitoring piece.

34
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:31.880
But we're gonna primarily in this
set of this discussions anyway

35
00:01:31.880 --> 00:01:35.460
really be focusing our attention in on
System Center Virtual Machine Manager and

36
00:01:35.460 --> 00:01:39.690
what VMM can do for
us with regards to private cloud.

37
00:01:39.690 --> 00:01:42.720
So when we think about monitoring and
operating the private cloud,

38
00:01:42.720 --> 00:01:46.750
we think about setting up the enablement
of our private cloud infrastructure,

39
00:01:46.750 --> 00:01:48.230
we think about VMM.

40
00:01:48.230 --> 00:01:51.254
VMM has a lot of key features
that are included with it,

41
00:01:51.254 --> 00:01:55.250
we've hinted at some of these, talked
about some of them in prior episodes.

42
00:01:55.250 --> 00:01:58.490
The ability to be able to set
up our host environments so

43
00:01:58.490 --> 00:02:01.380
at our host in and be able to see them.

44
00:02:01.380 --> 00:02:05.930
Manager across the fabric,
be able to setup storage networking,

45
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:08.582
something called library service
we'll talk more about what those are.

46
00:02:08.582 --> 00:02:10.300
Think file structures and

47
00:02:10.300 --> 00:02:14.300
file server I capabilities in term of
archiving storing things for later usage.

48
00:02:14.300 --> 00:02:16.560
It's what a library server primarily does.

49
00:02:16.560 --> 00:02:17.740
But we haven't really drilled down and

50
00:02:17.740 --> 00:02:20.070
talked specifically about
some of these features.

51
00:02:20.070 --> 00:02:21.390
So let's just name them off here.

52
00:02:21.390 --> 00:02:25.240
We've talked about the ability to
have multi host hyper visor support

53
00:02:25.240 --> 00:02:30.490
in the sense that we have as we did our
installation of VMM and spun it up.

54
00:02:30.490 --> 00:02:34.160
Talked a little bit about the fact that we
can host, and the interesting thing about

55
00:02:34.160 --> 00:02:39.370
Microsoft System Center product line,
specifically SCVMM, it is the only virtual

56
00:02:39.370 --> 00:02:43.350
machine fabric manager in market
right now of the three biggies.

57
00:02:43.350 --> 00:02:46.400
We have VMWare, we have Microsoft,
and we have Citrix.

58
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:50.130
So of those three that are kind
of the leaders in that space,

59
00:02:50.130 --> 00:02:53.070
this is the only product that
manages across all three platforms.

60
00:02:53.070 --> 00:02:58.224
So we will be able to pull in
Microsoft HyperV Hosts and manage HyperV.

61
00:02:58.224 --> 00:03:02.820
We'll be able to pull in and
manage VMware V Center and VMware ESXI

62
00:03:02.820 --> 00:03:07.710
hosts as a result of that, and we can pull
in Citrix Zen servers and manage them.

63
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:10.200
And when I say manage,
we are not going to have

64
00:03:10.200 --> 00:03:14.380
complete stack capabilities in the way
we would if we were using VCenter and

65
00:03:14.380 --> 00:03:19.310
VSphere ESXI and the web client, yet
we would obviously much richer and

66
00:03:19.310 --> 00:03:23.120
more full management capabilities in
the native stack from the vendor.

67
00:03:23.120 --> 00:03:26.240
But we do have awareness of those
products, we can see them at a high level.

68
00:03:26.240 --> 00:03:29.140
We can you know poke our
toe in the water there

69
00:03:29.140 --> 00:03:31.490
look under the hood see
what's going on in Vcenter.

70
00:03:31.490 --> 00:03:34.898
See what's going on with Zen
servers directly from VMM.

71
00:03:34.898 --> 00:03:38.423
We also can and
indeed do have the ability through SCOM,

72
00:03:38.423 --> 00:03:43.770
through the extension into System Center
Ops Manager of using management packs.

73
00:03:43.770 --> 00:03:46.910
That will let us reach out and
manage VM ware infrastructure.

74
00:03:46.910 --> 00:03:48.420
We can manage Vcenter.

75
00:03:48.420 --> 00:03:52.250
We can manage hosts, we can manage our,
the horizon view environment or

76
00:03:52.250 --> 00:03:55.420
VDI or Virtual Desktop Infrastructure
environments.

77
00:03:55.420 --> 00:03:58.130
So we have a lot of
cross-platform capabilities.

78
00:03:58.130 --> 00:04:01.020
Not to mention the Unix Linux
monitoring that goes on in SCOM and

79
00:04:01.020 --> 00:04:03.030
the ability to be able to do all of that.

80
00:04:03.030 --> 00:04:07.510
So we do have a very rich feature set
associated with the use of this product.

81
00:04:07.510 --> 00:04:08.970
We also have Power Shell integration.

82
00:04:08.970 --> 00:04:10.230
Spoke a little about that.

83
00:04:10.230 --> 00:04:12.510
Some of our prior episodes
we showed you the Azure.

84
00:04:12.510 --> 00:04:16.160
A Commandlets for
PowerShell that can be used to monitor and

85
00:04:16.160 --> 00:04:18.502
to manage across SCOM and with SCVMM.

86
00:04:18.502 --> 00:04:19.966
So we've talked a little bit about that.

87
00:04:19.966 --> 00:04:22.450
And we'll see some more
about that as we go.

88
00:04:22.450 --> 00:04:24.960
We mentioned performance and
resource optimization,

89
00:04:24.960 --> 00:04:27.770
what we will call Pro, the acronym for it.

90
00:04:27.770 --> 00:04:33.170
Performance and resource optimization
is technology that sits in SCVMM,

91
00:04:33.170 --> 00:04:36.540
that if you're familiar with VMware,
you would know probably is DRS,

92
00:04:36.540 --> 00:04:38.250
Distributed Resource Scheduling.

93
00:04:38.250 --> 00:04:41.390
Or even just generically,
Oracle's hosting environment for

94
00:04:41.390 --> 00:04:44.830
their virtual infrastructure
has a form of DRS as well.

95
00:04:44.830 --> 00:04:50.310
The idea is,
that we can look at resource usage, and

96
00:04:50.310 --> 00:04:54.450
attempt to load balance, and/or scale that
resource usage, so it is evenly spread, or

97
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:59.370
more evenly spread, across the members
of that resource pool or cluster.

98
00:04:59.370 --> 00:05:03.120
As opposed to front-loading one machine,
just piling on

99
00:05:03.120 --> 00:05:06.425
all the VMs in the requirements for
hosting and leaving the other members,

100
00:05:06.425 --> 00:05:09.995
the other hosts in that resource pool or
cluster, under-utilized.

101
00:05:09.995 --> 00:05:12.895
We don't wanna have an imbalance,
in other words, and performance and

102
00:05:12.895 --> 00:05:16.965
resource optimization is technology that
allows us to try to proactively monitor

103
00:05:16.965 --> 00:05:20.470
for that and balance out if possible
what those loads may look like.

104
00:05:20.470 --> 00:05:24.800
We have intelligent placement, the idea
paired with PRO being able to understand

105
00:05:24.800 --> 00:05:29.190
where we're going to put virtual machines
upon power on and also throughout their

106
00:05:29.190 --> 00:05:33.850
management lifecycle as they're running
across resource pools or clusters.

107
00:05:33.850 --> 00:05:37.380
We can then be able to move them
around with live migration so

108
00:05:37.380 --> 00:05:40.880
that way they stay running but they're
running on different hosts and they're

109
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:44.990
more balanced as a result of that based
on need and based on available resources.

110
00:05:44.990 --> 00:05:49.675
So this would be for us in the real world,
this would be similar to saying,

111
00:05:49.675 --> 00:05:53.715
we have a team of people, and
everybody needs to pitch in and more or

112
00:05:53.715 --> 00:05:57.625
less you'll do something to contribute to
the betterment of our little group here.

113
00:05:57.625 --> 00:05:59.705
Everybody's got a job or a responsibility.

114
00:05:59.705 --> 00:06:03.805
But if somebody finishes early and maybe
is idling and has time on their hands.

115
00:06:03.805 --> 00:06:06.195
Instead of just going and
sitting down and taking a break.

116
00:06:06.195 --> 00:06:08.845
We'll say,
hey why don't you come along and chip in.

117
00:06:08.845 --> 00:06:10.760
Let's redistribute the remaining load.

118
00:06:10.760 --> 00:06:14.040
Let's let everybody else finish a little
bit earlier by you helping out.

119
00:06:14.040 --> 00:06:16.770
So, no slackers,
is what we would say there.

120
00:06:16.770 --> 00:06:20.140
Make sure that everybody pulls their
weight and does what they need to do.

121
00:06:20.140 --> 00:06:22.539
So that's good, if you think about
the thought process here and

122
00:06:22.539 --> 00:06:23.670
the logic of this.

123
00:06:23.670 --> 00:06:26.200
And all the major vendors have
this technology in one form or

124
00:06:26.200 --> 00:06:29.170
another, as I was suggesting, but
it's good to know that we have it here and

125
00:06:29.170 --> 00:06:30.610
we'll be taking a look at it.

126
00:06:30.610 --> 00:06:31.809
We have live migrations,

127
00:06:31.809 --> 00:06:34.861
as I mentioned, we will call this
Vmotion on the VMware platform.

128
00:06:34.861 --> 00:06:37.970
If you're familiar with that technology
it's what we refer to it there.

129
00:06:37.970 --> 00:06:39.460
We have storage migration.

130
00:06:39.460 --> 00:06:44.260
We will call that SV Motion or
Storage V Motion in the VMware platform so

131
00:06:44.260 --> 00:06:45.370
you know what that is.

132
00:06:45.370 --> 00:06:49.100
But we can move with live migration
a running virtual machine

133
00:06:49.100 --> 00:06:52.900
between two hosts in real-time
with no loss of continuity.

134
00:06:52.900 --> 00:06:55.125
So imagine you're running
a virtualized instance,

135
00:06:55.125 --> 00:06:57.030
what we call a guest operating system.

136
00:06:57.030 --> 00:07:00.564
You're running a VM on my
laptop right over here.

137
00:07:00.564 --> 00:07:04.049
I wanna move it over to this laptop over
here, but I don't wanna turn it off,

138
00:07:04.049 --> 00:07:07.387
which is what we'd have to do in
the old-fashioned way of doing things.

139
00:07:07.387 --> 00:07:09.388
So we hosted all of our infrastructure,
physically.

140
00:07:09.388 --> 00:07:13.521
I'd have to power it off,
unrack it, move it, rack it back up,

141
00:07:13.521 --> 00:07:16.059
cable it all back up, power it back on.

142
00:07:16.059 --> 00:07:19.654
There's a delay in time, there is
infrastructure management concerns,

143
00:07:19.654 --> 00:07:23.418
maybe I don't re-cable that thing
the right way, maybe I forget something,

144
00:07:23.418 --> 00:07:25.900
maybe I turned it off the wrong way,
and I crash it.

145
00:07:25.900 --> 00:07:28.002
>> Maybe you drop it while
you're moving it on over.

146
00:07:28.002 --> 00:07:29.246
[LAUGH]
>> Could drop it hurt,

147
00:07:29.246 --> 00:07:32.360
my foot cuz I don't have
my steel-toed work boots.

148
00:07:32.360 --> 00:07:33.671
All these things can go wrong.

149
00:07:33.671 --> 00:07:35.840
And so there is a lot of concern.

150
00:07:35.840 --> 00:07:38.166
But if we can move it in
real-time while it's running.

151
00:07:38.166 --> 00:07:41.814
Never shut it off and
never bother to actually change out,

152
00:07:41.814 --> 00:07:46.506
in the sense that we have to unrack and
rerack and un-cable and re-cable,

153
00:07:46.506 --> 00:07:51.067
all the physical and logical
connectivity and supporting mechanisms.

154
00:07:51.067 --> 00:07:55.090
All we have to do is obviously
program in some stuff in the console.

155
00:07:55.090 --> 00:07:55.992
Make sure everything is good.

156
00:07:55.992 --> 00:07:57.856
We have to have network connectivity,

157
00:07:57.856 --> 00:08:01.190
we've gotta be able to see the resource
from both sides of the divide.

158
00:08:01.190 --> 00:08:04.930
We have to have common storage
area in common or capable for

159
00:08:04.930 --> 00:08:08.590
access so the hosts can take control of
the VM as it moves from one to the other.

160
00:08:08.590 --> 00:08:10.260
We need a common network to do that.

161
00:08:10.260 --> 00:08:12.560
You know, there's obviously
things that have to happen.

162
00:08:12.560 --> 00:08:15.530
But assuming all that's in place,
we push a couple of buttons,

163
00:08:15.530 --> 00:08:18.870
this is the value of work flow,
this is the value of automation.

164
00:08:18.870 --> 00:08:21.940
And that VM zips across and
we never turn it off.

165
00:08:21.940 --> 00:08:24.690
Users attach to it,
never know they're being moved.

166
00:08:24.690 --> 00:08:27.800
And literally we go, and I'm gonna
get this right, we go from here, now

167
00:08:27.800 --> 00:08:31.640
watch carefully cuz I barely, normally I'm
able to do this but I'm gonna do it right.

168
00:08:31.640 --> 00:08:34.290
We're not gonna go this way cuz
that will be bad I go off camera,

169
00:08:34.290 --> 00:08:35.220
instead what are we gonna do?

170
00:08:35.220 --> 00:08:38.820
We're gonna go from here and it's like I'm
here one minute and I'm here the next.

171
00:08:38.820 --> 00:08:41.670
If you close your eyes and
open them up really quick like that.

172
00:08:41.670 --> 00:08:42.610
You may see me
>> [LAUGH]

173
00:08:42.610 --> 00:08:43.740
>> One place among the other and

174
00:08:43.740 --> 00:08:46.680
never know that I moved and
that's exactly what we're talking.

175
00:08:46.680 --> 00:08:49.260
We're gonna be able to do this migration.

176
00:08:49.260 --> 00:08:50.930
This live migration in real time.

177
00:08:51.990 --> 00:08:52.930
So did you close your eyes.

178
00:08:52.930 --> 00:08:55.060
Did you see me.

episodes.description: In this show, Cherokee and Adam explain how to manage the virtual environment with Virtual Machine Manager.  Adam explains the three fabric resource nodes that need to be configured. They also discuss the importance of Library Servers and Library Shares. Lastly, they explain additional configurations options including VM hardware options.

00:01:51.800 --> 00:01:55.045
So you can see the network sites here are

45
00:01:55.045 --> 00:01:56.640
could be used as single connected network.

46
00:01:56.640 --> 00:01:59.630
In other words, everything is

00:01:59.630 --> 00:02:01.040

00:02:01.040 --> 00:02:03.310
It's all together in one area.

49
00:02:03.310 --> 00:02:06.150
We have VLAN based independent networks or
private VLANs,

50
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:07.980
what are called PVLAN networks.

51
00:02:07.980 --> 00:02:10.709
These are nested VLANs,
VLANs inside of other VLANs,

52
00:02:10.709 --> 00:02:12.560
sometimes called secondary VLANs.

53
00:02:12.560 --> 00:02:16.307
Here we refer to them differently, just
depending on who you're talking about, or

54
00:02:16.307 --> 00:02:19.180
rather, whose documentation you
may be reading, I would say.

55
00:02:19.180 --> 00:02:23.520
But you'll see we can be doing primary and
secondary VLANs in isolated mode.

56
00:02:23.520 --> 00:02:28.570
We could stack our VLANs one inside
the other and create a secondary layer

57
00:02:28.570 --> 00:02:32.840
of isolation with a private, a community,
different kinds of VLANs associated.

58
00:02:32.840 --> 00:02:35.380
If you're not familiar with them,
it's definitely an interesting concept.

59
00:02:35.380 --> 00:02:39.770
It's used quite a bit in virtual hosting,
especially in multitenant

60
00:02:39.770 --> 00:02:42.470
environments where we wanna isolate
certain traffic from others.

61
00:02:42.470 --> 00:02:44.550
So it may be something to consider,
think about.

62
00:02:44.550 --> 00:02:47.010
A little out beyond the conversation
we're having right now, but

63
00:02:47.010 --> 00:02:48.460
certainly something to consider.

64
00:02:48.460 --> 00:02:50.060
We do have that capability.

65
00:02:50.060 --> 00:02:52.590
We have our general VLAN
based independent networks.

00:02:52.590 --> 00:02:57.000
We can specify our VLAN pairs here to
find buyer's sites within the logical

00:02:57.000 --> 00:02:59.400

used as independent networks.

00:02:59.400 --> 00:03:00.507
Every VLAN, in other words,

00:03:00.507 --> 00:03:03.270

70
00:03:03.270 --> 00:03:07.900
So as a result, VMs may or may not be

71
00:03:07.900 --> 00:03:11.309
We may not be able to see traffic between
VMs and different VLAN based independent

72
00:03:11.309 --> 00:03:13.981

from an isolation standpoint.

00:03:13.981 --> 00:03:16.300
That's what we want from

we can see Create Hyper-V port profile.

00:10:58.120 --> 00:10:59.114
Just move this over,

254
00:10:59.114 --> 00:11:02.520
cuz this thing keeps coming up,
just on the edge of our box in box.

255
00:11:02.520 --> 00:11:05.350
And so what we do, is you'll see we
can select a different type of Hyper-V

256
00:11:05.350 --> 00:11:07.430
port profile that we wanna use.

257
00:11:07.430 --> 00:11:09.790
Let's go ahead and we'll give it a name.

258
00:11:09.790 --> 00:11:14.830
Let's call this ITProTV

259
00:11:15.830 --> 00:11:18.640
port Hyper-V.

260
00:11:18.640 --> 00:11:19.751
So we'll do that.

261
00:11:19.751 --> 00:11:23.360
We've got our virtual network adapter,
port profile, or uplink port profile.

262
00:11:23.360 --> 00:11:25.760
We'll choose whichever one we wanna use.

263
00:11:25.760 --> 00:11:27.990
Notice we do change what
we're selecting here.

264
00:11:27.990 --> 00:11:29.610
Let's go back and just take a look.

265
00:11:29.610 --> 00:11:31.700
We'll have some different
options depending on what we do.

266
00:11:31.700 --> 00:11:33.547
If we're doing our uplink port profile,

267
00:11:33.547 --> 00:11:35.960
we'll specify our load
balancing algorithm.

268
00:11:35.960 --> 00:11:37.988
We have some different options here for
load balancing.

269
00:11:37.988 --> 00:11:41.354
This is software-based load balancing
done in the networking stack through

270
00:11:41.354 --> 00:11:42.190
the hypervisors.

271
00:11:42.190 --> 00:11:46.040
So through Hyper-V and through
the application of either algorithms that

272
00:11:46.040 --> 00:11:50.150
are used, or the proprietary load
balancing methods that we will deploy.

273
00:11:50.150 --> 00:11:54.638
We're gonna decide how to route traffic
through the switch once we bind this to

274
00:11:54.638 --> 00:11:55.390
the switch.

275
00:11:55.390 --> 00:11:57.780
And then specify how
traffic should be managed.

276
00:11:57.780 --> 00:11:59.030
How do VMs bind?

277
00:11:59.030 --> 00:12:00.370
How do they send traffic?

278
00:12:00.370 --> 00:12:03.280
Do they stay bound to that port,
or do they rotate through?

279
00:12:03.280 --> 00:12:06.740
Or how does traffic get sent and
received back and forth?

280
00:12:06.740 --> 00:12:09.450
And this is what will happen
based on what we choose here.

281
00:12:09.450 --> 00:12:14.330
So we have address hash,
IP address, MAC address hash.

282
00:12:15.460 --> 00:12:19.800
We have different ways of doing this,
Hyper-V port dynamic host default.

283
00:12:19.800 --> 00:12:21.550
We can do different ones.

284
00:12:21.550 --> 00:12:25.005
Each one of these methods has unique
properties associated with it, and

285
00:12:25.005 --> 00:12:26.260
we would have to specify.

286
00:12:26.260 --> 00:12:30.340
Depending on what we do, we in our mind
would have to know how this behaves.

287
00:12:30.340 --> 00:12:35.320
When we do hashing, for instance, we're
taking a, in the case of address hashing,

288
00:12:35.320 --> 00:12:38.170
we're looking at source IP and
destination IP.

289
00:12:38.170 --> 00:12:40.280
We're gonna be able to hash the values.

290
00:12:40.280 --> 00:12:43.450
And then based on what we're sending
from or where we're sending from and

291
00:12:43.450 --> 00:12:47.370
where we're sending to, we're gonna
decide how that traffic gets mapped.

292
00:12:47.370 --> 00:12:50.716
And how it gets sent and
received out through, what uplink adapter,

293
00:12:50.716 --> 00:12:53.320
essentially through what
uplink port on the switch.

294
00:12:53.320 --> 00:12:56.110
And based on that,
we may bind to different uplinks or

295
00:12:56.110 --> 00:13:00.388
different paths out of the virtual switch
from the hypervisor to actually send and

296
00:13:00.388 --> 00:13:02.750
be able to move traffic in and
out of the host.

297
00:13:02.750 --> 00:13:05.846
So there's different options here,
and we do have to be cognizant of or

298
00:13:05.846 --> 00:13:07.200
aware of what our choices are.

299
00:13:07.200 --> 00:13:10.812
Because if we're not paying attention,
we may wind up creating an uplink port

300
00:13:10.812 --> 00:13:14.660
profile that behaves differently than what
it is that we would like to actually do.

301
00:13:14.660 --> 00:13:16.821
So we do have to just think about this,

302
00:13:16.821 --> 00:13:20.880
make sure we're aware of what we
wanna do and the choices we make.

303
00:13:20.880 --> 00:13:22.340
If we choose also, and

304
00:13:22.340 --> 00:13:25.900
we can choose also here, teaming,
we can choose our teaming mode.

305
00:13:25.900 --> 00:13:28.391
We have different options for teaming,

306
00:13:28.391 --> 00:13:32.720
binding the ports together and/or
creating a redundancy solution.

307
00:13:32.720 --> 00:13:36.181
So if we lose one, we still have
the ability to use the others that are in

308
00:13:36.181 --> 00:13:39.190
the team, so that we don't have
a total failure of our path.

309
00:13:39.190 --> 00:13:41.990
And we can use
Link Aggregation Control Protocol.

310
00:13:41.990 --> 00:13:46.885
So we could use LACP to be able to do some
advanced management of traffic outside of

311
00:13:46.885 --> 00:13:50.800
the virtual environment if we support this
out, for instance, in our CISCO gear.

312
00:13:50.800 --> 00:13:52.360
We could be using this in our stack.

313
00:13:52.360 --> 00:13:55.010
And we could be doing bonding and teaming.

314
00:13:55.010 --> 00:13:58.585
And we can do all sorts of stuff that
we could use to manage traffic and

315
00:13:58.585 --> 00:13:59.730
create redundancy.

316
00:13:59.730 --> 00:14:01.570
As well as optimize and
aggregate bandwidth so

317
00:14:01.570 --> 00:14:04.645
we get the full value of all the bandwidth
coming through all the connectors.

318
00:14:04.645 --> 00:14:06.317
So we have a lot of
different options here.

319
00:14:06.317 --> 00:14:08.525
It really just depends on what
our choices are gonna be.

320
00:14:08.525 --> 00:14:10.965
Can we go full screen just so
we can see this a little bit easier?

321
00:14:10.965 --> 00:14:12.785
It's a little bit easier
to see when we do this.

322
00:14:12.785 --> 00:14:16.295
So we're gonna go ahead and
we're gonna do our uplink port profile.

323
00:14:16.295 --> 00:14:22.145
And we're gonna go ahead and
we are going to just go here.

324
00:14:22.145 --> 00:14:24.660
Let's actually just go back one second.

325
00:14:24.660 --> 00:14:30.980
Do this, and we're going to choose our,
which one do we wanna choose?

326
00:14:30.980 --> 00:14:38.387
Do our uplink port, rather, and
we will choose our host default.

327
00:14:38.387 --> 00:14:40.974
And we're gonna leave that
at switch independent.

328
00:14:40.974 --> 00:14:42.340
So we'll just put it
back to the way it was.

329
00:14:42.340 --> 00:14:43.400
We'll get started.

330
00:14:43.400 --> 00:14:44.660
We'll click Next.

331
00:14:44.660 --> 00:14:48.127
Then we're gonna choose our
logical network here for our site.

332
00:14:48.127 --> 00:14:50.070
You can see we have our logical network.

333
00:14:50.070 --> 00:14:52.289
I'm gonna check that off, bring that in,

334
00:14:52.289 --> 00:14:56.160
allowing us to bind this to our
logical network configuration.

335
00:14:56.160 --> 00:14:59.900
Then once we're done,
we'll go ahead and we will click Next.

336
00:14:59.900 --> 00:15:02.910
We just have our summary screen,
no big deal there.

337
00:15:02.910 --> 00:15:04.950
We'll click Finish,
wait for that to happen.

338
00:15:04.950 --> 00:15:06.570
Doesn't take very long.

339
00:15:06.570 --> 00:15:11.120
And then once we have this done,
let me just go back here.

340
00:15:11.120 --> 00:15:12.500
We have our port profile.

341
00:15:12.500 --> 00:15:15.090
Let's just go down here.

342
00:15:15.090 --> 00:15:20.360
And we'll have that right down at
the bottom ITProTV Pro Hyper-V.

343
00:15:20.360 --> 00:15:24.280
So we could see it's an uplink port
type as opposed to a virtual type.

344
00:15:24.280 --> 00:15:25.769
And we could see that it's being used.

345
00:15:25.769 --> 00:15:27.230
We see that it's now been created.

346
00:15:27.230 --> 00:15:28.170
If we need to go in and

347
00:15:28.170 --> 00:15:30.940
take a look at it just like we
did with the others, no big deal.

348
00:15:30.940 --> 00:15:33.130
Go into the properties
that we need to change.

349
00:15:33.130 --> 00:15:36.548
Either the load balancing algorithm,
our teaming mode,

350
00:15:36.548 --> 00:15:38.580
and/or any of the settings here.

351
00:15:38.580 --> 00:15:41.260
We can go in if we wanna add
another network site here.

352
00:15:41.260 --> 00:15:43.880
So we bind it to more than
one logical network, or

353
00:15:43.880 --> 00:15:45.530
unbind from one bind to another.

354
00:15:45.530 --> 00:15:47.530
That kind of thing, we could do that.

355
00:15:47.530 --> 00:15:49.320
So we have all of that available to us.

356
00:15:49.320 --> 00:15:51.165
If we're gonna run in and
talk about this when we created it.

357
00:15:51.165 --> 00:15:55.150
Let's just briefly talk about enabling
Hyper-V host network virtualization.

358
00:15:55.150 --> 00:15:59.325
If we're running, as you can see here,
on a host running server 12 only,

359
00:15:59.325 --> 00:16:03.434
we will then be able to set this up
because we have to enable it versus 12 R2

360
00:16:03.434 --> 00:16:05.940
where this is automatically enabled for
us.

361
00:16:05.940 --> 00:16:09.105
So we don't have to worry about it going
forward, in other words, in the newer OSs.

362
00:16:09.105 --> 00:16:12.816
But in the older OS, we would enable
the Hyper-V network virtualization, so

363
00:16:12.816 --> 00:16:16.015
we would have to check that off
to enable that and ensure that.

364
00:16:16.015 --> 00:16:19.869
We turn that on in the Hyper-V stack,
because in 12 it was an option,

365
00:16:19.869 --> 00:16:20.717
not a default.

366
00:16:20.717 --> 00:16:23.297
Whereas in 12R2 and 16,
it is enabled by default.

367
00:16:23.297 --> 00:16:25.949
So we would just have to make
sure we're aware of that,

368
00:16:25.949 --> 00:16:27.687
check that off if that's the case.

369
00:16:27.687 --> 00:16:30.007
And then we can go ahead and
just make sure that gets enabled.

370
00:16:30.007 --> 00:16:32.407
Click OK, and it will go through and
configure that for us.

371
00:16:32.407 --> 00:16:35.537
So we'd be able to create that
port profile and use that.

372
00:16:35.537 --> 00:16:37.577
We're not gonna turn it on,
cuz we're on 12R2.

373
00:16:37.577 --> 00:16:40.647
So it's actually already enabled for
us, won't have to worry about it.

374
00:16:40.647 --> 00:16:45.183
But we would create whatever port profiles
we need using those port profiles,

375
00:16:45.183 --> 00:16:47.450
linking them to our logical networks or

376
00:16:47.450 --> 00:16:51.660
sites that we're then gonna be able to
use to be able to use our networks.

377
00:16:51.660 --> 00:16:54.089
And then once we've added in
the other components and the parts,

378
00:16:54.089 --> 00:16:55.915
we're gonna go in and
create an IP address pool.

379
00:16:55.915 --> 00:16:58.695
We'll be taking a look at that,
a MAC address pool as well.

380
00:16:58.695 --> 00:17:01.925
We'll be building out some of the other
building blocks of the network fabric.

381
00:17:01.925 --> 00:17:04.425
So we'll be doing that in
our upcoming conversations.

382
00:17:04.425 --> 00:17:07.595
Once we have all those pieces together,
we'll actually have a functional

383
00:17:07.595 --> 00:17:10.528
structured network fabric that we
can begin to communicate across.

384
00:17:10.528 --> 00:17:13.199
And we'll then use that going
forward in our other demonstrations,

385
00:17:13.199 --> 00:17:16.238
our other discussions, to be able to
start deploying VMs and using the network

386
00:17:16.238 --> 00:17:19.425
topology we're creating to be able to
have them communicate with one another.

387
00:17:19.425 --> 00:17:22.714
So we'll be continuing these
conversations in just a few minutes.

388
00:17:22.714 --> 00:17:26.170
>> All right, well, without further ado,
let's go ahead and get started with that.

389
00:17:26.170 --> 00:17:27.740
So ladies and gentlemen, stay tuned.

390
00:17:27.740 --> 00:17:30.000
But for this show we're gonna go ahead and
sign off.

391
00:17:30.000 --> 00:17:32.440
Remember, I'm your host, Cherokee Boose,
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

392
00:17:32.440 --> 00:17:34.660
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

393
00:17:34.660 --> 00:17:41.840
[MUSIC]

394
00:17:41.840 --> 00:17:44.950
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Daniel discuss the process to install and configure Operations Manager
episodes.title: Install Operations Manager on Single Server

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.190
Welcome to IT PRO TV.

2
00:00:01.190 --> 00:00:03.494
I'm your host, [CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:03.494 --> 00:00:04.985
>> You're watching IT PRO TV.

4
00:00:04.985 --> 00:00:09.921
>> All right, greetings everyone and

00:00:09.921 --> 00:00:17.510
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:17.510 --> 00:00:18.540
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

7
00:00:18.540 --> 00:00:22.510
And in today's episode we are coming back
at you with more of our configuring and

8
00:00:22.510 --> 00:00:25.940
deploying a private cloud series and
of course joining us,

9
00:00:25.940 --> 00:00:29.480
like a day without sunshine,
it would be a day without Mr. Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:29.480 --> 00:00:31.500
Adam, welcome back we're so
glad to have you again.

11
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:35.398
>> It is going fantabulously well,
I feel like I'm [INAUDIBLE] with sunshine.

12
00:00:35.398 --> 00:00:36.760
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's what I feel like,

13
00:00:36.760 --> 00:00:37.620
a day with sunshine.

14
00:00:37.620 --> 00:00:38.450
>> Blue skies.

15
00:00:38.450 --> 00:00:39.520
>> Blue skies, coming your way.

16
00:00:39.520 --> 00:00:44.160
So we're gonna continue our
discussion/demo series here

17
00:00:44.160 --> 00:00:45.860
with focusing on the SCOM product now,

18
00:00:45.860 --> 00:00:50.200
the center piece of what we've been
talking about in these shows/episodes.

19
00:00:50.200 --> 00:00:54.270
We've done some of the background and
some of the supporting cast of characters.

20
00:00:54.270 --> 00:00:58.200
We set up in episode one in
this series the VMM product.

21
00:00:58.200 --> 00:01:00.560
We set up in episode

22
00:01:00.560 --> 00:01:04.200
We're now gonna do SCOM and
configure SCOM on a single server install.

23
00:01:04.200 --> 00:01:07.420
The reason we're gonna do that is it's
just easier to bring all that together in

24
00:01:07.420 --> 00:01:12.040
one place, do the demo for you, than it
is to have all those different pieces

25
00:01:12.040 --> 00:01:15.490
configured out and having to jump
through them during the demo just to put

26
00:01:15.490 --> 00:01:19.310
the database in place, just to
configure this, just to configure that.

27
00:01:19.310 --> 00:01:22.090
So we're gonna do a standard
all-in-one install,

28
00:01:22.090 --> 00:01:25.960
database assumption is it's
running on the same machine.

29
00:01:25.960 --> 00:01:29.170
Remember in the real world, if you're
setting this up at a lab environment,

30
00:01:29.170 --> 00:01:30.320
this is most likely what you would do.

31
00:01:30.320 --> 00:01:33.737
Anyway, if you're gonna do this in
production, the only difference is where

32
00:01:33.737 --> 00:01:37.391
you go to spec out the database and say
where is my database, where's my instance.

33
00:01:37.391 --> 00:01:39.362
You will be connecting
to a remote machine.

34
00:01:39.362 --> 00:01:43.250
But other than that, most of what we're
gonna do is gonna look identical for you.

35
00:01:43.250 --> 00:01:44.566
Just to be aware of of that.

36
00:01:44.566 --> 00:01:47.542
We are gonna start out with
dealing with our pre reqs.

37
00:01:47.542 --> 00:01:50.079
But I'm gonna do this a little bit
differently than I have done in some of

38
00:01:50.079 --> 00:01:50.854
the prior episodes.

39
00:01:50.854 --> 00:01:52.606
I'm gonna bring PowerShell
into the mix here.

40
00:01:52.606 --> 00:01:55.130
We will take a look at this in a minute,
we like PowerShell.

41
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:57.720
And we have to be using it for
a variety of things.

42
00:01:57.720 --> 00:02:00.771
So it's always important to think
about how we can use PowerShell,

43
00:02:00.771 --> 00:02:01.794
what we can use it for.

44
00:02:01.794 --> 00:02:04.301
Remember the ideas,
anything we could do in the GUI

45
00:02:04.301 --> 00:02:06.868
traditionally can be done
through PowerShell, and

46
00:02:06.868 --> 00:02:10.660
there may always be additional things
that are PowerShell only or PowerShell

47
00:02:10.660 --> 00:02:14.362
centric that may not apply to the GUI or
may not be possible through the GUI.

48
00:02:14.362 --> 00:02:18.174
But in this case what we're gonna
do in PowerShell is install and

49
00:02:18.174 --> 00:02:23.117
configure the web service, the web server
function rather as a role on the box prior

50
00:02:23.117 --> 00:02:26.290
to installing SCOM, and
then also configure it.

51
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:29.650
We could easily do that through the GUI
using the server manager, but I'm gonna

52
00:02:29.650 --> 00:02:32.260
show you how to do it in PowerShell
as a pre req to get this set up.

53
00:02:32.260 --> 00:02:33.910
So let's take a look if we could.

54
00:02:33.910 --> 00:02:35.840
We'll start with that,
we'll get that going,

55
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:39.800
and then once that's done we'll jump
in and actually do our install.

56
00:02:39.800 --> 00:02:41.620
We've got our media already loaded.

57
00:02:41.620 --> 00:02:43.020
Our set up file ready to go.

58
00:02:43.020 --> 00:02:45.948
But what we're gonna do
is jump in to PowerShell,

59
00:02:45.948 --> 00:02:50.634
I've adjusted the console shell font and
background and color scheme before.

60
00:02:50.634 --> 00:02:52.292
It's going to be easier for you to see.

61
00:02:52.292 --> 00:02:55.450
And what we've done is we've
gone ahead and I've typed in

62
00:02:55.450 --> 00:03:00.240
the add Windows feature of PowerShell
cmdlet, followed by the feature we want,

63
00:03:00.240 --> 00:03:04.150
in this case, the web server,
followed by a long string, no spaces,

64
00:03:04.150 --> 00:03:07.670
comma separated, of all
the configuration parameters we need.

65
00:03:07.670 --> 00:03:10.744
So, when we're doing the web server,
and we're gonna then go in and

66
00:03:10.744 --> 00:03:14.407
do the Web Management Compatibility,
Web ASP, so we're gonna install the ASP.

67
00:03:14.407 --> 00:03:19.371
We're gonna go ahead of the Active Server
page content, we're gonna go through and,

68
00:03:19.371 --> 00:03:23.519
as you see, when you read through
that string, set up ASP.NET 4.5,

69
00:03:23.519 --> 00:03:27.320
ASP.NET, HTTP activation,
include the management tools.

70
00:03:27.320 --> 00:03:28.300
Do all the various things.

71
00:03:28.300 --> 00:03:30.160
The asape filters are there as well.

72
00:03:30.160 --> 00:03:32.390
All the things we need done
to configure this out and

73
00:03:32.390 --> 00:03:35.360
have the .NET framework capability
built in and ready to go.

74
00:03:35.360 --> 00:03:38.960
So we're gonna go ahead, let me just
click in here so we're all set.

75
00:03:38.960 --> 00:03:43.683
And we're gonna hit Enter and
get our little paste buffer there.

76
00:03:43.683 --> 00:03:48.310
Let me do that, and then actually do
it this way, one second, I forgot.

77
00:03:48.310 --> 00:03:53.090
Gotta just backspace one, and
then we'll be able to, there we go.

78
00:03:53.090 --> 00:03:55.310
Tools, activate the console.

79
00:03:55.310 --> 00:03:59.100
Little trick in our demo environment to
make sure it's working the right way.

80
00:03:59.100 --> 00:04:00.605
>> It's fun showing things on live TV,
isn't it?

81
00:04:00.605 --> 00:04:01.135
>> It is live so

82
00:04:01.135 --> 00:04:04.686
you gotta have those little things happen
