IP address information, etc.

763
00:37:40.130 --> 00:37:44.660
We'd be able to go in, look at detailed
health monitoring with various dashboards.

764
00:37:44.660 --> 00:37:47.180
Things like disk health, right,
would be displayed here.

765
00:37:47.180 --> 00:37:49.050
We'd be able to see what that looks like.

766
00:37:49.050 --> 00:37:51.740
Again, nothing is monitoring yet,
because we're just out of the box,

767
00:37:51.740 --> 00:37:52.880
but you get the idea.

768
00:37:52.880 --> 00:37:55.150
Performance would be
looked at here as well.

769
00:37:55.150 --> 00:38:00.380
And so, all of these views and all this
information is coming to us out of

770
00:38:00.380 --> 00:38:04.080
the management packs that have been
installed, with the default configuration.

771
00:38:04.080 --> 00:38:06.910
And then we start to delve in, modify, and

772
00:38:06.910 --> 00:38:11.300
manipulate as necessary to create
the environment, install the agents and

773
00:38:11.300 --> 00:38:15.390
start to do the in-depth monitoring
that SCOM is actually gonna be used for.

774
00:38:15.390 --> 00:38:18.520
>> All right, definitely a lot to
take a look at when it comes to

775
00:38:18.520 --> 00:38:22.255
the Operations Manager, and now
>> We know how to install the thing,

776
00:38:22.255 --> 00:38:24.955
we can actually do that and
start playing around in there,

777
00:38:24.955 --> 00:38:29.215
start getting things connected and
monitoring as well.

778
00:38:29.215 --> 00:38:30.395
Adam, we do thank you for

779
00:38:30.395 --> 00:38:33.755
showing us how to get this far because
this is an important step for us.

780
00:38:33.755 --> 00:38:37.932
So being able to install this thing, get
it running operational is very important.

781
00:38:37.932 --> 00:38:39.582
And now I think that,

782
00:38:39.582 --> 00:38:43.012
hopefully our audience there will have
the ability to do that very thing.

783
00:38:43.012 --> 00:38:46.512
And being so, I'm looking at our clock,
our time is will expired, but for

784
00:38:46.512 --> 00:38:49.782
very good reason, we hang in there for
it, for you good people, so

785
00:38:49.782 --> 00:38:52.812
that you have knowledge, which is power.

786
00:38:52.812 --> 00:38:54.852
That being said,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

787
00:38:54.852 --> 00:38:56.152
For ITProTV, thanks for watching.

788
00:38:56.152 --> 00:38:58.462
I've been your host Daniel Larry
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

789
00:38:58.462 --> 00:39:00.961
>> And we'll see you next time.

790
00:39:00.961 --> 00:39:06.978
[MUSIC]

791
00:39:06.978 --> 00:39:10.798
Thank you for watching IT PRO TV.

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Daniel discuss installing and configuring App Controller.
episodes.title: Install and Configure App Controller Server
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:00.911
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.911 --> 00:00:01.576
I'm your host.

3
00:00:01.576 --> 00:00:06.258
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.258 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:11.585
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.585 --> 00:00:13.618
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:13.618 --> 00:00:16.271
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.271 --> 00:00:17.754
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:17.754 --> 00:00:21.643
And in today's episode, we are back
with more of our configuring and

10
00:00:21.643 --> 00:00:23.668
deploying a private cloud series.

11
00:00:23.668 --> 00:00:27.569
And joining us in the studio, uou know
him, the man, the myth, the legend,

12
00:00:27.569 --> 00:00:28.910
that is Mr. Adam Gordon.

13
00:00:28.910 --> 00:00:30.750
Adam, welcome back, sir,
and how's it going today?

14
00:00:30.750 --> 00:00:31.460
>> Going really well.

15
00:00:31.460 --> 00:00:32.060
Going really well.

16
00:00:32.060 --> 00:00:33.960
Hopefully, it's going well for you also.

17
00:00:33.960 --> 00:00:37.080
We're gonna continue our discussion/demos.

18
00:00:37.080 --> 00:00:39.830
Installing various aspects
of the system center suite.

19
00:00:39.830 --> 00:00:41.740
We're going to be configuring,
installing and

20
00:00:41.740 --> 00:00:44.240
configuring the App Controller Server
piece.

21
00:00:44.240 --> 00:00:46.390
We're gonna take you through that,
see how that works.

22
00:00:46.390 --> 00:00:49.160
Just reminding you the last episode,
in case you haven't seen it,

23
00:00:49.160 --> 00:00:51.990
probably a good idea to walk
through these sequentially.

24
00:00:51.990 --> 00:00:54.090
We configured the SCVMM products.

25
00:00:54.090 --> 00:00:57.090
So we installed
System Center Virtual Machine Manager.

26
00:00:57.090 --> 00:01:01.060
We finished up that install with
a restart of the VMM server

27
00:01:01.060 --> 00:01:03.310
to enable us to then
continue where we are.

28
00:01:03.310 --> 00:01:06.330
We'll go there in just a second to
install the app controller piece.

29
00:01:06.330 --> 00:01:08.495
We're installing it on the VMM Server.

30
00:01:08.495 --> 00:01:12.445
But we talked about the fact we need that
restart at the end of the VMM install

31
00:01:12.445 --> 00:01:16.666
in order to set the system, make sure that
we can do the app controller install.

32
00:01:16.666 --> 00:01:20.543
If you don't do that, what you find
is you get about, oo, third or so,

33
00:01:20.543 --> 00:01:24.182
maybe halfway through the app
controller install, and it stops.

34
00:01:24.182 --> 00:01:26.589
And says, hey, by the way,
you have a pending restart and

35
00:01:26.589 --> 00:01:29.212
we need to get that done before
you can actually do the install.

36
00:01:29.212 --> 00:01:31.882
And it wipes out all
the information you typed in.

37
00:01:31.882 --> 00:01:33.415
You gotta restart and start over again.

38
00:01:33.415 --> 00:01:36.277
So just reminding you of that
as we get started here so

39
00:01:36.277 --> 00:01:38.891
you don't get caught by
that in the real world.

40
00:01:38.891 --> 00:01:43.427
In addition, I did also remind you in
the last episode that VMM has a strange

41
00:01:43.427 --> 00:01:47.980
habit of not always starting the service
to load the console properly.

42
00:01:47.980 --> 00:01:48.830
It usually works.

43
00:01:48.830 --> 00:01:52.340
I don't wanna give you the case or
the sense that it will not work correctly.

44
00:01:52.340 --> 00:01:57.092
But we do see sometimes in the real world
that the VMM service will, even though

45
00:01:57.092 --> 00:02:01.712
it's set to autostart, will go to
delayed start and not start up properly.

46
00:02:01.712 --> 00:02:03.821
So if you have a problem
loading the console,

47
00:02:03.821 --> 00:02:06.220
just make sure you go check
that service on the box.

48
00:02:06.220 --> 00:02:07.682
It's usually nothing more than that.

49
00:02:07.682 --> 00:02:11.020
If you start the service up,
you'll find the console loads right away.

50
00:02:11.020 --> 00:02:13.362
So just a few little
minor things to consider.

51
00:02:13.362 --> 00:02:17.620
Just be aware of real world
scenarios/issues you wanna address.

52
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:20.683
And that way you're not stuck having to
scratch your head and think about, hey,

53
00:02:20.683 --> 00:02:21.778
what's going on with that?

54
00:02:21.778 --> 00:02:25.120
How did that not or did happen or
not happen the right way?

55
00:02:25.120 --> 00:02:25.924
All right, so we're gonna go ahead.

56
00:02:25.924 --> 00:02:26.428
We're gonna go in.

57
00:02:26.428 --> 00:02:29.712
Gonna take a look at how to do
the app controller install.

58
00:02:29.712 --> 00:02:32.528
What you're gonna see up there,
I've just gonna ahead and

59
00:02:32.528 --> 00:02:34.168
loaded the app controller media.

60
00:02:34.168 --> 00:02:35.706
So we just started that up.

61
00:02:35.706 --> 00:02:38.483
We've got our setup foul right there.

62
00:02:38.483 --> 00:02:41.050
We're gonna right-click,
do run as administrator,

63
00:02:41.050 --> 00:02:42.530
as you're used to seeing me do.

64
00:02:42.530 --> 00:02:44.285
Just reminding you of that so we know.

65
00:02:44.285 --> 00:02:48.320
On the system center 2012
App Controller install interface,

66
00:02:48.320 --> 00:02:50.400
you'll notice we do install.

67
00:02:50.400 --> 00:02:52.276
But you'll notice we have a checkbox here.

68
00:02:52.276 --> 00:02:56.103
And what we're gonna see is that this
says use Microsoft update to go out and

69
00:02:56.103 --> 00:02:58.420
check for updates to app controller.

70
00:02:58.420 --> 00:02:59.542
This is important.

71
00:02:59.542 --> 00:03:03.970
I know we talked about in the VMM
install that there is a checkbox.

72
00:03:03.970 --> 00:03:06.436
It occurs at the end of the install cycle.

73
00:03:06.436 --> 00:03:10.965
As we finish up on the complete screen,
we unchecked it in the demo, saying, hey,

74
00:03:10.965 --> 00:03:13.962
use Windows Update to go out and
download new updates.

75
00:03:13.962 --> 00:03:16.024
We said in the real world
leave that checked off,

76
00:03:16.024 --> 00:03:18.200
you wanna make sure you
update the product.

77
00:03:18.200 --> 00:03:20.280
We're doing that on the front end here.

78
00:03:20.280 --> 00:03:24.310
The reason is that we're probably
gonna need some specific software

79
00:03:24.310 --> 00:03:28.310
that's gonna have to be in or
on the box as a prereq for app controller.

80
00:03:28.310 --> 00:03:32.005
You're gonna see that, and I'm just gonna
click Install while we're talking just to

81
00:03:32.005 --> 00:03:33.840
kick this off, so we can get this running.

82
00:03:33.840 --> 00:03:38.400
But what you'll see is we're gonna go out,
we're gonna check for that software.

83
00:03:38.400 --> 00:03:39.713
And then once we do that,

84
00:03:39.713 --> 00:03:43.416
we are gonna actually then potentially
have to download and install.

85
00:03:43.416 --> 00:03:46.270
We're gonna go out and check and
see it's doing that right now.

86
00:03:46.270 --> 00:03:50.670
Comes out, brings up our, hey,
let's put in our product key.

87
00:03:50.670 --> 00:03:53.890
We talked about this on the last
install with VMM as well.

88
00:03:53.890 --> 00:03:56.770
In the real world, clearly you would
license these products, right?

89
00:03:56.770 --> 00:03:58.870
Cuz you have to use them in production.

90
00:03:58.870 --> 00:04:02.622
In the demo environments we're building
and or you may build to practice with,

91
00:04:02.622 --> 00:04:05.148
you don't have to necessarily
install the license.

92
00:04:05.148 --> 00:04:06.994
You can install the product as an eval.

93
00:04:06.994 --> 00:04:09.690
If you do that, you get 180 day usage.

94
00:04:09.690 --> 00:04:13.740
Or 90 days, depending on what version
you downloaded, that kinda thing.

95
00:04:13.740 --> 00:04:16.700
If it's one of the beta release,
or pre-release builds,

96
00:04:16.700 --> 00:04:21.560
versus the full, finished product release
build, you may get 90 versus 180 days.

97
00:04:21.560 --> 00:04:23.550
But if you're using full-release product,

98
00:04:23.550 --> 00:04:27.810
in this case 2012 R2 would be,
you get 180 day eval.

99
00:04:27.810 --> 00:04:28.982
So you could skip the license key.

100
00:04:28.982 --> 00:04:30.710
We're gonna skip that as well.

101
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:34.240
It does tell you right here, hey,
we're putting this in an eval mode or

102
00:04:34.240 --> 00:04:36.400
an eval edition,
if you're not gonna license it.

103
00:04:36.400 --> 00:04:37.423
So we'll click Next.

104
00:04:37.423 --> 00:04:42.284
We get our EULA, we're gonna check off and
say we read that, even though we did not,

105
00:04:42.284 --> 00:04:44.540
as Daniel reminded me last time.

106
00:04:44.540 --> 00:04:47.620
And you'll notice that checkbox
we had on the first screen.

107
00:04:47.620 --> 00:04:49.840
Hey, do we need to check for
missing software?

108
00:04:49.840 --> 00:04:53.010
Absolutely, you'll see we got
a couple of items here, on the WCF,

109
00:04:53.010 --> 00:04:56.810
the Windows Communication Framework,
data services version five.

110
00:04:56.810 --> 00:05:00.940
The web server IIS roll has to be
installed and configured on the box.

111
00:05:00.940 --> 00:05:04.360
It is not, so we're gonna configure
that as part of the install.

112
00:05:04.360 --> 00:05:06.050
So these things are gonna happen.

113
00:05:06.050 --> 00:05:09.445
So we're gonna be going through and
having this do its thing.

114
00:05:09.445 --> 00:05:13.459
Now we can, just so we know,
in case we think we missed something,

115
00:05:13.459 --> 00:05:15.050
verify pre-reqs again.

116
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:16.227
We're not gonna bother doing that.

117
00:05:16.227 --> 00:05:17.860
We know we have all the pre-reqs.

118
00:05:17.860 --> 00:05:20.363
But if for some reason,
you feel you're missing something or

119
00:05:20.363 --> 00:05:23.072
something doesn't look right,
just rerun that pre-req check.

120
00:05:23.072 --> 00:05:25.110
You could do that at the lower-left.

121
00:05:25.110 --> 00:05:28.083
And then obviously once you get the
results, make sure you have what you need.

122
00:05:28.083 --> 00:05:30.370
We're gonna click Install.

123
00:05:30.370 --> 00:05:31.135
I'm gonna let this do its thing.

124
00:05:31.135 --> 00:05:34.880
It is gonna take a few minutes to
download, get all of that done.

125
00:05:34.880 --> 00:05:37.800
It's enabling IIS and
the role services right now.

126
00:05:37.800 --> 00:05:40.120
We'll wait for that to finish,
we'll come on back and

127
00:05:40.120 --> 00:05:42.460
we'll take a look at what's that done,
and then we'll continue.

128
00:05:43.670 --> 00:05:46.314
All right, so you could see we've got
our select install pass screen up.

129
00:05:46.314 --> 00:05:49.728
We finished downloading our prereqs,
configuring IIS,

130
00:05:49.728 --> 00:05:52.800
got the WCF Services Version
5 installed in there.

131
00:05:52.800 --> 00:05:55.104
We're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna use the default path.

132
00:05:55.104 --> 00:05:57.950
We can obviously modify
this in the real world.

133
00:05:57.950 --> 00:05:59.968
Just keep in mind here,
free disk space, about 24 GB.

134
00:05:59.968 --> 00:06:01.854
What do we require?

135
00:06:01.854 --> 00:06:02.400
50 MB.

136
00:06:02.400 --> 00:06:04.951
Real, real small install compared
to some of the others, right?

137
00:06:04.951 --> 00:06:09.364
Remember, [COUGH] some of the other
software we took a look at as pre-reqs to

138
00:06:09.364 --> 00:06:12.584
the VMM, we needed about three
to four gigs of space for

139
00:06:12.584 --> 00:06:15.470
the Windows deployment
kit that we downloaded.

140
00:06:15.470 --> 00:06:16.974
We don't need that for
this, this is really tiny.

141
00:06:16.974 --> 00:06:19.740
So we're just gonna go ahead and
click Next here.

142
00:06:19.740 --> 00:06:22.150
Configure the services, what kinda
service account are we gonna use?

143
00:06:22.150 --> 00:06:23.560
Gonna do our domain account.

144
00:06:23.560 --> 00:06:24.726
So we're just gonna click here.

145
00:06:24.726 --> 00:06:26.965
I'll just put this in real quick.

146
00:06:26.965 --> 00:06:32.340
This'll be our domain, so
practice labs administrator.

147
00:06:32.340 --> 00:06:36.974
And then make sure that's
spelled correctly cuz-

148
00:06:36.974 --> 00:06:37.903
>> [CROSSTALK] It does matter, doesn't it?

149
00:06:37.903 --> 00:06:39.900
>> I am just such a great typist.

150
00:06:39.900 --> 00:06:41.180
Yeah, spelling does matter.

151
00:06:41.180 --> 00:06:42.700
Believe it or not, it does.

152
00:06:42.700 --> 00:06:43.899
And we have our password there.

153
00:06:43.899 --> 00:06:45.710
We do have our port number
down at the bottom.

154
00:06:45.710 --> 00:06:47.198
I don't know if you're able to see that or
not.

155
00:06:47.198 --> 00:06:51.094
We could go to full screen for
just a second just to show you that,

156
00:06:51.094 --> 00:06:56.087
you'll see the port number down
here 18000, 18622, 18,622.

157
00:06:56.087 --> 00:07:00.929
This is the traditional port that's
used for app controller communication.

158
00:07:00.929 --> 00:07:02.176
We can modify that.

159
00:07:02.176 --> 00:07:05.673
Probably don't wanna do that, but we could
go in to modify that if we wanted to.

160
00:07:05.673 --> 00:07:08.312
We'd have to make some
changes in other areas.

161
00:07:08.312 --> 00:07:11.512
And it may get a little complicated
to get it right everywhere, but

162
00:07:11.512 --> 00:07:13.470
we can modify that port, if necessary.

163
00:07:13.470 --> 00:07:14.480
So, you'll see it here.

164
00:07:15.770 --> 00:07:17.340
Gonna go ahead and click Next.

165
00:07:17.340 --> 00:07:19.034
We have to configure the website now.

166
00:07:19.034 --> 00:07:23.111
Remember, the app controller is gonna be
resting on top of the IIS role that we've

167
00:07:23.111 --> 00:07:24.050
configured.

168
00:07:24.050 --> 00:07:27.959
So we need to make sure that
we are setting up the website.

169
00:07:27.959 --> 00:07:31.035
And having it configured the right way so
that we can interact with it and

170
00:07:31.035 --> 00:07:32.760
app controller can leverage it.

171
00:07:32.760 --> 00:07:34.266
So we're gonna go ahead and
just take a look.

172
00:07:34.266 --> 00:07:38.530
We have our default IP address all
unassigned, meaning it'll bind to any IP.

173
00:07:38.530 --> 00:07:42.932
We've got our default port here,
443, so secure communications for

174
00:07:42.932 --> 00:07:44.073
HTTPS being used.

175
00:07:44.073 --> 00:07:45.912
We'll see that here.

176
00:07:45.912 --> 00:07:50.001
We do then have either the ability
to use an existing certificate, or

177
00:07:50.001 --> 00:07:52.974
we have to generate
a self-signed certificate.

178
00:07:52.974 --> 00:07:57.208
We can go ahead, if we use the existing
certificate, and pull down,

179
00:07:57.208 --> 00:08:01.880
we'll see that we have our domain
specified here, or domain certificate,

180
00:08:01.880 --> 00:08:04.007
quote unquote, specified here.

181
00:08:04.007 --> 00:08:08.405
The machinepracticelabs.com Certificate
that's been issued behind the scenes.

182
00:08:08.405 --> 00:08:12.640
This is just the certificate that's
been used or setup for this demo.

183
00:08:12.640 --> 00:08:15.840
In the real world you would either have
to have a certificate already available,

184
00:08:15.840 --> 00:08:20.130
it could be a self signed certificate
issued to the machine from your PKI,

185
00:08:20.130 --> 00:08:21.960
from your Public Key Infrastructure.

186
00:08:21.960 --> 00:08:23.740
Probably ADCS, right, so

187
00:08:23.740 --> 00:08:26.690
the Active Directory Certificate Services
would be used to self sign and

188
00:08:26.690 --> 00:08:30.740
auto generate a certificate that could
then be assigned to this machine.

189
00:08:30.740 --> 00:08:34.240
You could generate a self signed
certificate on this machine itself.

190
00:08:34.240 --> 00:08:36.720
Would be up to you to
decide how to do that.

191
00:08:36.720 --> 00:08:40.250
But if the domain certificate
services issues the certificate,

192
00:08:40.250 --> 00:08:42.260
you'll then have it published and
made available.

193
00:08:42.260 --> 00:08:44.685
You could pull it in either way,
so we'll go ahead or

194
00:08:44.685 --> 00:08:47.343
a third party certificate as
well from a third party PKI.

195
00:08:47.343 --> 00:08:49.460
We'll just go ahead and grab this.

196
00:08:49.460 --> 00:08:50.780
We click View here.

197
00:08:50.780 --> 00:08:54.300
We can see the certificate just quickly so
you can see what it looks like.

198
00:08:54.300 --> 00:08:57.460
This is our standard X509 E3
certificate template.

199
00:08:57.460 --> 00:08:59.410
Nothing too weird about this.

200
00:08:59.410 --> 00:09:01.080

Didn't set it up and install it

No big deal, you just have to

So make sure you opt out of those if

00:19:42.210 --> 00:19:43.780

Go back and

So okay, you've got the opt-ins, but

00:19:57.800 --> 00:20:02.800
print down there, asterisk after each one,

This is the behavior,
they just want you to know that, right?

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, thank you very much.

It will take just a moment to download and

They do say in the little prompt there

You could see it is pretty quick, It has

That's the super secret magnetic

For you to see the console there.

It's almost as good as the swirling

No big deal, just reminding you of that.

no restriction other than just

No one's gonna die but

And we'll interact with this

But we can see this is fully

488
00:21:38.360 --> 00:21:42.030
At that point, we can either sign out or

489
00:21:42.030 --> 00:21:43.630
We'll go ahead and we'll sign out.

490
00:21:43.630 --> 00:21:48.010
And then once we've done that we'll see

491
00:21:48.010 --> 00:21:50.270
Whoops should.
Lets try that one more time.

492
00:21:50.270 --> 00:21:52.630
That's the refresh issue

493
00:21:52.630 --> 00:21:54.064
Lets do it this way.

494
00:21:54.064 --> 00:21:57.820
Lets just do this and get rid of that.

495
00:21:57.820 --> 00:21:58.675
But that's good enough.

496
00:21:58.675 --> 00:22:01.457
Without refreshing it, it doesn't actually
sign out the right way the first time.

497
00:22:01.457 --> 00:22:05.175
I'll be, you can see once we've done
the install, we're all set, ready to go.

498

And that completes our discussion and
our demo for you,

499

server product.

500
00:22:10.017 --> 00:22:12.121
Come back and join us for another episode,

501
00:22:12.121 --> 00:22:15.842
we are gonna be taking a look at how
to configure and install opps manager.

502
00:22:15.842 --> 00:22:17.740
That's going to be I believe
our next demo coming up,

503

that'll be an interesting one especially
given the fact that that's gonna be

504

the focus of our attention from majority

505
00:22:23.372 --> 00:22:27.097
Really important demo, you wanna see how
we build that out from the ground up,

506
00:22:27.097 --> 00:22:29.525
and make sure we understand
how to configure it, so

507
00:22:29.525 --> 00:22:33.210
we can be successful at doing our
data center monitoring in the cloud.

508
00:22:33.210 --> 00:22:34.340
So come back and see us for that.

509
00:22:34.340 --> 00:22:36.272
>> Awesome stuff Adam and
thank you so much for

510
00:22:36.272 --> 00:22:38.956
showing us how to get the apps
manager installed very very or

511
00:22:38.956 --> 00:22:41.383
our controller should I say
apps control [CROSSTALK].

512
00:22:41.383 --> 00:22:45.070
Managers and controllers all over

513
00:22:45.070 --> 00:22:45.796
>> Everything wants to be heard.

514
00:22:45.796 --> 00:22:47.590
>> Yeah exactly.

515
00:22:47.590 --> 00:22:49.632
All right, that being said, it looks like
we've come to the end of our episode.

516
00:22:49.632 --> 00:22:52.080
Hopefully, you've enjoyed it, and
you've learned something from it.

517
00:22:52.080 --> 00:22:53.558
We strive hard to make that the very case.

518
00:22:53.558 --> 00:22:55.942
And we're going to ahead and
sign-off, though.

519
00:22:55.942 --> 00:22:58.270
For ITPROTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

00:22:58.270 --> 00:23:00.068

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.149 --> 00:00:06.208
[CROSSTALK]
You're

2

00:00:12.648 --> 00:00:14.422
>> All right, greetings everyone and

welcome to another great episode of ITPRO
TV, I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in

00:00:18.441 --> 00:00:23.210

6
00:00:23.210 --> 00:00:27.339
And joining us in our [LAUGH] in our
studio here, our good friend Mr.

Adam Gordon [LAUGH].

how is it going today?

9
00:00:30.980 --> 00:00:31.572
>> Good.
>> [LAUGH]

10
00:00:31.572 --> 00:00:32.074
>> Good, good.

11

How's it going? Hello.

12
00:00:32.896 --> 00:00:33.726
>> There he is.
>> [LAUGH]

13
00:00:33.726 --> 00:00:35.310
>> All right, so we're gonna pick up and

00:00:35.310 --> 00:00:40.450
continue our demonstration/explanation
of the components and

15
00:00:40.450 --> 00:00:43.825
all the surroundings environment
around SCOM in system center.

00:00:43.825 --> 00:00:46.980
Just to remind you, if you haven't
seen the episodes up until now,

00:00:46.980 --> 00:00:48.450

We did the VMM,

We did the app controller, we did SCOM,

we're about to do the,

The Orchestrator, right,
that's what we're doing now right?

22

>> That's right, you get to [INAUDIBLE]
>> Yeah we're gonna do the Orchestrator.

23

So we're gonna have Daniel orchestrate for
us.

24
00:01:05.944 --> 00:01:09.048
Tthe Orchestrator product is
the automation workflow product.

25
00:01:09.048 --> 00:01:10.674
This is like PowerShell, but

26
00:01:10.674 --> 00:01:14.708
with a graphical interface allowing
us to be able to build workflows, and

27
00:01:14.708 --> 00:01:18.300

are called integration connectors.

28
00:01:18.300 --> 00:01:19.840
We're gonna be able to connect and

29
00:01:19.840 --> 00:01:23.150
use integration packages to be
able to manage workflow and

30
00:01:23.150 --> 00:01:27.540
build componentized, compartmentalized
workflows for various products.

31
00:01:27.540 --> 00:01:30.260
Really cool little
aspect of system center.

32
00:01:30.260 --> 00:01:33.680
Not a lot of people use the product and
use it well.

33
00:01:33.680 --> 00:01:35.800
I see this in the field with
a lot of the customers.

34
00:01:35.800 --> 00:01:37.640
They hear about it, they wanna use it.

35
00:01:37.640 --> 00:01:39.025
They're not really sure
what to do with it.

36
00:01:39.025 --> 00:01:41.440
And it is a really,
really neat little product.

37
00:01:41.440 --> 00:01:44.230
We're gonna show you how to
set this up and install this.

38
00:01:44.230 --> 00:01:46.130
So we're gonna go ahead
jump right in if we can.

39
00:01:46.130 --> 00:01:47.000
We'll take a look.

40
00:01:47.000 --> 00:01:50.010
So we've got our installation
media loaded up.

41
00:01:50.010 --> 00:01:52.220
Our System Center Orchestrator Media.

42
00:01:52.220 --> 00:01:55.309
We're gonna right click on set
up Orchestrator down here,

43
00:01:56.440 --> 00:01:59.080
do the run as administrator
as we always do.

44
00:01:59.080 --> 00:02:00.690
Let's just get that out of the way.

45
00:02:00.690 --> 00:02:01.760
Bring this up, and

46
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:05.790
you'll see here we have our System Center
2012 R2 Orchestrator product.

47
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:07.690
Do our install right here.

48
00:02:07.690 --> 00:02:10.970
So let's just click on that, and
we'll give that just a second to spin up.

49
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:13.700
We get our standard product
registrations screen.

50
00:02:13.700 --> 00:02:15.210
Most of these products will look more or

51
00:02:15.210 --> 00:02:18.390
less the same,
the naming of the product notwithstanding.

52
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:21.360
So we're gonna go ahead as
we've been doing, set this up.

53
00:02:21.360 --> 00:02:23.350
We'll call this administrator.

54
00:02:23.350 --> 00:02:27.130
We'll put this in as practicelabs.

55
00:02:27.130 --> 00:02:31.010
We're gonna bypass our key on this one,
set up as an eval.

56
00:02:31.010 --> 00:02:34.790
So go ahead and we'll do that,
we're gonna accept our EULA, and yes,

57
00:02:34.790 --> 00:02:37.440
I did read it ahead of time,
in case you were wondering.

58
00:02:37.440 --> 00:02:39.300
And, if we could just zoom in for
a minute,

59
00:02:39.300 --> 00:02:43.350
go full screen just to see this here,
we do have Management Server selected

60
00:02:43.350 --> 00:02:46.770
by default, but notice the options,
we are gonna leave all the defaults.

61
00:02:46.770 --> 00:02:48.390
But we have the runbook server.

62
00:02:48.390 --> 00:02:52.340
We have the Orchestator console, and
Web Service, and the Runbook Designer.

63
00:02:52.340 --> 00:02:55.290
The designer is where we're going to
actually build out our workflows.

64
00:02:55.290 --> 00:02:57.865
It's going to be our drag and
drop grid-like environment.

65
00:02:57.865 --> 00:03:00.020
And we are going to be able to go in, and

66
00:03:00.020 --> 00:03:02.930
use that to be able to build out
our workflows and deploy them.

67
00:03:02.930 --> 00:03:03.772
We'll take a look at that.

68
00:03:03.772 --> 00:03:06.270
So we're to go head and
do this install, we'll kick this off.

69
00:03:06.270 --> 00:03:06.994
Let's click Next.

70
00:03:06.994 --> 00:03:09.620
We're going to check for
required hardware and software.

71
00:03:09.620 --> 00:03:11.860
You'll see that we have
that piece well in hand.

72
00:03:11.860 --> 00:03:13.400
We have to configure our service account.

73
00:03:13.400 --> 00:03:15.970
So we are gonna go in,
set up the information we need here.

74
00:03:15.970 --> 00:03:21.010
We will install with our
practicelabs account,

75
00:03:21.010 --> 00:03:23.425
so let me just spell that correctly here.

76
00:03:23.425 --> 00:03:27.350
Practicelabsadministrator, the one
we've been using for

77
00:03:27.350 --> 00:03:30.410
most of our installs, so
we'll do administrator.

78
00:03:30.410 --> 00:03:33.490
We're gonna do our
standard password here and

79
00:03:33.490 --> 00:03:37.100
then, what we're gonna do is you'll see
we have our domain down at the bottom.

80
00:03:37.100 --> 00:03:40.095
We are gonna run a test to make sure
we put the credential in correctly,

81
00:03:40.095 --> 00:03:42.720
didn't fat-finger anything or
screwed something up.

82
00:03:42.720 --> 00:03:45.560
Cuz you never know, you may have made
a mistake, you want to catch it now, so

83
00:03:45.560 --> 00:03:46.650
we'll check it quickly.

84
00:03:46.650 --> 00:03:49.320
You could see credential accepted,
that's what we're looking for.

85
00:03:49.320 --> 00:03:51.379
Now we're gonna click next here,

86
00:03:51.379 --> 00:03:55.499
we're gonna then have to go in and
configure the database server, so

87
00:03:55.499 --> 00:03:59.991
we're gonna specify what we're gonna
do here for our database instance.

88
00:03:59.991 --> 00:04:03.324
Remember we're doing an all in one install
where we have our database running on

89
00:04:03.324 --> 00:04:03.930
the machine.

90
00:04:03.930 --> 00:04:05.125
We've been using that for

91
00:04:05.125 --> 00:04:08.810
our various demonstrations in
the different episodes we've been doing.

92
00:04:08.810 --> 00:04:11.050
So we have an instance
of SQL running locally.

93
00:04:11.050 --> 00:04:13.750
As a result we're gonna
use that local instance.

94
00:04:13.750 --> 00:04:16.940
In the real world as you're doing
your install in the organization,

95
00:04:16.940 --> 00:04:20.530
out the enterprise, whenever you're doing
this, you may path this differently.

96
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:22.140
So just understand what
I'm about to type in,

97
00:04:22.140 --> 00:04:26.180
in other words, is the local install and
the instance for the local install.

98
00:04:26.180 --> 00:04:28.110
You may choose to do this differently.

99
00:04:28.110 --> 00:04:30.730
So I'm gonna put in practicelabs.

100
00:04:30.730 --> 00:04:33.080
So let's just put that in, no,
I'm sorry, not practicelabs.

101
00:04:33.080 --> 00:04:34.360
Thinking about the credential here.

102
00:04:34.360 --> 00:04:35.530
Getting ahead of myself.

103
00:04:35.530 --> 00:04:41.841
I'm gonna put in the name on my machine,
plab, for practice labs,

104
00:04:41.841 --> 00:04:47.508
this is our sys right or
sys machine, so plabsysbuild01.

105
00:04:47.508 --> 00:04:54.750
And then our database instance
mssqlserver, so we're gonna use that.

106
00:04:54.750 --> 00:04:57.200
We have our default port there, 1433.

107
00:04:57.200 --> 00:05:02.680
We're gonna go ahead and specify our
Windows authentication credential

108
00:05:02.680 --> 00:05:07.280
will be used, so we're not gonna put in
a specific credential for SQL, but rather

109
00:05:07.280 --> 00:05:11.060
just use our built-in Windows credential
that we're already supplying and using.

110
00:05:11.060 --> 00:05:14.391
We could test our database connection,
always good to do that check that out,

111
00:05:14.391 --> 00:05:16.714
make sure we haven't typed
in that name incorrectly,

112
00:05:16.714 --> 00:05:18.290
have a problem with the credential.

113
00:05:18.290 --> 00:05:20.020
Again, want to check these things out.

114
00:05:20.020 --> 00:05:23.889
Its a good way for us to catch errors
up front and not start the install and

115
00:05:23.889 --> 00:05:27.150
find out things are not going to
go well and have to backtrack.

116
00:05:27.150 --> 00:05:29.230
So we're going to go ahead and
do that, it doesn't take very long,

117
00:05:29.230 --> 00:05:30.990
typically about 30 seconds or so.

118
00:05:30.990 --> 00:05:33.420
You could see that here
we do have success, so

119
00:05:33.420 --> 00:05:35.745
that is good, so
we're going to click Next.

120
00:05:35.745 --> 00:05:38.320
We're then going to be asked
about configuring the database,

121
00:05:38.320 --> 00:05:40.930
are we doing a new install
with a new database.

122
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:41.820
We are going to do that.

123
00:05:41.820 --> 00:05:44.680
You'll see the default database
name there is Orchestrator.

124
00:05:44.680 --> 00:05:46.390
So we're gonna accept that.

125
00:05:46.390 --> 00:05:49.020
But we could specify an existing
database if we chose to.

126
00:05:49.020 --> 00:05:50.770
Be up to us to decide.

127
00:05:50.770 --> 00:05:52.770
Remember in the real world,

128
00:05:52.770 --> 00:05:56.060
if you are setting up multiple instances,
you may already have a database.

129
00:05:56.060 --> 00:05:58.520
And as a result you may have a named
instance you wanna connect to.

130
00:05:58.520 --> 00:06:01.140
So we're gonna do a new database,
we'll leave that alone.

131
00:06:01.140 --> 00:06:03.522
We're then gonna setup
the Orchestrator users group.

132
00:06:03.522 --> 00:06:06.460
In other words,
what group are we going to specify

133
00:06:07.640 --> 00:06:11.170
that is going to allow us to have
access to the Runbook Designer and

134
00:06:11.170 --> 00:06:14.690
the deployment manager,
portions of your Orchestrator install.

135
00:06:14.690 --> 00:06:17.070
Orchestrator is
a compartmentalized program.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee explain Service Templates. Adam relates them to a blank canvas or a Lego plate to build custom settings in a modular way. Tune in now to watch the process demonstrated as they discuss different options.

1

Welcome to ITPro.TV.

00:00:16.760 --> 00:00:18.449

8

In this episode we'll be walking through
the steps to demonstrate how to utilize

Server App-V.

Adam Gordon.

actually mentioned Server App-V,

just to remind you quickly.

21

App-V, the concept of virtualizing an
application is the idea of being able to

22
00:00:55.536 --> 00:00:59.658

record essentially all the settings,

23
00:00:59.658 --> 00:01:04.060

24

Put that together in a package alone with
the application binary themselves and

25
00:01:07.947 --> 00:01:11.222
then use that as a portable
solution that we can throw and

26
00:01:11.222 --> 00:01:14.299
deploy when needed
virtualizing the application.

27
00:01:14.299 --> 00:01:15.929
In this case, Server App-V so

28
00:01:15.929 --> 00:01:18.962
application that will be deployed

29
00:01:18.962 --> 00:01:20.846
Service deployment traditionally,

30
00:01:20.846 --> 00:01:22.578
we'll throw that into our
service design template.

31
00:01:22.578 --> 00:01:26.046
We'll take a look at how to do that
talked about that in a prior episode.

32

And, when we throw that, then that becomes
part of the deployment into the cloud for

33
00:01:30.908 --> 00:01:32.045

34
00:01:32.045 --> 00:01:35.814
The nice thing about running
an application that's virtualized is we're

35
00:01:35.814 --> 00:01:39.236
not actually installing the app
with the full footprint on the box.

36
00:01:39.236 --> 00:01:43.632
But rather running it, essentially its
own isolated space without any worry or

37
00:01:43.632 --> 00:01:45.738
concern about what it does to the box.

38
00:01:45.738 --> 00:01:48.286
Because when we're done,
shut the application off, essentially

39
00:01:48.286 --> 00:01:51.729
there's nothing left behind, because
that we we're using to run the app and

40
00:01:51.729 --> 00:01:55.652
configure it is part of the application
package, so it is totally portable and

41
00:01:55.652 --> 00:01:57.493
leaves behind no footprint, essentially.

42
00:01:57.493 --> 00:01:59.974
So this is nice, we are going to
take a look at how to set this up.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam demonstrates a step by step tutorial on how to create, import,  and export Service Templates. You will also get a chance to see how to modify the properties of a virtual machine template.

00:28:57.180 --> 00:28:58.910
You can do versioning
however you would like.

673
00:28:58.910 --> 00:29:02.990
It's really unique to your dev
environment through thought process,

674
00:29:02.990 --> 00:29:05.330
the methodology and
the frameworks you may use.

675
00:29:05.330 --> 00:29:09.410
But which ever one you choose, pretty much
everyone of them has this thought process

676
00:29:09.410 --> 00:29:12.300
associated with it and you'll see
it's a standardized thought process.

677
00:29:12.300 --> 00:29:16.770
So you may want to start using
the release area here to actually signify

678
00:29:16.770 --> 00:29:19.888
versioning and
as a result track that over time.

679
00:29:19.888 --> 00:29:23.045
And that may be something that will
just help you to keep track and

680
00:29:23.045 --> 00:29:24.754
iterate through your templates.

681
00:29:24.754 --> 00:29:27.590
If you're going to do that,
what you may do,

682
00:29:27.590 --> 00:29:29.920
is instead of just updating
the main template,

683
00:29:29.920 --> 00:29:33.930
you may have noticed since I've gone in
and done this, I can copy the template.

684
00:29:33.930 --> 00:29:37.470
So, I can make a copy of it, you'll see,
and then I can use the copy, and

685
00:29:37.470 --> 00:29:39.210
I can start creating changes in the copy.

686
00:29:39.210 --> 00:29:44.506
So, I may freeze kind of a golden master
template that's set up and is structured,

687
00:29:44.506 --> 00:29:49.596
and then I make iterated copies and then
make changes from there if I choose you.

688
00:29:49.596 --> 00:29:53.157
So you could see the copy of QA, right,
which is just right-click-copy, and

689
00:29:53.157 --> 00:29:56.899
it's there, and then I'm going to be able
to go in and I'm able to modify the copy.

690
00:29:56.899 --> 00:29:59.009
And then I could change
the versioning on that.

691
00:29:59.009 --> 00:30:04.314
Because if I do that and I change
the release, instead of copy of QA,

692
00:30:04.314 --> 00:30:08.240
you know, I may make this QA 1.1 or
something.

693
00:30:08.240 --> 00:30:12.102
And just by doing that alone, you'll
see that now I can stack them up, and

694
00:30:12.102 --> 00:30:13.797
I can kind of keep track of them.

695
00:30:13.797 --> 00:30:16.221
And I can see when they're created,
or at least look at the properties,

696
00:30:16.221 --> 00:30:17.230
have a sense of that.

697
00:30:17.230 --> 00:30:19.310
But I can then start creating
a burgeoning solution.

698
00:30:19.310 --> 00:30:22.110
>> Well yeah, even by just that naming
convention you don't even have to

699
00:30:22.110 --> 00:30:23.930
guess you just use the logic.

700
00:30:23.930 --> 00:30:26.160
>> Absolutely or you can just use
The Force, whatever makes more sense.

701
00:30:26.160 --> 00:30:27.245
>> There you go.

702
00:30:27.245 --> 00:30:29.974
>> All right, so one other thing I just
thought I'd show you really quick since

703
00:30:29.974 --> 00:30:32.662
we've been talking about user roles,
and just using that access tab, and

704
00:30:32.662 --> 00:30:34.174
seeing how the rule would get delegated.

705
00:30:34.174 --> 00:30:37.310
I haven't really showed it to you, we've
talked about it in a prior episode, but

706
00:30:37.310 --> 00:30:40.180
I thought, what should we do to round
this out and make this perfect?

707
00:30:40.180 --> 00:30:43.730
Put the proverbial cherry
on the Cherokee rule.

708
00:30:43.730 --> 00:30:45.698
So, we're going to go ahead, and we're
going to create that rule for Cherokee.

709
00:30:45.698 --> 00:30:47.754
I've actually already created it,
so we have it in there.

710
00:30:47.754 --> 00:30:49.756
Because I was quick in doing
that while she was talking, but

711
00:30:49.756 --> 00:30:51.930
I'm just going to quickly show
you where those rules come from.

712
00:30:51.930 --> 00:30:53.310
So we're going to go ahead and
take a look.

713
00:30:53.310 --> 00:30:56.033
We're over here in the settings area,
in the work space.

714
00:30:56.033 --> 00:31:00.289
We're going to go up under security,
we have our user roles right here.

715
00:31:00.289 --> 00:31:04.553
Snd just click on that, and you'll see,
aside from the administrator role that's

716
00:31:04.553 --> 00:31:07.512
there by default,
I've created a role called Cherokee.

717
00:31:07.512 --> 00:31:11.555
And we're going to use that Cherokee role
or delegate it back over to that template.

718
00:31:11.555 --> 00:31:13.104
And then I'm going to
walk you back through and

719
00:31:13.104 --> 00:31:14.342
just show you where that comes from.

720
00:31:14.342 --> 00:31:17.703
But let me just start the wizard up to
show you which templates you want to use.

721
00:31:17.703 --> 00:31:20.134
Cuz there's several
different user templates and

722
00:31:20.134 --> 00:31:22.405
only one of them actually
gives you this right.

723
00:31:22.405 --> 00:31:25.230
So let's just take a look here,
we're going to go in, right-click.

724
00:31:25.230 --> 00:31:28.040
And or let's just actually do
it up here create user role.

725
00:31:28.040 --> 00:31:30.880
I'll give it a name, doesn't really matter
what we call it because we're not going to

726
00:31:30.880 --> 00:31:32.770
bother to go all the way through.

727
00:31:32.770 --> 00:31:34.950
But under profile this
is where we want to be.

728
00:31:34.950 --> 00:31:39.220
We want this right here the application
administrator self service user.

729
00:31:40.470 --> 00:31:44.320
Just highlight that, you'll see it does
add in some additional items here.

730
00:31:44.320 --> 00:31:48.800
But this role once we go through set
it all up is then going to actually be

731
00:31:48.800 --> 00:31:53.070
the role that will show up on that list,
we'll check it off and we'll assign it to

732
00:31:53.070 --> 00:31:56.220
that template and we're going to go back
and show you how to bind that right now.

733
00:31:56.220 --> 00:31:59.860
But we go through,
we'd specify the members of the role here.

734
00:31:59.860 --> 00:32:02.180
So admin, the users, administrator, guest,

735
00:32:02.180 --> 00:32:05.620
whoever, make sure they're domain members
because we're going to validate their ID.

736
00:32:05.620 --> 00:32:08.630
We'll go ahead,
we'll specify our networking.

737
00:32:08.630 --> 00:32:11.740
So if we do have a network we'll bind it,
if not we can create one.

738
00:32:11.740 --> 00:32:15.368
Resources, what resource do you want
to make available what template do we

739
00:32:15.368 --> 00:32:16.130
want to bind.

740
00:32:16.130 --> 00:32:18.690
We could skip that and
always just add it in after the fact,

741
00:32:18.690 --> 00:32:20.040
doesn't matter either way.

742
00:32:20.040 --> 00:32:21.750
Permissions that's a big one.

743
00:32:21.750 --> 00:32:25.703
Do we want to go ahead and do we want
to be able to narrowly define or

744
00:32:25.703 --> 00:32:29.020
broadly allow permissions and
access to resources.

745
00:32:29.020 --> 00:32:32.670
So can we turn on a VM,
turn it off, power it off,

746
00:32:32.670 --> 00:32:34.330
pause it there's different
permission levels.

747
00:32:34.330 --> 00:32:36.550
You see them if you run all
the way through the Wizard.

748
00:32:36.550 --> 00:32:37.655
So we're just going to cancel out here,

749
00:32:37.655 --> 00:32:39.960
because we're not going to bother
create that, we already have it.

750
00:32:39.960 --> 00:32:43.090
So what we're going to do is come back
over here, we'll go back to fabric.

751
00:32:43.090 --> 00:32:45.290
Go back to our, excuse me,
back to library rather.

752
00:32:45.290 --> 00:32:46.700
To our library, to our template.

753
00:32:46.700 --> 00:32:49.750
I would choose whatever template,
it doesn't really matter which one.

754
00:32:49.750 --> 00:32:51.580
Right click, we'll go into properties.

755
00:32:52.950 --> 00:32:57.000
Go down to our access area and
you'll see here when we go in and

756
00:32:57.000 --> 00:32:59.970
add that our Cherokee role that
we've created is there, and so

757
00:32:59.970 --> 00:33:03.920
if we grab that and click okay,
that's how we then say okay for

758
00:33:03.920 --> 00:33:07.640
this role whoever's the member, they're
now going to have rights specifically

759
00:33:07.640 --> 00:33:11.320
to use this template based on
the permissions and scoping that we did.

760
00:33:11.320 --> 00:33:13.560
So we can start to narrowly define and

761
00:33:13.560 --> 00:33:16.100
create these self-service options for
users.

762
00:33:16.100 --> 00:33:17.625
Which gives a lot more flexibility,

763
00:33:17.625 --> 00:33:20.350
but also a lot more control,
as an administrator, ultimately,

764
00:33:20.350 --> 00:33:23.780
over the resources we create and
the deployments of them.

765
00:33:23.780 --> 00:33:27.541
And then who's going to ultimately be able
to use them to drive the use of and/or

766
00:33:27.541 --> 00:33:29.170
the deployment of this template,

767
00:33:29.170 --> 00:33:33.119
versus maybe users that we don't want
using this template, for various reasons.

768
00:33:33.119 --> 00:33:36.038
So that's what we would do here,
we would just simply click, OK.

769
00:33:36.038 --> 00:33:39.470
And once we've done that,
we would have the user roles set up here.

770
00:33:39.470 --> 00:33:40.579
Click OK again.

771
00:33:40.579 --> 00:33:42.901
And then that user role is
scoped to this template,

772
00:33:42.901 --> 00:33:46.790
and we'll now be allowed to use it
based on whatever settings we provided.

773
00:33:46.790 --> 00:33:50.030
>> All right, Adam, that does bring us to
the end of this particular episode, but

774
00:33:50.030 --> 00:33:51.140
we've covered a lot, right?

775
00:33:51.140 --> 00:33:54.330
We've looked at importing,
exporting, looking at how to

776
00:33:54.330 --> 00:33:58.280
create service templates, and also
looking at our virtual machine templates.

777
00:33:58.280 --> 00:33:58.860
Anything else?

778
00:33:58.860 --> 00:33:59.840
Am I forgetting anything?

779
00:33:59.840 --> 00:34:01.594
>> No, I think that was everything.

780
00:34:01.594 --> 00:34:02.691
Except for the fact that-
>> All right, high-five!

781
00:34:02.691 --> 00:34:04.108
>> High-five.
Except the fact that you and

782
00:34:04.108 --> 00:34:06.900
I are switched, so when you said
all right, Adam, it's actually you.

783
00:34:06.900 --> 00:34:07.429
>> Yeah.

784
00:34:07.429 --> 00:34:08.078
>> Because you're me, and I'm you.

785
00:34:08.078 --> 00:34:09.214
>> So let's go ahead and sign off.

786
00:34:09.214 --> 00:34:09.782
>> Okay, let's do that.

787
00:34:09.782 --> 00:34:13.560
>> So, for this particular episode,
remember, I'm your show host, Adam Gordon.

788
00:34:13.560 --> 00:34:14.199
>> I'm Cherokee Boose.

789
00:34:14.199 --> 00:34:15.029
You like my hair?

790
00:34:15.029 --> 00:34:17.845
>> [LAUGH] See you next
time here at ITProTV.

791
00:34:17.845 --> 00:34:20.269
>> Take care, everybody.

792
00:34:20.269 --> 00:34:26.237
[MUSIC]

793
00:34:26.237 --> 00:34:29.492
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this show, Adam demonstrates a step by step tutorial on how to create and use Application Profiles.
episodes.title: Application Profiles
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.062
Welcome to ITPro TV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.062 --> 00:00:06.348
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.348 --> 00:00:08.255
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.255 --> 00:00:12.115
>> You're watching ITPro TV.

5
00:00:12.115 --> 00:00:15.445
>> Welcome to your Monitoring and
Operating a Private Cloud series.

6
00:00:15.445 --> 00:00:17.425
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:17.425 --> 00:00:18.395
In this episode,

8
00:00:18.395 --> 00:00:21.835
you'll see a demonstration on how
to create application profiles.

9
00:00:21.835 --> 00:00:25.795
And to walk us through this demonstration,
we have Mr. Adam Gordon in studios.

10
00:00:25.795 --> 00:00:27.555
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

11
00:00:27.555 --> 00:00:30.068
Yes, walking through the demonstration.

12
00:00:30.068 --> 00:00:31.848
[LAUGH]
>> Walking through the demonstration,

13
00:00:31.848 --> 00:00:32.930
here we are walking.

14
00:00:32.930 --> 00:00:36.510
So we're gonna go through and take a look
at, very quickly kind of remind ourselves

15
00:00:36.510 --> 00:00:38.360
of what application profiles
are on the console.

16
00:00:38.360 --> 00:00:38.940
I know you've seen them,

17
00:00:38.940 --> 00:00:42.090
we've talked about them, probably not
a lot of mystery there at this point.

18
00:00:42.090 --> 00:00:45.570
But in case you haven't seen our prior
episodes in this area remind you that you

19
00:00:45.570 --> 00:00:47.840
should think about going in and
taking a look.

20
00:00:47.840 --> 00:00:48.800
If you have and

21
00:00:48.800 --> 00:00:52.130
you're keeping up-to-date with us, we're
going to do a quick run through the app

22
00:00:52.130 --> 00:00:55.870
profile creation process focusing on one
of the elements we haven't touched on yet.

23
00:00:55.870 --> 00:00:58.530
Which is adding in pre and
post install scripts and

24
00:00:58.530 --> 00:01:00.220
just talking about what we can do there.

25
00:01:00.220 --> 00:01:02.560
Show you how we'd stack those apps up,
and configure them.

26
00:01:02.560 --> 00:01:03.908
We're gonna go ahead and jump right in.

27
00:01:03.908 --> 00:01:08.510
If we take a look,
got our console open, our SCVMM console.

28
00:01:08.510 --> 00:01:11.010
We are in, as you can see,
our library workspace.

29
00:01:11.010 --> 00:01:13.951
We have our profiles area selected,
our application profiles,

30
00:01:13.951 --> 00:01:14.971
over here on the left.

31
00:01:14.971 --> 00:01:17.979
We're just gonna either right click and
choose go in and

32
00:01:17.979 --> 00:01:20.880
create an app profile,
depending on the item.

33
00:01:20.880 --> 00:01:22.800
Just wait for
it to connect here, there we go.

34
00:01:22.800 --> 00:01:26.230
[LAUGH] We can either go in,
right-click, Create App Profile,

35
00:01:26.230 --> 00:01:28.910
and/or just come up here,
Create App Profiles.

36
00:01:28.910 --> 00:01:30.980
Again, we have different options,
depending on where we are.

37
00:01:30.980 --> 00:01:34.250
Doesn't matter by the way, both
the options wind up in the same place.

38
00:01:34.250 --> 00:01:37.300
We get our wizard here,
we'll go ahead and we'll give it a name.

39
00:01:37.300 --> 00:01:44.730
So let's just call this
ITProTV app profile one.

40
00:01:44.730 --> 00:01:50.300
And then under compatibility
we can choose either general

41
00:01:50.300 --> 00:01:54.490
you'll see we can choose SQL server
application host or web application host

42
00:01:54.490 --> 00:01:58.240
depending on what it is this particular
application profile is gonna focus on.

43
00:01:58.240 --> 00:02:03.250
Remember under application profiles we
can add in our sequel data application.

44
00:02:03.250 --> 00:02:04.650
We can add in our web application.

45
00:02:04.650 --> 00:02:08.410
And so our web deploy zip file that
gives us the output of the web app.

46
00:02:08.410 --> 00:02:10.840
We can do application virtualization.

47
00:02:10.840 --> 00:02:11.930
So we have different options.

48
00:02:11.930 --> 00:02:13.831
So we are gonna make a choice here.

49
00:02:13.831 --> 00:02:17.029
We can obviously decide if
we do web application host,

50
00:02:17.029 --> 00:02:21.825
then when we come over here and we start
adding in our applications you'll see that

51
00:02:21.825 --> 00:02:23.931
we limit ourselves just to web app.

52
00:02:23.931 --> 00:02:28.035
You can see it's filtered the list,
so that way we only get the app or

53
00:02:28.035 --> 00:02:29.768
the application category.

54
00:02:29.768 --> 00:02:34.109
Or categories that are specific to that
kind of compatibility that we chose on

55
00:02:34.109 --> 00:02:34.988
the prior tab.

56
00:02:34.988 --> 00:02:40.980
If we go back here to general and
we choose SQL Server Application Hosting.

57
00:02:40.980 --> 00:02:43.669
Come over here and we choose add.

58
00:02:43.669 --> 00:02:48.200
You'll see that we are limited just to
our SQL DAC, our data tier application.

59
00:02:48.200 --> 00:02:49.810
So we're just constraining and

60
00:02:49.810 --> 00:02:54.790
limiting ourselves in the template to
just this specific kind of application.

61
00:02:54.790 --> 00:02:57.560
No mistake by saying, hey,
let me click and do both.

62
00:02:57.560 --> 00:02:59.490
And then, you know, we only support one.

63
00:02:59.490 --> 00:03:04.500
So we can be narrowly defined we can scope
and tailor here, or we could go general.

64
00:03:04.500 --> 00:03:08.490
And if we go general we'll have access
to any and all of the application types.

65
00:03:08.490 --> 00:03:12.467
Let's just choose general and you'll
see under application configuration.

66
00:03:12.467 --> 00:03:16.982
You'll see we have our script
application virtual app,

67
00:03:16.982 --> 00:03:20.375
as well as SQL, and the data application.

68
00:03:20.375 --> 00:03:22.115
The DAC SQL application and the web apps.

69
00:03:22.115 --> 00:03:23.945
So we could choose any or all of these.

70
00:03:23.945 --> 00:03:26.925
So it's really up to us to
decide how we want to do this.

71
00:03:26.925 --> 00:03:30.461
There's no right and wrong, but if we
know we're gonna deploy a web app there's

72
00:03:30.461 --> 00:03:32.697
no harm in doing general and
just choosing web app.

73
00:03:32.697 --> 00:03:36.426
Or we can go ahead and just choose
web app compatibility up front, and

74
00:03:36.426 --> 00:03:40.750
then it just tailors and scopes that for
us and only allows us to choose web apps.

75
00:03:40.750 --> 00:03:42.250
So it's up to us to decide.

76
00:03:42.250 --> 00:03:46.120
We'll just go ahead and we'll choose one
just now for purposes of demonstration.

77
00:03:46.120 --> 00:03:49.230
But before we do that let me go
back up here to OS compatibility.

78
00:03:49.230 --> 00:03:53.470
We would wanna choose the appropriate
operating system compatibility.

79
00:03:53.470 --> 00:03:55.790
Let me move that over just a little bit so
you could see that.

80
00:03:55.790 --> 00:03:58.771
We would wanna choose the appropriate
operating system compatibility setting.

81
00:03:58.771 --> 00:04:00.186
We've talked about this before.

82
00:04:00.186 --> 00:04:04.411
It's highly unlikely, as I think I said
in the last episode when we did this,

83
00:04:04.411 --> 00:04:08.766
that we would have an application that
runs the gamut from Small Business Server

84
00:04:08.766 --> 00:04:12.020
2003 all the way up through
let's say 12 or 12 R2.

85
00:04:12.020 --> 00:04:15.288
So it would behoove us,
it would be a good idea, for

86
00:04:15.288 --> 00:04:18.480
us to choose or
check off which operating system or

87
00:04:18.480 --> 00:04:23.046
operating systems, may be more than one,
would be appropriate here.

88
00:04:23.046 --> 00:04:27.334
If we're not sure, than obviously it
will be up to us to decide how to

89
00:04:27.334 --> 00:04:32.230
either error on the side of caution or
decide just to select everything.

90
00:04:32.230 --> 00:04:35.650
And then just let the application
run based on whatever we decide to

91
00:04:35.650 --> 00:04:36.700
deploy this on.

92
00:04:36.700 --> 00:04:38.380
If we know for a fact, for instance,

93
00:04:38.380 --> 00:04:43.590
we're not gonna be deploying this on
anything other than 12 R2 instances and

94
00:04:43.590 --> 00:04:47.250
the app runs on 12 R2, let's just select
those to make sure we're covered.

95
00:04:47.250 --> 00:04:50.270
But let's not worry about all those other
ones because we're not gonna see them and

96
00:04:50.270 --> 00:04:50.910
they're not gonna be used.

97
00:04:50.910 --> 00:04:54.260
>> We're not gonna be breaking anything
if we just check all of them are we?

98
00:04:54.260 --> 00:04:57.740
>> No, it's just a matter
of the app may not actually

99
00:04:57.740 --> 00:05:00.550
run properly in some of the other
ones cuz the code wont be supported,

100
00:05:00.550 --> 00:05:02.990
but we wont hurt anything
by making that choice.

101
00:05:02.990 --> 00:05:06.275
So we could error on the side of caution,
but the reality is we know for

102
00:05:06.275 --> 00:05:09.745
a fact we're not supporting 2008 or
anything prior to that.

103
00:05:09.745 --> 00:05:10.875
No reason to select those,

104
00:05:10.875 --> 00:05:14.475
we're just making selections which
doesn't really matter in our world.

105
00:05:14.475 --> 00:05:17.995
So we'll just go ahead,
we'll just choose let's just say 64-bit,

106
00:05:17.995 --> 00:05:22.295
Windows Server 2008 data center
R2 standard or whatever.

107
00:05:22.295 --> 00:05:25.115
I'm not actually gonna configure
this profile end to end so

108
00:05:25.115 --> 00:05:27.015
it doesn't really matter what I choose.

109
00:05:27.015 --> 00:05:29.505
But in the real world it would
just be something to consider.

110
00:05:29.505 --> 00:05:30.509
So we'll just select that.

111
00:05:30.509 --> 00:05:33.062
Just didn't want that to get
lost in our conversation.

112
00:05:33.062 --> 00:05:36.230
Such a small little item up there
that the minute you click off and

113
00:05:36.230 --> 00:05:40.050
you add the app it goes away, and you may
forget it's there and not even realize it.

114
00:05:40.050 --> 00:05:43.070
Put a big neon, hey you didn't
fill me out yet, kinda flash.

115
00:05:43.070 --> 00:05:44.050
Or something on there.

116
00:05:44.050 --> 00:05:47.190
All right so we could stack up one or
more of these applications.

117
00:05:47.190 --> 00:05:49.470
We've done our web app
just as a choice here, and

118
00:05:49.470 --> 00:05:51.680
you could see we would go out we
would find our web app package.

119
00:05:51.680 --> 00:05:53.770
We've talked about this,
it would be in the library.

120
00:05:53.770 --> 00:05:56.160
Remember we'd import
from our web deploy tool,

121
00:05:56.160 --> 00:05:58.950
the exported zip file
we get as the output.

122
00:05:58.950 --> 00:06:01.092
Throw that in the library so
it's available as a resource.

123
00:06:01.092 --> 00:06:03.061
We would go out and browse and
bring that in here.

124
00:06:03.061 --> 00:06:05.173
And then that package
would actually show up.

125
00:06:05.173 --> 00:06:06.899
We're not as concerned about that,
cuz we've talked about that.

126
00:06:06.899 --> 00:06:09.040
You guys have a sense of
how to deal with that.

127
00:06:09.040 --> 00:06:10.990
What I am concerned about,
what I wanna show you here,

128
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:14.580
which we haven't done yet, is this
other little area here called scripts.

129
00:06:14.580 --> 00:06:16.290
We haven't really spent any time on it.

130
00:06:16.290 --> 00:06:18.110
We haven't talked about what goes on here.

131
00:06:18.110 --> 00:06:19.030
Move this over a little more.

132
00:06:20.370 --> 00:06:23.155
And it's all kinda empty and
lonely all sitting off by itself there.

133
00:06:23.155 --> 00:06:26.240
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's gonna be unhappy if we don't give

134
00:06:26.240 --> 00:06:29.110
it something that represents
its ability to contribute here.

135
00:06:29.110 --> 00:06:30.970
So we're gonna go to add.

136
00:06:30.970 --> 00:06:35.260
And instead of adding the app what we see
down here is we can add now since we've

137
00:06:35.260 --> 00:06:38.010
chosen the app, Script to Application.

138
00:06:38.010 --> 00:06:38.944
And so we can add a script.

139
00:06:38.944 --> 00:06:41.737
And you'll see it adds a script
in right below the app,

140
00:06:41.737 --> 00:06:46.070
and you'll see we can do pre install
script but we can actually change that.

141
00:06:46.070 --> 00:06:48.220
So this is an app, or
rather a script that would run,

142
00:06:48.220 --> 00:06:51.770
at least the way it's set right now,
to do some stuff pre install.

143
00:06:51.770 --> 00:06:53.510
So we would say okay,
what do we wanna run ahead of time?

144
00:06:53.510 --> 00:06:56.790
Maybe we want to format out a drive,
maybe we want to go ahead and map a drive,

145
00:06:56.790 --> 00:06:58.700
who knows what we would do with a script.

146
00:06:58.700 --> 00:07:01.200
But whatever we would do,
we could do that here.

147
00:07:01.200 --> 00:07:05.709
We'll specify our executable, our
parameters, the script resource package,

148
00:07:05.709 --> 00:07:06.634
Run As account.

149
00:07:06.634 --> 00:07:09.313
The really cool thing,
and also the time out,

150
00:07:09.313 --> 00:07:13.584
really cool thing though is we go in
under advanced if we choose to do that.

151
00:07:13.584 --> 00:07:14.688
Can we go full screen, just to see this?

152
00:07:14.688 --> 00:07:17.666
It may be easier for you to see this
while we're talking, than it is for

153
00:07:17.666 --> 00:07:20.818
you to watch me talk and point at
the screen, but you can't see anything.

154
00:07:20.818 --> 00:07:23.960
But you can see here that we
have our output persistence,

155
00:07:23.960 --> 00:07:27.181
our file path, our failure policy,
our restart policy.

156
00:07:27.181 --> 00:07:31.002
We have detailed settings about how to
deal with the script if things go right

157
00:07:31.002 --> 00:07:34.010
and where they happen,
but also if they go wrong.

158
00:07:34.010 --> 00:07:37.920
And if something goes wrong, what kind of
error codes or exit codes do we want here?

159
00:07:37.920 --> 00:07:40.300
What do we want our responsibility or

160
00:07:40.300 --> 00:07:43.430
our operational output to be,
if we have a problem?

161
00:07:43.430 --> 00:07:45.430
What actions do we wanna take?

162
00:07:45.430 --> 00:07:48.510
And you'll see,
we can match a string here for output.

163
00:07:48.510 --> 00:07:52.380
You'll see that Action when matched.

164
00:07:52.380 --> 00:07:56.440
If our exit code is any value
other than zero or not match.

165
00:07:56.440 --> 00:07:57.360
We can specify and

166
00:07:57.360 --> 00:08:01.228
be very prescriptive here,
very detailed about what's gonna happen.

167
00:08:01.228 --> 00:08:04.090
We also, after the computer
virtual machine is restarted,

168
00:08:04.090 --> 00:08:07.590
restart the script if there's a pause or
some sort of a problem.

169
00:08:07.590 --> 00:08:09.950
So we can re-engage the script,
try to run it again.

170
00:08:09.950 --> 00:08:13.250
There's been a challenge,
if something isn't working the right way.

171
00:08:13.250 --> 00:08:15.250
So, we can go ahead and

172
00:08:15.250 --> 00:08:19.990
program in all of the necessary
additional depth or details here,

173
00:08:19.990 --> 00:08:23.950
under advanced, for any of the scripts you
want to look at in one form or another.

174
00:08:23.950 --> 00:08:24.890
Now, we have pre-install,

175
00:08:24.890 --> 00:08:29.220
but that's not all, because we are going
to be able to do post-install.

176
00:08:29.220 --> 00:08:32.250
So we can change this
script by toggling here.

177
00:08:32.250 --> 00:08:34.290
We could do a post-install
script instead of pre.

178
00:08:34.290 --> 00:08:36.830
We could just have it
run after the install.

179
00:08:36.830 --> 00:08:40.230
Maybe at that point we wanna map
the drive instead of beforehand.

180
00:08:40.230 --> 00:08:43.130
Specify where we want
this action to take place

181
00:08:43.130 --> 00:08:44.865
cuz sometimes you feel like a preinstall.

182
00:08:44.865 --> 00:08:47.410
>> [LAUGH]
>> Sometimes you feel like a post install.

183
00:08:47.410 --> 00:08:49.600
Just a matter of what you're feeling for.

184
00:08:49.600 --> 00:08:51.960
You'll see we could do a save state,
restore state.

185
00:08:51.960 --> 00:08:53.700
We may be capturing
state from the machine.

186
00:08:53.700 --> 00:08:57.155
We could be doing a pre-service,
post-service, pre-uninstall,

187
00:08:57.155 --> 00:08:58.090
post-uninstall.

188
00:08:58.090 --> 00:09:02.910
Maybe this application will have to have
a script routine that runs that actually

189
00:09:02.910 --> 00:09:07.490
does an uninstall for
something before that's there,

190
00:09:07.490 --> 00:09:11.250
maybe a prior instance, and then goes
ahead and does an install of this new one.

191
00:09:11.250 --> 00:09:12.838
>> Pretty cool.
>> So there's a lot of stuff we could do

192
00:09:12.838 --> 00:09:14.380
in theory,
depending on what we want it to do.

193
00:09:14.380 --> 00:09:17.190
So don't want to underestimate
the value of scripts here,

194
00:09:17.190 --> 00:09:20.900
because this gives a lot of additional
capabilities with the application

195
00:09:20.900 --> 00:09:25.470
to add functionality outside that
application, around it in some way.

196
00:09:25.470 --> 00:09:28.210
That then allows us to
be able to hard code or

197
00:09:28.210 --> 00:09:31.955
at least program in what program,
what script, and

198
00:09:31.955 --> 00:09:37.250
what application are bound to what script
and what application and script together.

199
00:09:37.250 --> 00:09:40.500
Based on that and
the commands that we issue with the script

200
00:09:40.500 --> 00:09:41.900
will then tell us what
the outcome will be.

201
00:09:41.900 --> 00:09:43.020
We can do just about anything.

202
00:09:43.020 --> 00:09:45.960
So can we be doing PowerShell here,
we can do a batch file of some kind,

203
00:09:45.960 --> 00:09:47.450
some sort of command script, any or

204
00:09:47.450 --> 00:09:50.800
all of those things can be done,
it's just a matter of what we're gonna do.

205
00:09:50.800 --> 00:09:52.050
So we could go in now and do this.

206
00:09:52.050 --> 00:09:54.957
Now if we add, let's say,
stack up another application,

207
00:09:54.957 --> 00:09:58.056
let's do our sequel application,
doesn't matter.

208
00:09:58.056 --> 00:10:00.724
But you'll see here,
we have this, we actually,

209
00:10:00.724 --> 00:10:04.700
you'll see, have the ability to put
a SQL server script in as well.

210
00:10:04.700 --> 00:10:07.239
So you'll see we can add scripts for
the SQL server.

211
00:10:07.239 --> 00:10:10.730
You can click add here and
we can specify for the SQL server.

212
00:10:12.162 --> 00:10:15.570
Pre-install, post-install same
kind of format, if you will.

213
00:10:15.570 --> 00:10:18.430
But specify the authentication
type because we have to typically

214
00:10:18.430 --> 00:10:20.550
authenticate to run
against the SQL Server.

215
00:10:20.550 --> 00:10:22.830
To run the scripts,
we have to provide credentials for that.

216
00:10:22.830 --> 00:10:25.780
A little bit different than what we may
do otherwise, you did the credential but

217
00:10:25.780 --> 00:10:26.660
a run as account.

218
00:10:26.660 --> 00:10:28.310
This is a SQL account specifically.

219
00:10:28.310 --> 00:10:31.310
We also need permission to do
the sequel box in the instance, so

220
00:10:31.310 --> 00:10:32.970
it's a little bit of a different account.

221
00:10:32.970 --> 00:10:34.112
But you'll see there,

222
00:10:34.112 --> 00:10:36.495
we could also encrypt the connection-
>> Applying our password.

223
00:10:36.495 --> 00:10:40.709
>> No, this would actually encrypt
the connection back to SQL.

224
00:10:40.709 --> 00:10:43.149
This would actually encrypt
the connection back to the database, so

225
00:10:43.149 --> 00:10:45.177
that information is exchanged
over encrypted, right?

226
00:10:45.177 --> 00:10:45.901
>> Nice.

227
00:10:45.901 --> 00:10:46.717
>> So nobody could see it.

228
00:10:46.717 --> 00:10:48.404
Because, we may be running a script,

229
00:10:48.404 --> 00:10:51.908
not only that will provide credentials
to see Windows authentication or SQL.

230
00:10:51.908 --> 00:10:55.490
We want to protect that password exchange,
username exchange.

231
00:10:55.490 --> 00:10:58.100
But also, we wanna to protect
the data that may be going back and

232
00:10:58.100 --> 00:10:59.090
forth as a result of the script.

233
00:10:59.090 --> 00:11:01.110
So it is important for
us to take advantage of that, or

234
00:11:01.110 --> 00:11:02.920
at least know that we can
take advantage of that.

235
00:11:02.920 --> 00:11:08.941
So we have that here, and if we add in,
let's just add in one more.

236
00:11:08.941 --> 00:11:11.355
Our virtual application if
we decide we wanna do that,

237
00:11:11.355 --> 00:11:14.083
remember we made this general so
we could just stack them up and

238
00:11:14.083 --> 00:11:17.142
show them to you as opposed to hey
just web app or something like that.

239
00:11:17.142 --> 00:11:19.440
So we're gonna show you
the different types in other words.

240
00:11:19.440 --> 00:11:22.228
We could add a script here as well.

241
00:11:22.228 --> 00:11:24.282
Remember virtual applications
is an application.

242
00:11:24.282 --> 00:11:25.510
It's just a virtual application.

243
00:11:25.510 --> 00:11:27.960
It works the same way as a web
app does in the sense that

244
00:11:27.960 --> 00:11:31.380
we consider it an application,
it's just a type of application.

245
00:11:31.380 --> 00:11:35.243
And so the script options themselves
are going to be the same, as you can see,

246
00:11:35.243 --> 00:11:37.451
they work the same as
the web app scripts do.

247
00:11:37.451 --> 00:11:41.280
We just choose which ones we want to
use and program them in accordingly.

248
00:11:41.280 --> 00:11:44.670
So we're able to add in these scripts,
modify them as we go, or

249
00:11:44.670 --> 00:11:49.080
specify, hey this is what I want or
whatever the particular option will be.

250
00:11:49.080 --> 00:11:52.540
And then when we're done,
we can go ahead and click okay and

251
00:11:52.540 --> 00:11:55.510
then we'll finish everything out and
then we'll have our app profile.

252
00:11:55.510 --> 00:11:59.015
So creating the app profile is really
just a matter of bringing in one or

253
00:11:59.015 --> 00:12:00.435
more of these app types.

254
00:12:00.435 --> 00:12:04.088
Obviously, I've got the associated package
or deployment items that we can have in

255
00:12:04.088 --> 00:12:06.875
the library traditionally, so
we'll pull them in from there.

256
00:12:06.875 --> 00:12:10.155
But then we wanna make sure we use or
at least think about investigating

257
00:12:10.155 --> 00:12:13.615
the use of these scripts to further
refine our deployments if necessary.

258
00:12:13.615 --> 00:12:16.355
So that's what we wanted to make
sure we spent a little time on here.

259
00:12:16.355 --> 00:12:18.057
Now that you've seen how to do this, or

260
00:12:18.057 --> 00:12:20.947
hopefully have a better sense of
how to use application profiles,

261
00:12:20.947 --> 00:12:24.164
remember we can link those profiles
back to our service design template.

262
00:12:24.164 --> 00:12:27.092
We talked about that, in our service
template in the designer route.

263
00:12:27.092 --> 00:12:30.420
And we've shown you how to do that
with our tiered-based deployment in

264
00:12:30.420 --> 00:12:32.920
the template,
adding those applications in.

265
00:12:32.920 --> 00:12:35.350
You pull them in, and now we have
them all set up and associated.

266
00:12:35.350 --> 00:12:39.078
We can add our deployments in, or
our applications into our deployments, and

267
00:12:39.078 --> 00:12:41.338
throw the application as
well as the machines,

268
00:12:41.338 --> 00:12:44.250
as part of provisioning
out to the private cloud.

269
00:12:44.250 --> 00:12:45.900
>> Well, there you have it,
ladies and gentlemen.

270
00:12:45.900 --> 00:12:48.240
That is Application Profiles.

271
00:12:48.240 --> 00:12:50.510
For this particular episode,
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

272
00:12:50.510 --> 00:12:53.150
But remember,
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose.

273
00:12:53.150 --> 00:12:53.950
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

274
00:12:53.950 --> 00:12:57.229
>> See you next time here at ITProTV.

275
00:12:57.229 --> 00:13:03.198
[MUSIC]

276
00:13:03.198 --> 00:13:06.621
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee introduce System Center 2012 R2. Adam explains the core components and key features. Tune in now to get started.
episodes.title: Monitoring Cloud Based Applications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.104
Welcome to IT PRO TV,
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.104 --> 00:00:08.256
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.256 --> 00:00:09.407
>> You're watching IT PRO TV.

4
00:00:09.407 --> 00:00:15.420
>> Welcome to your Monitoring and
operating a private cloud series.

5
00:00:15.420 --> 00:00:17.630
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

6
00:00:17.630 --> 00:00:21.920
In this episode we'll be looking at how
to monitor cloud-based applications.

7
00:00:21.920 --> 00:00:25.070
And with us today we have Mr.
Adam Gordon in studios.

8
00:00:25.070 --> 00:00:27.080
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

9
00:00:27.080 --> 00:00:27.630
>> Thank you.

10
00:00:27.630 --> 00:00:28.550
Always a pleasure to be here.

11
00:00:28.550 --> 00:00:33.900
We're going to continue talking
about all things cloud, as they say.

12
00:00:33.900 --> 00:00:36.285
Cloudy with a chance of cloud,
I guess is how we would put that.

13
00:00:36.285 --> 00:00:38.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> So we're going to continue talking

14
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:38.600
about cloud.

15
00:00:38.600 --> 00:00:42.520
We've been talking up until now some of
the highlights from prior episodes incase

16
00:00:42.520 --> 00:00:43.970
you haven't seen them all.

17
00:00:43.970 --> 00:00:46.860
We have been talking about just
a general overview of what cloud is.

18
00:00:46.860 --> 00:00:49.360
We've gone through Cloud
from the perspective of

19
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:53.050
what are the service models,
how to deliver services,

20
00:00:53.050 --> 00:00:55.140
infrastructure platform
software as a service.

21
00:00:55.140 --> 00:00:58.770
We've talked extensively about
the virtual machine manager,

22
00:00:58.770 --> 00:01:03.230
the fabric in the Microsoft System
Center Sweep, how we configure that,

23
00:01:03.230 --> 00:01:06.720
how we use that,
how we build out library capabilities for

24
00:01:06.720 --> 00:01:11.565
storing and referencing information
packages, whatever we may have.

25
00:01:11.565 --> 00:01:15.030
Talked about how to set up networks and
the network components,

26
00:01:15.030 --> 00:01:18.710
IP pools, Mac pools, logical networks.

27
00:01:18.710 --> 00:01:23.840
Went in and took a look at the IP
templates, virtual IP configuration.

28
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:27.710
We took a look at and talked about
how to use all three elements of our

29
00:01:27.710 --> 00:01:32.530
fabric networking storage and the
configuration of the servers themselves.

30
00:01:32.530 --> 00:01:34.960
And we've also gone
through the VMM console.

31
00:01:34.960 --> 00:01:39.620
And really just spend time in there
understanding how we can leverage that

32
00:01:39.620 --> 00:01:44.050
management solution to be able to set
up and stage our packages that can then

33
00:01:44.050 --> 00:01:47.830
be used in either a service
design template of some kind and

34
00:01:47.830 --> 00:01:52.720
use those service templates to be able
to deploy not just virtual machines, but

35
00:01:52.720 --> 00:01:54.710
an entire solution around them.

36
00:01:54.710 --> 00:01:56.580
That includes the applications,

37
00:01:56.580 --> 00:01:59.850
that includes the virtual machine
configuration, the operating system,

38
00:01:59.850 --> 00:02:05.942
we call it the guest OS, the hardware
profiles, maybe a SQL solution,

39
00:02:05.942 --> 00:02:10.340
or a SQL application, and
a database that is all configured and

40
00:02:10.340 --> 00:02:14.430
ready to go, along with all the
Virtualized applications we may wanna use.

41
00:02:14.430 --> 00:02:16.720
We talked about Server App-V and
how all that's gonna happen.

42
00:02:16.720 --> 00:02:19.070
So we've done all of that up until now.

43
00:02:19.070 --> 00:02:20.500
We've done a lot of stuff, right?

44
00:02:20.500 --> 00:02:21.000
>> We really have.
[LAUGH]

45
00:02:21.000 --> 00:02:21.700
>> We've been really busy.

46
00:02:21.700 --> 00:02:25.120
So if you haven't seen all that stuff,
definitely encourage you to go back,

47
00:02:25.120 --> 00:02:28.630
take a look at all those episodes in
the earlier part of our discussions,

48
00:02:28.630 --> 00:02:31.430
cuz they're gonna set you up to have
a better sense of what we're gonna start

49
00:02:31.430 --> 00:02:32.690
focusing on here.

50
00:02:32.690 --> 00:02:38.700
And for next Several of our conversations,
next several episodes we're

51
00:02:38.700 --> 00:02:42.340
going to be going through and talking

00:20:42.130 --> 00:20:45.120

00:20:56.345 --> 00:20:59.625

437
00:20:59.625 --> 00:21:01.365

00:21:01.365 --> 00:21:04.035
They're all considered
primary servers if you will,

00:21:04.035 --> 00:21:07.385

00:21:07.385 --> 00:21:11.270

00:21:11.270 --> 00:21:14.180

00:21:14.180 --> 00:21:17.070
