507
00:24:25.950 --> 00:24:28.785
We have a web console as
well we can interact with.

508
00:24:28.785 --> 00:24:32.730
It's typically what you give to users
who need to do some basic monitoring and

509
00:24:32.730 --> 00:24:36.910
consume some basic information but don't
need the full admin rights to the product.

510
00:24:36.910 --> 00:24:41.950
So the web console is truncated or
essentially a scoped console that is gonna

511
00:24:41.950 --> 00:24:44.840
cut out the majority of
the administrative functions and

512
00:24:44.840 --> 00:24:47.930
really just let users focus on
consuming the monitoring piece.

513
00:24:47.930 --> 00:24:50.510
So looking at management pack and
monitoring and

514
00:24:50.510 --> 00:24:51.890
really not much more than that.

515
00:24:51.890 --> 00:24:55.560
We install those depending
on how we do our install

516
00:24:55.560 --> 00:24:57.860
typically through several iterations.

517
00:24:57.860 --> 00:25:00.600
We will install our
first management server.

518
00:25:00.600 --> 00:25:04.480
We can install our ops console as part of
that install if we want, kind of as we go,

519
00:25:04.480 --> 00:25:06.650
or install the console separately.

520
00:25:06.650 --> 00:25:10.140
We will then install typically one or
more management servers after the fact,

521
00:25:10.140 --> 00:25:12.090
second, third, fourth, whatever.

522
00:25:12.090 --> 00:25:16.620
Again, ops console could be installed
during that round or installed separately.

523
00:25:16.620 --> 00:25:19.550
Then we will typically install the Web
console after we have at least one or

524
00:25:19.550 --> 00:25:21.220
more management servers stood up.

525
00:25:21.220 --> 00:25:23.500
So we'll typically do
that as a separate step.

526
00:25:23.500 --> 00:25:25.450
So we would see that being done.

527
00:25:25.450 --> 00:25:30.520
We then would go through, most likely at
that point, we would configure reporting.

528
00:25:30.520 --> 00:25:33.840
So we would go ahead and
get our reporting infrastructure stood up.

529
00:25:33.840 --> 00:25:36.880
And then we have to think about
what's going on over here,

530
00:25:36.880 --> 00:25:39.470
in the lower left-hand
corner of our diagram.

531
00:25:39.470 --> 00:25:41.660
This thing outside the firewall I
haven't really talked about yet,

532
00:25:41.660 --> 00:25:43.340
which is our gateway server.

533
00:25:43.340 --> 00:25:46.390
Gateway servers are used in
very specific circumstances.

534
00:25:46.390 --> 00:25:49.170
There is a kind of a business case,
if you will,

535
00:25:49.170 --> 00:25:52.370
or use case, that we define around
the use of gateway servers.

536
00:25:52.370 --> 00:25:56.470
Specifically what we're doing here
is we are looking at two criteria.

537
00:25:56.470 --> 00:26:00.630
Number one intermittent and
a high-latency environment.

538
00:26:00.630 --> 00:26:03.100
So where we do not have
dedicated reliable bandwidth.

539
00:26:03.100 --> 00:26:06.730
Where we're not gonna be able to
connect reliably and consistently.

540
00:26:06.730 --> 00:26:10.280
And when we do, we've a lot of
latency involve in those connections,

541
00:26:10.280 --> 00:26:12.400
Gateway servers may be a good choice.

542
00:26:12.400 --> 00:26:14.620
You'll see, and
remember I specifically said hey,

543
00:26:14.620 --> 00:26:16.370
on the right-hand side
of the firewall here,

544
00:26:16.370 --> 00:26:20.420
we're assuming all of this stuff is gonna
be on the LAN, most likely internal.

545
00:26:20.420 --> 00:26:23.870
Which means that we're thinking
that this is gonna have

546
00:26:23.870 --> 00:26:25.990
dedicated network connections.

547
00:26:25.990 --> 00:26:29.970
Good reliable bandwidth, low-latency
networks, things like that that we would

548
00:26:29.970 --> 00:26:33.108
take for granted in many
cases in the infrastructure,

549
00:26:33.108 --> 00:26:37.180
in the enterprise that we need in order
to drive this kind of interaction.

550
00:26:37.180 --> 00:26:38.590
But we can't always take that for granted.

551
00:26:38.590 --> 00:26:40.640
We can't always assume
that that's the case.

552
00:26:40.640 --> 00:26:43.300
So outside the firewall we may have remote

553
00:26:43.300 --> 00:26:45.490
locations where where we don't
have good reliable bandwidth.

554
00:26:45.490 --> 00:26:46.550
Where there is a lot of latency.

555
00:26:46.550 --> 00:26:49.140
And so that's one of the two
criteria we're thinking about here.

556
00:26:49.140 --> 00:26:49.835
The other one is,

557
00:26:49.835 --> 00:26:54.310
non-domain joint, machines that
are not joined to the domain.

558
00:26:54.310 --> 00:26:58.160
They're outside of our LDAP directory,
they sit outside of our

559
00:26:58.160 --> 00:27:01.420
security perimeter, but
also outside of our directory services.

560
00:27:01.420 --> 00:27:03.620
So they're remote, and
they are not joined to the domain.

561
00:27:03.620 --> 00:27:08.970
In other words, no ability to do Kerberos
authentication for these machines.

562
00:27:08.970 --> 00:27:11.800
If that's the case,
it's the other major driving criteria,

563
00:27:11.800 --> 00:27:13.830
then the gateway server
is usually deployed.

564
00:27:13.830 --> 00:27:14.580
If we have five or

565
00:27:14.580 --> 00:27:18.790
more of these systems that we need to
monitor from outside to interact with,

566
00:27:18.790 --> 00:27:22.830
we need to then use a gateway server
to coordinate those activities.

567
00:27:22.830 --> 00:27:26.620
And so the gateway server is gonna
be deployed in some very specific

568
00:27:26.620 --> 00:27:27.620
circumstances.

569
00:27:27.620 --> 00:27:29.910
We do still deploy agents
there as you can see.

570
00:27:29.910 --> 00:27:31.960
So we would have Microsoft
monitoring agent.

571
00:27:31.960 --> 00:27:34.720
But what would happen is the gateway
server needs a little more

572
00:27:34.720 --> 00:27:36.870
configuration it's a little
bit more involved.

573
00:27:36.870 --> 00:27:39.960
There is documentation out on
the web on technet how to do this,

574
00:27:39.960 --> 00:27:41.070
not very difficult.

575
00:27:41.070 --> 00:27:45.650
But just a little specific, you gotta be
focused on the details as we would say.

576
00:27:45.650 --> 00:27:48.510
We need to generate some certificates
we gotta put those certificates

577
00:27:48.510 --> 00:27:52.370
into the gateway so that the gateway and
management servers can talk.

578
00:27:52.370 --> 00:27:56.100
So the gateway has to be authenticated and
those server certificates will be

579
00:27:56.100 --> 00:28:00.995
generated from inside from our
usually internal PKI or we'll use

580
00:28:00.995 --> 00:28:04.090
third-party certificates that are
purchased and used specifically for this.

581
00:28:04.090 --> 00:28:05.800
We'll implement that, step the gateway up,

582
00:28:05.800 --> 00:28:09.380
there's a little PowerShell we got to deal
with and do a couple of things there.

583
00:28:09.380 --> 00:28:13.300
Once we get that all bound and set up so
the gateway becomes our authenticated

584
00:28:13.300 --> 00:28:17.930
secure communication point, we then have
those agents reporting to the gateway.

585
00:28:17.930 --> 00:28:21.010
The agent machines never talk directly
through to the management servers,

586
00:28:21.010 --> 00:28:23.180
because they are unsecured,
from our perspective.

587
00:28:23.180 --> 00:28:24.640
They are not authenticated.

588
00:28:24.640 --> 00:28:26.525
Instead, all of the agents,

589
00:28:26.525 --> 00:28:30.190
all the managed infrastructure
that's outside that's reporting,

590
00:28:30.190 --> 00:28:33.640
will go through the gateway, and then
the gateway reports in on their behalf.

591
00:28:33.640 --> 00:28:37.210
So we are talking to a trusted end
point by using the gateway server.

592
00:28:37.210 --> 00:28:40.990
So just wanna make sure we're aware
of that, we're thinking about this,

593
00:28:40.990 --> 00:28:43.220
and we have a sense of the architecture.

594
00:28:43.220 --> 00:28:44.090
It's very important.

595
00:28:44.090 --> 00:28:47.370
We've got our management servers,
we've got our databases.

596
00:28:47.370 --> 00:28:48.430
We've got our agents.

597
00:28:48.430 --> 00:28:49.600
We talked about agents.

598
00:28:49.600 --> 00:28:52.090
Remember, we do have agents for
Unix and Linux systems, as well.

599
00:28:52.090 --> 00:28:53.900
By the way, we talked about managing and

600
00:28:53.900 --> 00:28:58.200
monitoring non-Microsoft stack
infrastructure, so we can do that.

601
00:28:58.200 --> 00:29:01.270
We have separate agents we would install
for those, but we could do that.

602
00:29:01.270 --> 00:29:02.340
We have reporting.

603
00:29:02.340 --> 00:29:05.550
We talked about management packs,
the basic unit of administration and

604
00:29:05.550 --> 00:29:06.360
monitoring.

605
00:29:06.360 --> 00:29:07.840
We didn't really put them into context.

606
00:29:07.840 --> 00:29:11.350
They would sit on the management servers,
but we will have more to say about them.

607
00:29:11.350 --> 00:29:16.660
Management packs are preconfigured
software items that we download.

608
00:29:16.660 --> 00:29:21.648
We integrate into SCOM by importing them
either locally from a disk, essentially

609
00:29:21.648 --> 00:29:25.820
already downloaded and ready to go, or
we download them from a web catalog.

610
00:29:25.820 --> 00:29:30.370
And we just integrate them directly to
the console, but they are preconfigured

611
00:29:30.370 --> 00:29:35.510
monitors, rules,
objects that are used for monitoring.

612
00:29:35.510 --> 00:29:37.600
We've got a list of them,
we'll talk to you about what they are,

613
00:29:37.600 --> 00:29:41.110
tasks, and all sorts of different things.

614
00:29:41.110 --> 00:29:42.650
All of that comes together.

615
00:29:42.650 --> 00:29:46.060
And we will then, discovery mechanisms,
as well, I forgot those.

616
00:29:46.060 --> 00:29:48.990
Those go in there, overrides, in theory,
go to management packs, as well.

617
00:29:48.990 --> 00:29:51.820
All of that will be done, and
we get a lot of them from Microsoft.

618
00:29:51.820 --> 00:29:54.300
But we also get a lot of them
from third-party vendors.

619
00:29:54.300 --> 00:29:58.290
And so we're able to download those,
install those, tune those,

620
00:29:58.290 --> 00:30:00.530
which is really the art and
science of using SCOM.

621
00:30:01.540 --> 00:30:05.280
And as a result of that,
target our monitoring efforts on specific

622
00:30:05.280 --> 00:30:07.564
kinds of servers or
specific infrastructure.

623
00:30:07.564 --> 00:30:08.200
We have management packs for Azure.

624
00:30:08.200 --> 00:30:11.120
We have management packs for Office 365.

625
00:30:11.120 --> 00:30:16.700
We have management packs for any of your
infrastructure on the Microsoft side,

626
00:30:16.700 --> 00:30:17.680
even if it's not Microsoft.

627
00:30:17.680 --> 00:30:19.600
We have management packs for VMWare.

628
00:30:19.600 --> 00:30:22.400
Management packs for IBM, for
HP, for everything, you name it.

629
00:30:22.400 --> 00:30:23.430
We can monitor and

630
00:30:23.430 --> 00:30:27.460
manage your Horizon View VDI installs
in VMWare with management packs.

631
00:30:27.460 --> 00:30:31.030
We can monitor your VMWare stack
infrastructure with management packs.

632
00:30:31.030 --> 00:30:34.170
So, we've got tremendous
capabilities in this platform.

633
00:30:34.170 --> 00:30:35.870
We just have to go out and download them.

634
00:30:35.870 --> 00:30:38.200
Majority of those
management packs are free.

635
00:30:38.200 --> 00:30:40.570
A few of them you may have to pay for
depending on what we're doing and

636
00:30:40.570 --> 00:30:42.610
who your getting them from,
but the bulk of them are free.

637
00:30:42.610 --> 00:30:44.430
You just download them and integrate them.

638
00:30:44.430 --> 00:30:46.990
Cisco, we got a lot of
Cisco-related management gear,

639
00:30:46.990 --> 00:30:48.160
stuff like that we can do.

640
00:30:48.160 --> 00:30:50.705
So there's a lot of
different functionally.

641
00:30:50.705 --> 00:30:53.915
We've also got, as I mentioned,
several different consoles.

642
00:30:53.915 --> 00:30:56.605
I believe I mentioned the fact,
let me just scroll back down,

643
00:30:56.605 --> 00:30:59.685
cuz I'm trying to keep up with my notes
while I talk to you to make sure we're

644
00:30:59.685 --> 00:31:01.705
covering all the different things
we want to throw out there.

645
00:31:01.705 --> 00:31:04.515
I mentioned the other
two management consoles.

646
00:31:04.515 --> 00:31:06.345
We go back to the diagram for
just one second.

647
00:31:06.345 --> 00:31:07.675
I just wanna show you something.

648
00:31:07.675 --> 00:31:10.585
So, I did mention that we have
two consoles sitting up here, but

649
00:31:10.585 --> 00:31:12.485
there were two more that
I threw out quickly.

650
00:31:12.485 --> 00:31:15.070
I said, hey, they're application-based for
monitoring, we'll

651
00:31:15.070 --> 00:31:18.500
talk more about them with what's called
APM, Application Performance Monitoring.

652
00:31:18.500 --> 00:31:20.980
They will get installed,
they are web-driven as well.

653
00:31:20.980 --> 00:31:24.340
Three of the four consoles rely
on web services to connect.

654
00:31:24.340 --> 00:31:28.370
And I've talked about this a couple other
episodes, but you do need Silverlight

655
00:31:28.370 --> 00:31:31.080
as a result of that to be able to
drive the console integration.

656
00:31:31.080 --> 00:31:33.290
So the first time you connect
you'll typically get a prompt for

657
00:31:33.290 --> 00:31:37.000
Silverlight, especially if you don't have
the most recent version available to you.

658
00:31:37.000 --> 00:31:38.440
And you will then be
able to download that,

659
00:31:38.440 --> 00:31:42.460
typically then close out the browser,
open it back up and then it will come up.

660
00:31:42.460 --> 00:31:44.380
But the application diagnostics and

661
00:31:44.380 --> 00:31:46.920
application adviser consoles
will also be there.

662
00:31:46.920 --> 00:31:49.800
I didn't put them on the diagram but
those the other two consoles you'll see.

663
00:31:49.800 --> 00:31:50.890
So we've talked about all of that.

664
00:31:50.890 --> 00:31:52.230
We've talked about the gateway server.

665
00:31:52.230 --> 00:31:53.520
We've talked about the role for this.

666
00:31:53.520 --> 00:31:57.670
We've talked about the fact that the
console, or rather the resource pool for

667
00:31:57.670 --> 00:31:59.980
service, makes this highly available.

668
00:31:59.980 --> 00:32:02.390
So we just wanna keep that in mind and
just be aware of that.

669
00:32:03.670 --> 00:32:06.990
And we also have laid out
the foundational thought process for

670
00:32:06.990 --> 00:32:09.980
you around just what SCOM is and
how it's gonna operate.

671
00:32:09.980 --> 00:32:13.390
If I'm not mistaken, Ms.
Cherokee, that means we are ready for

672
00:32:13.390 --> 00:32:14.940
another episode cuz we're out of time,
correct?

673
00:32:14.940 --> 00:32:16.570
>> We've covered a lot in this episode so
far.

674
00:32:16.570 --> 00:32:18.200
You've laid a great foundation here.

675
00:32:18.200 --> 00:32:19.420
Showed us the components.

676
00:32:19.420 --> 00:32:23.970
But I have a feeling we have several
other episodes to continue our,

677
00:32:23.970 --> 00:32:26.700
what did you say, your fire hose of?

678
00:32:26.700 --> 00:32:28.848
>> Drinking from the fire
hose of knowledge.

679
00:32:28.848 --> 00:32:31.000
>> There we go.

680
00:32:31.000 --> 00:32:35.590
So hopefully we don't burn you out
too prematurely, but stay tuned,

681
00:32:35.590 --> 00:32:38.580
we have a lot of more interesting
information so don't go anywhere.

682
00:32:38.580 --> 00:32:41.920
For this show, Adam's right,
we are out of time so we will go ahead and

683
00:32:41.920 --> 00:32:44.730
sign out, remember I am your
show host Cherokee Boose.

684
00:32:44.730 --> 00:32:45.490
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

685
00:32:45.490 --> 00:32:48.606
>> See ya next time here at ITPro.TV.

686
00:32:48.606 --> 00:32:54.488
[MUSIC]

687
00:32:54.488 --> 00:32:57.922
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee first discuss how utilizing the RMS emulator role enables backwards compatibility for connectors or previous Management Packs. They also revisit some vocabulary terms, explain built-in profile types and explain Management Packs.
episodes.title: Monitoring Cloud Based Applications Part 2

All right, so anyway we're gonna continue
talking about, as we said part two,

23
00:00:53.552 --> 00:00:57.556
cloud application monitoring,
monitoring of cloud based applications.

24
00:00:57.556 --> 00:01:00.716
What we really need to do now that
we've talked about all the basics,

25
00:01:00.716 --> 00:01:04.382
laid out the foundation for you, given

26
00:01:04.382 --> 00:01:06.424
If you haven't seen that episode,
by the way, want to go back and

27
00:01:06.424 --> 00:01:07.064
take a look at that.

28

We walked through all the pieces that
make up the System Center Option Manager

29
00:01:10.268 --> 00:01:13.124
installation, how we put that all

00:01:13.124 --> 00:01:14.073

00:01:14.073 --> 00:01:16.824
And we do wanna make sure you have that
knowledge going into the rest of these

00:01:17.487 --> 00:01:20.622
Cuz we'll start referring to those things,

we'll talk about management servers,

So you wanna make sure you know what

So definitely take a few minutes, go back

But what we're gonna do now is take

00:01:39.224 --> 00:01:42.763

Cuz we've talked about the fabric side,

Explain to you what all the different

I want to do the same thing with you here

46
00:01:52.702 --> 00:01:54.927
of what we're gonna be able to do and

00:13:50.760 --> 00:13:52.260

00:14:16.095 --> 00:14:20.120

00:14:21.530 --> 00:14:24.330

00:14:24.330 --> 00:14:26.480

00:14:26.480 --> 00:14:30.220

00:42:46.650 --> 00:42:49.300

00:43:25.600 --> 00:43:28.462

00:43:32.221 --> 00:43:33.055

there can be only one, as we say.

00:43:41.670 --> 00:43:43.522

00:43:50.907 --> 00:43:55.309

00:43:55.309 --> 00:43:56.670

Once we do that, if we do a manual install

That's usually the interaction

So when we do that, if we just take

It may be the connection

1023

I hate to be the Debbie Downer here.

1033

So just remember I'm your show host,
Cherokee Boose.

1034

>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee explain how to use Management Pack rules, object discovery, and various monitors to define the monitoring scope of your environment. Adam demonstrates how to monitor the health state of an object. He also shows how to use unit monitors to create alert thresholds. Tune in now to see what else can be achieved through monitors.

00:25:31.630 --> 00:25:34.790
We use three methods for discovery,
we use the registry so we can look at

573
00:25:34.790 --> 00:25:38.268
the registry of the system that's targeted
profile settings that are there so

574
00:25:38.268 --> 00:25:42.008

575
00:25:42.008 --> 00:25:43.297

00:25:43.297 --> 00:25:46.780
That's our prefered option, because
that is the least amount of CPU and

577
00:25:46.780 --> 00:25:49.945
RAM requirements on terms of overhead and
stress on the machine.

578
00:25:49.945 --> 00:25:53.545
So it's a very low impact way to
understand and profile what's there for

579
00:25:53.545 --> 00:25:55.495
the management pack to do its job.

580
00:25:55.495 --> 00:25:59.100
We can also use WMI, so
when is management instrumentation, WQL,

581
00:25:59.100 --> 00:26:02.276
the Windows management
instrumentation query language.

582
00:26:02.276 --> 00:26:06.765
We can use WQL to be able to send
queries to the box, run through them and

583
00:26:06.765 --> 00:26:08.925

584
00:26:08.925 --> 00:26:09.825

00:26:09.825 --> 00:26:11.190
Or we can use scripts.

00:26:11.190 --> 00:26:13.830
So these are the ways we
actually do discovery.

00:26:13.830 --> 00:26:17.690
We can find information that the
management packs will then be able to use

588
00:26:17.690 --> 00:26:19.120
in order to be able to monitor.

00:26:19.120 --> 00:26:22.410
We then need management pack rules,
as in these things sitting right here,

590
00:26:22.410 --> 00:26:24.720
are because these things are used
to structure the outcomes.

591
00:26:24.720 --> 00:26:28.940
The rules are the set of operational
instructions that tell management packs

592
00:26:28.940 --> 00:26:31.580

and in what order and

593
00:26:31.580 --> 00:26:34.870
with what specificity they should

00:26:34.870 --> 00:26:36.290
So we have three types of rules.

00:26:36.290 --> 00:26:38.462
We have alert generating rules,

00:26:38.462 --> 00:26:42.272
we have collection rules and
we have timed command rules.

00:26:42.272 --> 00:26:45.013

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee explain several Run As accounts to allow one the ability to run different rules, tasks, monitors, or discoveries under different credentials on different computers. They also cover Overrides and explain how useful they can be to customize Management Packs to tailor your environment.

00:30:01.820 --> 00:30:03.250
but we have not taken a look at yet.

679
00:30:03.250 --> 00:30:06.230
We're going to explain those, and show
you what those are, and how they work.

680
00:30:06.230 --> 00:30:09.310
And that'll tie in nicely for
episodes coming up later, where we do APM,

681
00:30:09.310 --> 00:30:11.448
the application for
performance monitoring, and

682
00:30:11.448 --> 00:30:14.163
talk about how to monitor
applications using those templates.

683
00:30:14.163 --> 00:30:15.370
We're gonna take a look at some-
>> Also the labs,

684
00:30:15.370 --> 00:30:18.480
they can use all that information that
you've covered to help them through, and

685
00:30:18.480 --> 00:30:19.490
walk through all those other labs.

686
00:30:19.490 --> 00:30:20.210
We've got a lot.
>> They can,

687
00:30:20.210 --> 00:30:22.030
cuz we do have full
hands-on demonstration.

688
00:30:22.030 --> 00:30:24.640
Separate episodes, broken out,
about how to do and

689
00:30:24.640 --> 00:30:27.650
configure many of the things that
we're taking a look at here quickly,

690
00:30:27.650 --> 00:30:30.080
with a little more depth and
specificity associated with them.

691
00:30:30.080 --> 00:30:31.850
So you can take a look at those also.

692
00:30:31.850 --> 00:30:32.690
>> Well, that's it.

693
00:30:32.690 --> 00:30:33.810
You heard it yourself.

694
00:30:33.810 --> 00:30:36.370
We have more information to cover,
so stay tuned.

695
00:30:36.370 --> 00:30:38.070
But for this show, we are out of time.

696
00:30:38.070 --> 00:30:39.190
So we'll go ahead and sign off.

697
00:30:39.190 --> 00:30:40.550
Remember, I'm Cherokee Boose.

698
00:30:40.550 --> 00:30:41.183
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

699
00:30:41.183 --> 00:30:44.574
See you next time here at ITProTV.

700
00:30:44.574 --> 00:30:50.393
[MUSIC]

701
00:30:50.393 --> 00:30:53.731
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee show how to configure Fabric Monitoring. Adam first covers the prerequisites needed then navigates through the VMM  Fabric dashboard. He also covers configuring the System Center Management Pack for Windows Azure. Next they discuss the integration between Operations Manager and System Center Adviser. Lastly, learn about Global Service Monitor and Real-Time Visio Dashboards.
episodes.title: Monitoring Cloud Based Applications Part 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

2
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:02.655

3
00:00:02.655 --> 00:00:06.613
>> [CROSSTALK]

4

[MUSIC]

5

6

Operating a Private Cloud series.

7

8

9

10

Adam Gordon.

12

Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

13

14
00:00:29.764 --> 00:00:31.040
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm just thinking in my mind,

that's blooper reel material right there.

16
00:00:33.290 --> 00:00:34.400
>> It is blooper reel material.

>> All right
>> [LAUGH]

18

We're gonna move in to part
five of our conversation,

27

We have to have some operational

One of the main things is, we need some

But there's a list of them,
all of them are in,

In addition, we have to have

We should also,

53
00:02:17.235 --> 00:02:18.370
See, I'm thinking.

54

That's important.

55
00:02:19.270 --> 00:02:21.620
I'm planning to be successful, as we say.

So that way, we can actually monitor the

and all the things that we would need.

59
00:02:33.705 --> 00:02:35.600
So that's going to be important for us.

60

We'll then go ahead, and
we'll use the wizard in the VMM console

00:02:39.925 --> 00:02:42.775

62
00:02:42.775 --> 00:02:45.360

63
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:46.400
Let's go in, we'll take a look.

64
00:02:46.400 --> 00:02:48.160
We're on our SCVMM server.

65
00:02:48.160 --> 00:02:50.160
You may remember this from

66
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:52.500
We spent some fun times,

00:02:52.500 --> 00:02:53.240
Fun times in here.

68
00:02:53.240 --> 00:02:54.275

>> Good times, good times.

69
00:02:54.275 --> 00:02:55.990
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's what it was, good times.

70
00:02:55.990 --> 00:02:58.940
We spent some good times in here,

And I'm just gonna show

We do have our Ops console

And if we go in,

00:03:15.510 --> 00:03:16.940
Our Microsoft Monitoring Agent.

And you saw me push this in a prior

00:03:19.950 --> 00:03:21.170

But you would have to

But we've kinda cheated a little bit, and

91

And this is the Ad Operations Manager

plabsis01, practicelabs.com,

00:04:38.990 --> 00:04:42.650
You know about those now, and how to set

00:04:42.650 --> 00:04:44.820

112

And we talked about this with VMM earlier,

114
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:57.390
Pro is something we've talked about or

119
00:05:10.050 --> 00:05:16.370
Pro is gonna be performance, and,

It is very similar to the DRS

00:05:20.360 --> 00:05:22.260

122
00:05:22.260 --> 00:05:27.150
Pro-active monitoring of our host

123
00:05:27.150 --> 00:05:31.230

to take full advantage of that.

124
00:05:31.230 --> 00:05:32.900
Pro operates a very similar way.

125
00:05:32.900 --> 00:05:36.670
Dynamic optimization is part
of that technology as well.

126
00:05:36.670 --> 00:05:38.240
So that's what that does.

127
00:05:38.240 --> 00:05:41.356
And then enabling maintenance

00:05:41.356 --> 00:05:43.960

129
00:05:43.960 --> 00:05:48.830
Meaning, if I leave these both selected, I

131
00:05:52.430 --> 00:05:54.040

132
00:05:54.040 --> 00:05:58.610
And as a result, what we will do is

00:05:58.610 --> 00:06:01.150
And we showed you this in one

134
00:06:01.150 --> 00:06:02.930

135
00:06:02.930 --> 00:06:05.960
Where we can use maintenance mode

136
00:06:05.960 --> 00:06:09.770

137
00:06:09.770 --> 00:06:12.730

machines that may be running,

138
00:06:12.730 --> 00:06:15.900

depending on what it's being used for.

139
00:06:15.900 --> 00:06:17.555
And so, we can integrate that here.

140
00:06:17.555 --> 00:06:18.835
And so
we're gonna leave those checked off.

141
00:06:18.835 --> 00:06:21.765
We're gonna click Next.

142

We're gonna put in our user credential

143
00:06:26.565 --> 00:06:30.285

OpsManager should use

144

145
00:06:32.215 --> 00:06:35.535

00:06:35.535 --> 00:06:40.095
So, we gotta have an account that will

147
00:06:40.095 --> 00:06:44.120

148
00:06:44.120 --> 00:06:47.280
We use our administrator account for this.

149
00:06:47.280 --> 00:06:48.430
We'll do our password.

150
00:06:48.430 --> 00:06:51.160
Let me just make sure I typed
that correctly, cuz I got

00:06:51.160 --> 00:06:55.330

not gonna be registered properly there.

152
00:06:55.330 --> 00:06:57.880
We'll give that just a minute to go off,
check, do its thing.

153
00:06:59.430 --> 00:07:02.270
Once that is done,
we'll then get our summary.

154
00:07:02.270 --> 00:07:04.890
And we'll be able to essentially go and
get this started.

155
00:07:04.890 --> 00:07:06.490
You'll see there, we got our summary.

156
00:07:06.490 --> 00:07:09.160
I was showing you the PowerShell
scripts that take place for

00:07:10.750 --> 00:07:12.930
Remember, you can always go under

159
00:07:12.930 --> 00:07:15.110
We'll go ahead and we'll click Finish.

160
00:07:15.110 --> 00:07:17.810
This is now going to

161
00:07:17.810 --> 00:07:19.160
And you could see that it has started.

162
00:07:19.160 --> 00:07:20.860
Now, this is gonna take a while.

00:07:20.860 --> 00:07:24.870
I've done this exact demo in other
episodes for the 10964 class.

164
00:07:24.870 --> 00:07:26.980
You hear us refer to that sometimes.

165
00:07:26.980 --> 00:07:30.280
And that set of shows,
that episode in particular does this.

166
00:07:30.280 --> 00:07:32.950
We're not going to wait for this,
it's going to take about 15 minutes.

167
00:07:32.950 --> 00:07:33.790
So I just kick this off.

168
00:07:33.790 --> 00:07:35.500
We're going to let this
cook in the background.

169
00:07:35.500 --> 00:07:36.790
I'm gonna go off, do some other stuff.

170
00:07:36.790 --> 00:07:38.690
We'll poke our heads back in
towards the end of the episode, and

171
00:07:38.690 --> 00:07:39.460
just see that it's done.

172
00:07:39.460 --> 00:07:40.730
But we're not going to wait on this.

173
00:07:40.730 --> 00:07:41.920
Because it's going to hang.

174
00:07:41.920 --> 00:07:45.995
And just so you know, in the real world,
it's gonna hang at 10% for, I don't know,

175
00:07:45.995 --> 00:07:47.685
probably a good five to ten minutes.

176
00:07:47.685 --> 00:07:49.254
And then all of the sudden,
it's gonna jump to about 40 or 50.

177
00:07:49.254 --> 00:07:51.004
Then it's gonna hang for a bit.

178
00:07:51.004 --> 00:07:51.675
It's gonna jump again.

179
00:07:51.675 --> 00:07:54.322
So, it is one of those things where
it seems like it's doing nothing for

180
00:07:54.322 --> 00:07:56.583
a while Then all of a sudden it's
done a whole bunch of stuff.

181
00:07:56.583 --> 00:07:59.332
Then it does some more thinking and
does some more stuff.

182
00:07:59.332 --> 00:08:00.550
So just be aware of that.

183
00:08:00.550 --> 00:08:03.440
We'll leave that up, we'll kinda let
that do its thing, and then as I said,

184
00:08:03.440 --> 00:08:05.810
we'll poke our nose back in and
take a look when we're done.

185
00:08:05.810 --> 00:08:07.440
But once we have done that, and

186
00:08:07.440 --> 00:08:10.910
we've actually set up
the integration with SCOM and VMM.

187
00:08:10.910 --> 00:08:13.070
All this is the backend work and

188
00:08:13.070 --> 00:08:16.250

able to do the fabric monitoring.

189
00:08:16.250 --> 00:08:17.860
We haven't started fabric monitoring.

190
00:08:17.860 --> 00:08:20.150
All we've done is lay down
the foundational elements and

191
00:08:20.150 --> 00:08:22.730

to enable us to do that.

192
00:08:22.730 --> 00:08:24.750
At that point, once we've installed and

193
00:08:24.750 --> 00:08:27.540

194
00:08:27.540 --> 00:08:31.180
Imported all the prereq management
packs on the SCOM side to allow

195
00:08:31.180 --> 00:08:32.750

196
00:08:32.750 --> 00:08:36.020
We've installed the ops
console on the VMM system.

197

Put a Microsoft monitoring

198
00:08:38.886 --> 00:08:43.780

199
00:08:43.780 --> 00:08:46.430

200
00:08:46.430 --> 00:08:48.040
That's a separate management pack.

201
00:08:48.040 --> 00:08:50.480
We would download it, install or import.

202
00:08:50.480 --> 00:08:53.010
And then once we've done that,
we'll get our cloud health view.

203
00:08:53.010 --> 00:08:54.230
These are the views we get.

204
00:08:54.230 --> 00:08:57.690
We get our fabric health dashboard and

us out just beyond the SCOM consoles

that it is really looking for

So, maybe a lot easier for you to give

885

So, it may just be another option for

886

>> All right, Adam, you've given us a ton

But that's okay,

And just get ready to go ahead and

But for this show we're out of time,

>> I'm Adam Gordon, that's who I am.

00:20:11.180 --> 00:20:13.800
But eventually, what we will get is,

431
00:20:13.800 --> 00:20:16.340
we will get a network
device that comes in here.

432
00:20:16.340 --> 00:20:18.810
And we'll then ask for your devices,
if there's more than one,

433
00:20:18.810 --> 00:20:22.310
that will come in and actually be
available after discovery runs.

434
00:20:22.310 --> 00:20:24.240
And remember,
you gotta be patient with this.

435
00:20:24.240 --> 00:20:26.710
It does take a little while for
that to run.

436
00:20:26.710 --> 00:20:28.320
You can see status is idle.

437
00:20:28.320 --> 00:20:32.200
Let me run this again, because I had this
happen the last time where I ran this and

438
00:20:32.200 --> 00:20:35.400
it didn't take the first time
when I was just setting this up.

439
00:20:35.400 --> 00:20:38.780
And then it took and
then it finally started running, okay.

440
00:20:38.780 --> 00:20:44.770
So because status there should actually
change, and we should actually

441
00:20:44.770 --> 00:20:49.780
get that to go to start it if we catch
it quickly enough, before it runs.

442
00:20:49.780 --> 00:20:52.320
So it may take a couple of minutes for
it to show up.

443
00:20:52.320 --> 00:20:54.181
We're not gonna wait for
it to actually get a device.

444
00:20:54.181 --> 00:20:55.540
But you get the general idea.

445
00:20:55.540 --> 00:20:58.946
Eventually, we would have
a device show up in there.

446
00:20:58.946 --> 00:21:00.510
And if anyone would discover,

447
00:21:00.510 --> 00:21:05.330
we would then be able to get the plabsy01
machine, the machine that we specified.

448
00:21:05.330 --> 00:21:07.190
It eventually would show up and
be available to us.

449
00:21:07.190 --> 00:21:12.050
So remember, we could target this
to do routers, to do switches.

450
00:21:12.050 --> 00:21:16.570
Do anything with SNMP and that's what we
would actually see ultimately as we do run

451
00:21:16.570 --> 00:21:18.620
through this and
then from there of course,

452
00:21:18.620 --> 00:21:22.800
we're able to then go in and we're
actually able to manage those devices.

453
00:21:22.800 --> 00:21:26.280
Report on them as we saw and do all
the things we need to associate them.

454
00:21:26.280 --> 00:21:27.360
>> Very cool stuff Adam.

455
00:21:27.360 --> 00:21:30.800
We appreciate you walking us through
this 'cuz it can be a little argues for

456
00:21:30.800 --> 00:21:34.300
the uninitiated such as myself,
I've never use SCRUM in this way.

457
00:21:34.300 --> 00:21:36.950
So very cool, to see those steps.

458
00:21:36.950 --> 00:21:41.190
And now I get a little more context on how
it's suppose to look what I should expect,

459
00:21:41.190 --> 00:21:45.530
and hopefully at the end of the day
I get all my stuff squared away.

460
00:21:45.530 --> 00:21:46.320
Very cool stuff.

461
00:21:46.320 --> 00:21:48.950
Adam we appreciate you joining us and
doing it for us.

462
00:21:48.950 --> 00:21:51.070
We do appreciate you good folks for
watching, but

463
00:21:51.070 --> 00:21:53.060
that is our demonstration for today.

464
00:21:53.060 --> 00:21:55.390
Hopefully, you've enjoyed it and
learned a little bit of something, but

465
00:21:55.390 --> 00:21:57.060
we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

466
00:21:57.060 --> 00:21:59.490
For ITPProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

467
00:21:59.490 --> 00:22:00.400
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

468
00:22:00.400 --> 00:22:01.585
>> And we'll see you next time.

469
00:22:01.585 --> 00:22:09.159
[MUSIC]

470
00:22:09.159 --> 00:22:12.037
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Daniel discuss the Import Ops Manager
episodes.title: Import Ops Manager Management Pack
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.082
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:06.082 --> 00:00:08.231
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.231 --> 00:00:11.797
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.797 --> 00:00:13.960
>> All right, greetings everyone and

5
00:00:13.960 --> 00:00:16.996
welcome to another exciting
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.996 --> 00:00:18.591
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

7
00:00:18.591 --> 00:00:23.010
in today's episode we are back with more
datacenter monitoring with Microsoft SCOM.

8
00:00:23.010 --> 00:00:24.550
And of course joining us in the studio,

9
00:00:24.550 --> 00:00:27.320
the man, the myth, the legend,
you know him as Adam Gordon.

10
00:00:27.320 --> 00:00:29.570
Adam, welcome back sir,
and how's it going today?

11
00:00:29.570 --> 00:00:32.162
>> Very, very good, hopefully better
after we're done with this demonstration.

12
00:00:32.162 --> 00:00:35.909
Gonna show you something that we've talked
about and actually done almost verbatim in

13
00:00:35.909 --> 00:00:38.279
a prior episode, but
we didn't really finish it out.

14
00:00:38.279 --> 00:00:42.047
Wanted to take the opportunity as we're
doing things here to show you end to end

15
00:00:42.047 --> 00:00:43.656
how to import a management pack.

16
00:00:43.656 --> 00:00:47.652
We're gonna download one from a website,
open up the MSI, grab the files,

17
00:00:47.652 --> 00:00:51.440
import the management pack,
just quickly walk you through that.

18
00:00:51.440 --> 00:00:54.118
So let's take a look if we could,
we're gonna go out here.

19
00:00:54.118 --> 00:00:56.812
We've got our website set
up with our tools and

20
00:00:56.812 --> 00:01:00.208
resources here,
thank you to the folks at practice labs.

21
00:01:00.208 --> 00:01:01.489
We always use the best and

22
00:01:01.489 --> 00:01:04.418
latest technology to bring
you these demonstrations and

23
00:01:04.418 --> 00:01:08.760
their stuff is, as you hopefully know cuz
you're using it, really, really good.

24
00:01:08.760 --> 00:01:11.660
We've got our System Center
Management Pack sitting here, so

25
00:01:11.660 --> 00:01:14.780
we're gonna download that MSI,
we're gonna grab it.

26
00:01:14.780 --> 00:01:17.850
You saw me do this in one of
the prior demonstrations I

27
00:01:17.850 --> 00:01:20.453
integrated into the episode
we were talking about it.

28
00:01:20.453 --> 00:01:22.935
I went out to the actual
Microsoft website,

29
00:01:22.935 --> 00:01:27.555
we grabbed one of the latest
management packs for Server 16 for

30
00:01:27.555 --> 00:01:31.790
Hyper-V, exploded it out on the desktop,
took a look at the different files.

31
00:01:31.790 --> 00:01:34.356
I'm just gonna wait until it
stops flashing yellow and

32
00:01:34.356 --> 00:01:36.431
goes bright nuclear red, before I import.

33
00:01:36.431 --> 00:01:38.278
>> You will pay attention to me!

34
00:01:38.278 --> 00:01:39.051
>> Exactly, [LAUGH].

35
00:01:39.051 --> 00:01:43.712
And then we talked about the .mp file, the
.mpb files to explain what they were, and

36
00:01:43.712 --> 00:01:47.790
we did the whole demonstration but
we didn't actually do the import.

37
00:01:47.790 --> 00:01:50.410
So I'm gonna actually show it to you and
show you how to pick up that thread and

38
00:01:50.410 --> 00:01:51.110
go from here.

39
00:01:51.110 --> 00:01:54.009
So I'm gonna go ahead and I'm gonna
run this, instead of saving it and

40
00:01:54.009 --> 00:01:55.890
then running it we'll
just run it directly.

41
00:01:55.890 --> 00:01:57.442
And we've got our EULA,

42
00:01:57.442 --> 00:02:01.010
our end user license agreement here,
scroll that over so you could see it.

43
00:02:01.010 --> 00:02:03.930
We'll go ahead and
we'll click I Accept, we'll hit Next.

44
00:02:03.930 --> 00:02:06.400
We'll accept our default
installation directory,

45
00:02:06.400 --> 00:02:10.960
we've got that sitting right here just so
you guys can see what that is.

46
00:02:10.960 --> 00:02:16.150
Copy that real quick just so
that we have a record of it,

47
00:02:16.150 --> 00:02:18.596
we'll then go ahead and just make
sure it's available for everybody.

48
00:02:18.596 --> 00:02:24.130
Click Next, then I'll click Install,
that'll be real quick.

49
00:02:24.130 --> 00:02:29.190
Put that in there and you could see it
opens up, just minimize that website,

50
00:02:29.190 --> 00:02:33.940
opens up and you can see that we have our

51
00:02:33.940 --> 00:02:36.960
various management packs,
our MP files are there.

52
00:02:36.960 --> 00:02:39.600
This was
the Windows Server Management Pack,

53
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:42.840
so we have the Windows Server Library
sitting right there, we can see that.

54
00:02:42.840 --> 00:02:44.590
Now what we're gonna do
is we're gonna go ahead,

55
00:02:44.590 --> 00:02:47.510
we're gonna grab that from the console and
we're gonna import that.

56
00:02:47.510 --> 00:02:48.655
So we're gonna minimize here,

57
00:02:48.655 --> 00:02:53.170
gonna come over here to our administration
workspace > Management packs.

58
00:02:53.170 --> 00:02:58.510
We're gonna right click, we're gonna do
import management pack right from there.

59
00:02:58.510 --> 00:03:03.560
Then we're gonna go ahead,
we're gonna click Add > Add from disk, and

60
00:03:03.560 --> 00:03:06.625
we're gonna get our online
catalogue connection.

61
00:03:06.625 --> 00:03:10.390
Hey, they're not all available there,
do you wanna go out and look for

62
00:03:10.390 --> 00:03:11.320
dependencies?

63
00:03:11.320 --> 00:03:13.730
Not right now, but
we would in the real world.

64
00:03:15.130 --> 00:03:18.100
Go ahead and do our import,
we're just gonna go ahead and

65
00:03:18.100 --> 00:03:21.160
we're gonna paste in our path there so
we can find it.

66
00:03:21.160 --> 00:03:23.890
So we have our ability to go out and

67
00:03:23.890 --> 00:03:27.470
grab the management pack that we need,
we can see it right there.

68
00:03:27.470 --> 00:03:31.020
We're gonna go ahead and grab the
Microsoft Server Library Management Pack,

69
00:03:31.020 --> 00:03:32.110
we've got it sitting right there.

70
00:03:32.110 --> 00:03:34.465
Let's go ahead and
double-click on that, bring that in,

71
00:03:34.465 --> 00:03:37.320
just move this over a little bit so
you can see that.

72
00:03:37.320 --> 00:03:38.350
And you'll see it loads up,

73
00:03:38.350 --> 00:03:41.870
we can stack up those management packs,
as many of them as we need.

74
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:44.740
We're just gonna right click and
hide the task bar here real quick so

75
00:03:44.740 --> 00:03:47.800
we actually can see
the bottom button there.

76
00:03:47.800 --> 00:03:51.080
Because as you know, sometimes those
wizards come up and it's hard to see that

77
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:55.440
screen just because of the screen size,
or see that bottom tier of the screen.

78
00:03:55.440 --> 00:03:59.980
So we're gonna click Install here and
we're then gonna watch this.

79
00:03:59.980 --> 00:04:01.340
Import doesn't take very long,

80
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:04.260
it's a small management pack,
takes just a moment to bring it in.

81
00:04:04.260 --> 00:04:07.855
You'll see as soon as that green light,
or the green bar finishes,

82
00:04:07.855 --> 00:04:10.330
you can see it's actually already
imported, that we are done.

83
00:04:11.870 --> 00:04:14.660
We're now gonna go ahead,
we're gonna click Close.

84
00:04:14.660 --> 00:04:17.145
And we will give that a moment,
it has to update.

85
00:04:17.145 --> 00:04:20.810
But if we come down here, we'll just
wait for the console to update so

86
00:04:20.810 --> 00:04:24.370
we can actually scroll, but when we go
down at the bottom we will then be able to

87
00:04:24.370 --> 00:04:28.270
see that we can find the Windows
Client Operating System Library and

88
00:04:28.270 --> 00:04:29.410
we'll know that it's been imported.

89
00:04:29.410 --> 00:04:32.240
So let's just scroll
down here alphabetically,

90
00:04:32.240 --> 00:04:36.500
go down towards the bottom,
all the way down here.

91
00:04:36.500 --> 00:04:38.290
Just one second, oops, there we go.

92
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:43.510
And Windows, Windows, Windows,
Windows, Windows, Windows,

93
00:04:43.510 --> 00:04:46.150
Windows Client Operating System Library
right there.

94
00:04:46.150 --> 00:04:51.070
And we can see that that one was the one
that we just went ahead and we imported,

95
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:53.490
and so now we have that
management pack available.

96
00:04:53.490 --> 00:04:58.360
And of course now all
the associated monitors, reports,

97
00:04:58.360 --> 00:05:01.390
views, anything associated with
that would have been loaded in.

98
00:05:01.390 --> 00:05:05.481
And so if we have any additional
information we could go in, for instance

99
00:05:05.481 --> 00:05:09.973
go to our monitoring area, and if we did
load anything up as an additional item,

100
00:05:09.973 --> 00:05:12.855
as a result of that we'd be
able to come down here and

101
00:05:12.855 --> 00:05:15.634
we will be able to see
Microsoft Windows Client.

102
00:05:15.634 --> 00:05:17.510
And we will be then able to go in and

103
00:05:17.510 --> 00:05:22.010
see all the different items that are
available as part of the management pack.

104
00:05:22.010 --> 00:05:24.120
We have a logical disk state view,

105
00:05:24.120 --> 00:05:27.690
we have a network adapter state view,
those obviously may be important.

106
00:05:27.690 --> 00:05:30.410
Operating system performance,
we'd have to target this out,

107
00:05:30.410 --> 00:05:34.710
obviously it would be monitoring
task status, Windows Client status.

108
00:05:34.710 --> 00:05:39.320
We've got some health monitoring going
on here with Windows Client OS Health.

109
00:05:39.320 --> 00:05:42.882
You can see things here like disk
health on our dashboard, right,

110
00:05:42.882 --> 00:05:45.340
we've also got operating system events.

111
00:05:45.340 --> 00:05:48.640
This is a pretty detailed
management pack that we bring in.

112
00:05:48.640 --> 00:05:50.310
You'll see here we've
got some stuff there,

113
00:05:50.310 --> 00:05:54.760
and we've got performance here as well,
Client OS performance.

114
00:05:54.760 --> 00:05:57.159
Drill down,
we've got additional dashboards here and

115
00:05:57.159 --> 00:05:58.389
monitoring capabilities.

116
00:05:58.389 --> 00:06:01.635
So we brought all that in as
part of our implementation and

117
00:06:01.635 --> 00:06:06.042
integration of the management pack through
the import that we saw end to end.

118
00:06:06.042 --> 00:06:09.962
You saw us go out and get it, you saw me
actually finish up by using the add from

119
00:06:09.962 --> 00:06:12.487
disk option,
then import the management pack.

120
00:06:12.487 --> 00:06:16.127
And of course you see in the console we're
able to leverage the management pack to do

121
00:06:16.127 --> 00:06:17.064
a variety of things.

122
00:06:17.064 --> 00:06:20.835
>> Well Adam, thanks so much, it's a short
little demo but a very important one.

123
00:06:20.835 --> 00:06:24.995
Wanted make sure that you guys had the
soup to nuts kind of thing with importing

124
00:06:24.995 --> 00:06:29.283
a management pack into the Operations
Manager, and therefore being able to use

125
00:06:29.283 --> 00:06:33.060
all of the features thereof that we
might download from the catalog.

126
00:06:33.060 --> 00:06:35.920
We do thank you for that, Adam,
we thank you good folks for watching.

127
00:06:35.920 --> 00:06:37.870
But we're gonna go ahead and sign off.

128
00:06:37.870 --> 00:06:41.040
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

129
00:06:41.040 --> 00:06:41.860
>> I'm Adam Gordon.

130
00:06:41.860 --> 00:06:44.084
>> And we'll see you next time.

131
00:06:44.084 --> 00:06:50.118
[MUSIC]

132
00:06:50.118 --> 00:06:53.726
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Adam and Daniel discuss linking VMM SCOM and PRO
episodes.title: Linking VMM SCOM and PRO
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.025 --> 00:00:03.411
[CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:03.411 --> 00:00:12.067
You are watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.067 --> 00:00:13.852
>> All right, greetings everyone and

4
00:00:13.852 --> 00:00:16.181
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

5
00:00:16.181 --> 00:00:20.983
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
episode we're talking all about data

6
00:00:20.983 --> 00:00:25.855
center monitoring with Microsoft SCOM, and
the six gun slinger standing next to me

7
00:00:25.855 --> 00:00:29.500
is our good friend joining us again today,
Mr. Adam Gordon.

8
00:00:29.500 --> 00:00:30.300
Adam, welcome back sir.

9
00:00:30.300 --> 00:00:31.520
How's it going, man?

10
00:00:31.520 --> 00:00:32.969
>> I'm shot.

11
00:00:32.969 --> 00:00:33.929
Help me.

12
00:00:33.929 --> 00:00:35.300
>> [LAUGH]
>> It's going well, it's going well.

13
00:00:35.300 --> 00:00:37.750
Hey, you got to have a little
fun when you're doing this,

14
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:39.810
otherwise, well, it's just not fun.

15
00:00:39.810 --> 00:00:41.220
So that's why you got to
play around a little bit.

16
00:00:41.220 --> 00:00:43.990
But we do bring you serious information.

17
00:00:43.990 --> 00:00:46.430
And good tidings from the land of SCOM.

18
00:00:46.430 --> 00:00:48.870
We are gonna continue our
demonstrations for you.

19
00:00:48.870 --> 00:00:53.260
We thought we would take a look at how to
integrate VMM, Virtual Machine Manager.

20
00:00:53.260 --> 00:00:55.290
How to take that,
integrate that with SCOM.

21
00:00:55.290 --> 00:00:57.506
We've talked a little bit about
that in one of our prior episodes.

22
00:00:57.506 --> 00:00:59.025
I wanna show you how that happens.

23
00:00:59.025 --> 00:01:01.125
Gonna go in,
take a look at the VMM settings.

24
00:01:01.125 --> 00:01:04.375
Go in, configure the OPS Manager
information in there.

25
00:01:04.375 --> 00:01:07.465
And we wanna also bring up pro and

26
00:01:07.465 --> 00:01:10.350
performance resource
optimization monitoring.

27
00:01:10.350 --> 00:01:11.500
We're going to take a look at that.

28
00:01:11.500 --> 00:01:16.540
That would be essentially the idea in
VMware's competitive stack of DRS,

29
00:01:16.540 --> 00:01:19.540
distributed resource schedule, and
that automated load balancing and

30
00:01:19.540 --> 00:01:22.440
automation and monitoring, and
all that kind of stuff that goes on.

31
00:01:22.440 --> 00:01:24.960
We're going to take a look at some of
that, how all that comes together.

32
00:01:24.960 --> 00:01:27.360
So we're going to jump in over here,
take a look.

33
00:01:27.360 --> 00:01:28.370
There we are, right up there.

34
00:01:29.600 --> 00:01:32.956
And we're going to- I've already
opened up the VMM console so

35
00:01:32.956 --> 00:01:36.135
we just on our server where our
CVMM instance is installed.

36
00:01:36.135 --> 00:01:40.401
I've opened up the console and I've just
gone into the settings workspace right

37
00:01:40.401 --> 00:01:44.979
down here, and in the settings workspace
I've highlighted system center settings,

38
00:01:44.979 --> 00:01:47.439
and we have our ops
manager server item there.

39
00:01:47.439 --> 00:01:50.914
I'm gonna right-click on that,
just bring up properties, and

40
00:01:50.914 --> 00:01:54.515
we're gonna get our add operations
manager, just move this over so

41
00:01:54.515 --> 00:01:57.535
you could see it,
add operations manager wizard.

42
00:01:57.535 --> 00:02:00.280
We're gonna go through here,
from the introductory screen.

43
00:02:00.280 --> 00:02:03.400
How we're gonna specify the ops
manager we're gonna connect to, and

44
00:02:03.400 --> 00:02:04.590
configure this out.

45
00:02:04.590 --> 00:02:07.745
We'll provide credentials,
we'll specify that we have- or

46
00:02:07.745 --> 00:02:10.605
it gives us a listing of all
the management packs we need.

47
00:02:10.605 --> 00:02:12.245
Make sure those are already installed.

48
00:02:12.245 --> 00:02:15.751
I'll walk through in my discussion and hit
the high level, and most of the management

49
00:02:15.751 --> 00:02:18.792
packs I've said, we needed to bunch
a router, two or three of them off.

50
00:02:18.792 --> 00:02:22.472
All of them, including the versions,
are in the show notes for you by the way.

51
00:02:22.472 --> 00:02:25.622
So you will be able to see them and

episodes.description: In this show, Adam and Cherokee really focus in on Application Performance Monitoring (APM). Tune in now to understand the guidelines, learn about integrating features and get to know how detailed configurations can help customize your enviroment.

[MUSIC]

499
00:23:52.588 --> 00:23:56.062
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this show, watch Adam explain how to view distributed applications.
episodes.title: Viewing Distributed Applications
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:03.379
Welcome to ITProTV,

2
00:00:03.379 --> 00:00:07.889
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.889 --> 00:00:12.026
>> You are watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.026 --> 00:00:14.761
>> Welcome ladies and
gentlemen to your Monitoring and

5
00:00:14.761 --> 00:00:17.065
Operating a Private Cloud series.

6
00:00:17.065 --> 00:00:18.995
I'm your show host, Cherokee Boose.

7
00:00:18.995 --> 00:00:22.327
In this episode we will be viewing
distributed applications and

8
00:00:22.327 --> 00:00:25.245
with us today in the studio,
we have Mr. Adam Gordon.

9
00:00:25.245 --> 00:00:27.385
Thank you for joining us today Adam.

10
00:00:27.385 --> 00:00:28.635
>> Hello.

11
00:00:28.635 --> 00:00:29.455
>> Hello.
>> Hello, so

12
00:00:29.455 --> 00:00:34.165
we're gonna continue our conversations
around showing you different aspects of

13
00:00:34.165 --> 00:00:38.020
the System Center Ops Manager capabilities
for monitoring application health.

14
00:00:38.020 --> 00:00:40.690
Take a look at APM,
talked about inside out and

15
00:00:40.690 --> 00:00:44.470
outside in transaction monitoring
with global service monitoring.

16
00:00:44.470 --> 00:00:48.540
We've taken a look at and talked about how
to deal with event notifications, alert

17
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:52.640
notifications, how we do run as accounts,
run as profiles and deal with that.

18
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:56.680
We're gonna now put the capstone in place,
talk about distributed applications.

19
00:00:56.680 --> 00:01:00.200
How we can diagram out, or
essentially create a visual reference for

20
00:01:00.200 --> 00:01:03.580
our application stack, and
then monitor against that stack.

21
00:01:03.580 --> 00:01:05.440
So we're gonna start off in the console.

22
00:01:05.440 --> 00:01:07.870
Take a look here,
if you don't mind joining me

23
00:01:07.870 --> 00:01:11.910
over here in the left wing of
the ITProTV demo environment.

24
00:01:11.910 --> 00:01:15.660
I've already gone ahead and created
an app that we can just look at first,

25
00:01:15.660 --> 00:01:17.350
just to show you some things.

26
00:01:17.350 --> 00:01:18.850
We'll then go ahead and go back and

27
00:01:18.850 --> 00:01:22.880
show you how to create this using
the distributed application wizard.

28
00:01:22.880 --> 00:01:26.380
But we call this distributed
app ITProTV Test App 1.

29
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:31.400
You could see we've opened up or
exploded out our diagram.

30
00:01:31.400 --> 00:01:34.200
This is like that network diagram
view that we've looked at

31
00:01:34.200 --> 00:01:37.750
in some of the other episodes where we've
looked at the health status monitoring and

32
00:01:37.750 --> 00:01:39.820
the update in real time
around those elements,

33
00:01:39.820 --> 00:01:43.900
and this is gonna be the same idea,
and we'll see underneath here,

34
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:47.800
I've added in two elements,
one that's called all computers and

35
00:01:47.800 --> 00:01:52.490
I have all Windows computers as objects
listed here that I can monitor for.

36
00:01:52.490 --> 00:01:54.780
I have an object called server and

37
00:01:54.780 --> 00:01:57.700
I've added a specific instance
of Windows Server here and

38
00:01:57.700 --> 00:02:01.760
when I hover what you will notice is we
got a pop out and I'll select this and

39
00:02:01.760 --> 00:02:05.390
that information will show up at
the bottom pane in just a minute but

40
00:02:05.390 --> 00:02:09.840
I get a pop out hover indicates that you
know, hey I wanna know some information

41
00:02:09.840 --> 00:02:13.450
and when I do that, if I can get it to do
that again I get this nice little pop out

42
00:02:13.450 --> 00:02:17.025
box that gives me all the information
about the object in question.

43
00:02:17.025 --> 00:02:18.465
But it's only there for about 10 seconds.

44
00:02:18.465 --> 00:02:19.155
It's hard to read.

45
00:02:19.155 --> 00:02:20.875
So if you highlight that,

46
00:02:20.875 --> 00:02:24.575
all that information shows up
down here in the lower third.

47
00:02:24.575 --> 00:02:27.995
And we could see the name,
the display name, principle name, DNS,

48
00:02:27.995 --> 00:02:33.195
the net bios name, the IP address, all
the information about this object is here.

49
00:02:33.195 --> 00:02:34.985
The network name,

50
00:02:34.985 --> 00:02:38.550
we have the active directory
information of it's domain joint.

51
00:02:38.550 --> 00:02:44.120
We have the number of logical processors
and physical processors available here,

52
00:02:44.120 --> 00:02:47.490
we have quite a bit of information
if it's a virtual machine

53
00:02:47.490 --> 00:02:51.620
we can tell that it's a virtual machine,
all that stuff would be available to us so

54
00:02:51.620 --> 00:02:56.310
all of that is here, in addition all
these diagrams are fully interactive,

55
00:02:56.310 --> 00:03:01.150
we can go in,
we can open up any of the views.

56
00:03:01.150 --> 00:03:04.170
Can we go fullscreen just so you could see
this as it pops out, cuz it's kinda hidden

57
00:03:04.170 --> 00:03:08.680
behind me a little bit there, and I didn't
bring my cloak of invisibility today with

58
00:03:08.680 --> 00:03:12.500
me, so it's hard for me to disappear out
of that box while you're taking a look.

59
00:03:12.500 --> 00:03:13.100
>> Maybe next time Adam.

60
00:03:13.100 --> 00:03:15.910
>> Perhaps next time,
when I'm feeling more like a Harry Porter

61
00:03:15.910 --> 00:03:20.700
kind of mood as opposed to my bright
effervescent pink mood that I'm in today.

62
00:03:20.700 --> 00:03:24.470
So you'll see alert view, event view,
performance view, diagram view,

63
00:03:24.470 --> 00:03:29.460
these views can be opened response
specific to the object in the diagram and

64
00:03:29.460 --> 00:03:33.550
if the stages would me allow me to be able
to click and access the information for

65
00:03:33.550 --> 00:03:35.190
that, so you'll see that.

66
00:03:35.190 --> 00:03:39.360
We have our instance properties, health
explorer, we've talked about that before,

67
00:03:39.360 --> 00:03:41.760
the importance of the ops manager shell.

68
00:03:41.760 --> 00:03:44.420
You could see that and we could interact
with that here, and you'll see,

69
00:03:44.420 --> 00:03:47.060
we could start maintenance mode, and

70
00:03:47.060 --> 00:03:50.700
we could actually put this machine
into maintenance mode on to work hard.

71
00:03:50.700 --> 00:03:53.290
And now we could do the same
thing right over here and

72
00:03:53.290 --> 00:03:56.580
then have more on the right,
we have access to all of those options.

73
00:03:56.580 --> 00:04:01.700
We could use this information or
this set of Windows computer tasks,

74
00:04:01.700 --> 00:04:06.280
right down here for instance to be
able to go in, open Computer Manager,

75
00:04:06.280 --> 00:04:10.460
ping the computer, perhaps do
a remote desktop out to it, right?

76
00:04:10.460 --> 00:04:14.130
So there's all this different stuff that
we could do if we use one of these tasks

77
00:04:14.130 --> 00:04:18.430
you'll notice I'm able to open Computer
Management against the system immediately,

78
00:04:18.430 --> 00:04:20.700
so long as the system's online and
available of course.

79
00:04:20.700 --> 00:04:24.590
And I could do that, so you could see that
I'm able to use tasks off to the right to

80
00:04:24.590 --> 00:04:27.610
interact with elements in
this diagram in real time.

81
00:04:27.610 --> 00:04:30.690
Which is incredibly important for us,
because we don't have to go into five or

82
00:04:30.690 --> 00:04:34.230
six different screens to do
administration based on health status.

83
00:04:34.230 --> 00:04:37.150
We can do it right from within
the distributed app diagram itself.

84
00:04:37.150 --> 00:04:39.590
Which makes a lot of sense
when you think about it.

85
00:04:39.590 --> 00:04:40.930
So we can see that.

86
00:04:40.930 --> 00:04:43.020
And you know we obvious can execute
any of these tasks depending on

87
00:04:43.020 --> 00:04:44.230
what we are looking for.

88
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:46.260
Now as we scroll down, we continue to see.

89
00:04:46.260 --> 00:04:48.630
I only opened up one area
here under the server.

90
00:04:48.630 --> 00:04:51.250
I could do the same under
all Windows computers.

91
00:04:51.250 --> 00:04:53.540
But I'll see that we have
some stuff that's healthy.

92
00:04:53.540 --> 00:04:56.770
So I can open this up,
it'd tell us what is healthy here.

93
00:04:56.770 --> 00:05:00.390
All these things on the server
are healthy elements.

94
00:05:00.390 --> 00:05:04.020
I can look at,
let's just bring that back up,

95
00:05:04.020 --> 00:05:07.760
things that are not monitored, so what is
currently not being monitored, I could

96
00:05:07.760 --> 00:05:11.510
see whatever is not being monitored and
I would see the status of those.

97
00:05:11.510 --> 00:05:15.120
And if there's anything in the warning
state I could see what's in the warning

98
00:05:15.120 --> 00:05:18.870
state, I could see that maybe our database
instance is in a warning state for

99
00:05:18.870 --> 00:05:20.200
instance hypothetically or

100
00:05:20.200 --> 00:05:23.250
whatever the case may be it may be
a service, or something like that.

101
00:05:23.250 --> 00:05:26.650
And I can get more information,
depending on what's happening.

102
00:05:26.650 --> 00:05:29.340
I can refresh in any area.

103
00:05:29.340 --> 00:05:33.640
It has to redraw, rerender diagram,
bringing it back in and updating it.

104
00:05:33.640 --> 00:05:34.420
So I can do that.

105
00:05:34.420 --> 00:05:36.090
It takes just a moment,
you see that it comes back up.

106
00:05:36.090 --> 00:05:38.820
And then I can delve in and
see if there's any updates.

107
00:05:38.820 --> 00:05:43.510
So the application, or distributed
application diagram, is very valuable for

108
00:05:43.510 --> 00:05:48.460
us because it allows us to bring
up an application that has been

109
00:05:48.460 --> 00:05:49.570
put into the system.

110
00:05:49.570 --> 00:05:53.480
Here you could see when close the diagrams
go back to the monitoring screen,

111
00:05:53.480 --> 00:05:57.520
you could see that under offering as we
use are distributed application area and

112
00:05:57.520 --> 00:05:58.580
we create our application.

113
00:05:58.580 --> 00:06:03.060
So this is the one that I preloaded before
we came on to do the demo just to show you

114
00:06:03.060 --> 00:06:07.910
the output, that once it's there and
created, we then can simply go in.

115
00:06:07.910 --> 00:06:09.300
It's very simple to do.

116
00:06:09.300 --> 00:06:11.210
Right click and just view diagram.

117
00:06:11.210 --> 00:06:12.690
That's what I was doing just now.

118
00:06:12.690 --> 00:06:14.010
That's what we will see.

119
00:06:14.010 --> 00:06:15.670
We could view state as well.

120
00:06:15.670 --> 00:06:17.360
I can right click and view state.

121
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:19.630
Give this just a second.

122
00:06:19.630 --> 00:06:21.530
We can go in and see our state monitor.

123
00:06:21.530 --> 00:06:24.580
We've looked at our state monitor
before in some of the other demos.

124
00:06:24.580 --> 00:06:27.070
We've seen the value of
understanding what the state is.

125
00:06:27.070 --> 00:06:29.490
We could see the state in
any of these categories.

126
00:06:29.490 --> 00:06:31.620
Are we up to date with software updates?

127
00:06:31.620 --> 00:06:35.920
Are or is our APM or application
performance monitoring taking place?

128
00:06:35.920 --> 00:06:37.890
You know all the different
things that are here and

129
00:06:37.890 --> 00:06:42.110
you'll see there are quite a number
of them as we scroll over, right?

130
00:06:42.110 --> 00:06:43.910
Just going by there.

131
00:06:43.910 --> 00:06:48.630
Look at all that stuff that potentially
we can monitor for and tell the state of.

132
00:06:48.630 --> 00:06:53.580
Just gonna keep going until either we run
out of room, I run out of things to say,

133
00:06:53.580 --> 00:06:56.600
or you get so dizzy that you go like
this and fall out of your chair.

134
00:06:56.600 --> 00:06:58.580
But you can see all the different stuff.

135
00:06:58.580 --> 00:07:00.101
>> That's crazy.
>> That's potentially is

136
00:07:00.101 --> 00:07:01.500
being monitored for here.

137
00:07:01.500 --> 00:07:03.000
And we're not even halfway through yet.

138
00:07:03.000 --> 00:07:04.700
Look at the slider at the bottom.

139
00:07:04.700 --> 00:07:06.830
We're approaching halfway right now.

140
00:07:06.830 --> 00:07:10.270
And I've already actually shaved and
changed my shirt twice.

141
00:07:10.270 --> 00:07:11.470
And we're still going.

142
00:07:11.470 --> 00:07:16.140
And so you could see that this is
pulling down all of this information.

143
00:07:16.140 --> 00:07:20.294
Every aspect of all the information
associated with the management packs, and

144
00:07:20.294 --> 00:07:22.099
everything we can be looking for.

145
00:07:22.099 --> 00:07:24.300
Now clearly we're not monitoring for
most of this.

146
00:07:24.300 --> 00:07:27.350
Most of it is just, essentially there,
hey I've available but

147
00:07:27.350 --> 00:07:29.250
I'm not really monitoring for you yet.

148
00:07:29.250 --> 00:07:34.320
But the point is you could see that I have
hundreds of items that could be looked

149
00:07:34.320 --> 00:07:39.468
at for state, right now we're just looking
at the fact that we're in a warning

150
00:07:39.468 --> 00:07:44.460
stage generically, we don't really know
why but we know that we can go in and

151
00:07:44.460 --> 00:07:48.146
we can open up any of our views
here to get a sense of that.

152
00:07:48.146 --> 00:07:50.748
We also know that we can
open our help explorer and

153
00:07:50.748 --> 00:07:54.936
begin to look at state transition or
changes and see what's happening when and

154
00:07:54.936 --> 00:07:57.872
then work backwards to figure
out what may be going on.

155
00:07:57.872 --> 00:08:00.818
We may want to do a quick look and
see if there's any alerts, so

156
00:08:00.818 --> 00:08:02.758
maybe we'll just do a quick alert view.

157
00:08:02.758 --> 00:08:04.585
We could see there are some alerts here,

158
00:08:04.585 --> 00:08:07.390
that may be leading to some of
the concern that we're seeing.

159
00:08:07.390 --> 00:08:11.578
And we could see what they are,
PowerShell scripts failed to run, may or

160
00:08:11.578 --> 00:08:12.892
may not be important.

161
00:08:12.892 --> 00:08:17.812
We can take a look and see that APM.net
server side configuration error

162
00:08:17.812 --> 00:08:22.821
conflicts with something with setting
up APM, may have been a problem.

163
00:08:22.821 --> 00:08:24.540
Looks like IS needs to be restarted,

164
00:08:24.540 --> 00:08:28.143
that will be from one of our prior demos
where I didn't bother to restart IS and

165
00:08:28.143 --> 00:08:30.750
just continued to do some stuff and
configure it.

166
00:08:30.750 --> 00:08:34.201
So we can see there's evidence of things
going on in the system but that's okay,

167
00:08:34.201 --> 00:08:36.105
we can at least now tell what they are.

168
00:08:36.105 --> 00:08:40.021
And if we needed to delve into one of
them in more detail we can go in, we can

169
00:08:40.021 --> 00:08:44.345
click on it, we could see down here that
we get the information about the alert.

170
00:08:44.345 --> 00:08:48.692
We can see the alert description down
here, what machine it came from,

171
00:08:48.692 --> 00:08:52.382
if there is an action that is
required it shows us what it is.

172
00:08:52.382 --> 00:08:56.420
Over here as we scroll down, we could see
that there may be additional details in

173
00:08:56.420 --> 00:09:00.235
the alert summary, or in the error
summary that we'd wanna take a look at.

174
00:09:00.235 --> 00:09:04.105
So there's very detailed information with
regards to performance monitoring that

175
00:09:04.105 --> 00:09:06.065
the system will give us in the console,
but

176
00:09:06.065 --> 00:09:08.308
we've gotta know where to
go in order to find it.

177
00:09:08.308 --> 00:09:11.977
And we've gotta be able to follow
the breadcrumb trail, essentially,

178
00:09:11.977 --> 00:09:15.887
that we have from console to console
window to be able to see what we're having

179
00:09:15.887 --> 00:09:19.134
to figure out as administrators and
what may be impactful to us so

180
00:09:19.134 --> 00:09:20.880
we better understand it.

181
00:09:20.880 --> 00:09:24.550
Very powerful tool, lots and
lots of things going on, and

182
00:09:24.550 --> 00:09:29.250
lots of information that oops,
that we can interact with, I did click,

183
00:09:29.250 --> 00:09:31.410
lots of things going on that
we can interact with in there.

184
00:09:31.410 --> 00:09:35.000
So what I wanna do is show you how to
create this distributed application view,

185
00:09:35.000 --> 00:09:36.020
so we're gonna do that right now.

186
00:09:36.020 --> 00:09:38.660
We're gonna right click on
the distributed application item,

187
00:09:38.660 --> 00:09:42.920
notice we are in the authoring workspace,
we are up under authoring.

188
00:09:42.920 --> 00:09:46.170
We've been through
the management pack templates,

189
00:09:46.170 --> 00:09:47.630
done a couple of different things there.

190
00:09:47.630 --> 00:09:50.530
We're gonna take a different tact here,
do Distributed Applications,

191
00:09:50.530 --> 00:09:52.410
right click > Create
a new distributed app.

192
00:09:52.410 --> 00:09:54.820
Get a little wizard that shows up,
pretty straightforward.

193
00:09:54.820 --> 00:09:59.120
We're gonna name this one for
my lovely co-host over there, Cherokee,

194
00:09:59.120 --> 00:10:03.750
and we're gonna say that this will
be called Cherokee App, right?

195
00:10:03.750 --> 00:10:06.290
>> Yea, there's an app for that.

196
00:10:06.290 --> 00:10:08.320
>> There's an app for that,
there's an app for Cherokee.

197
00:10:08.320 --> 00:10:10.160
Cherokee app one, okay.

198
00:10:10.160 --> 00:10:12.740
And we have some templates
here that we can choose,

199
00:10:12.740 --> 00:10:15.070
we have a .NET three-tier application.

200
00:10:15.070 --> 00:10:17.630
So if the Cherokee app was a .NET app,

201
00:10:17.630 --> 00:10:20.610
we would choose that to be able
to represent the different

202
00:10:20.610 --> 00:10:25.180
functionality levels in a .NET app
with a two or a three-tier solution.

203
00:10:25.180 --> 00:10:29.140
We may do a blank advance,
which is just a blank template.

204
00:10:29.140 --> 00:10:32.900
That's the one I'll do, and we can pull
out and essentially create components and

205
00:10:32.900 --> 00:10:36.170
then join them and create a connection,
I'll show you how to do that.

206
00:10:36.170 --> 00:10:39.700
We could do a messaging one,
we could do a line of business web app.

207
00:10:39.700 --> 00:10:42.850
So every template has
information specific to it and

208
00:10:42.850 --> 00:10:47.230
a specific way of diagramming
the application that we're gonna look at.

209
00:10:47.230 --> 00:10:50.162
And if you're not familiar with
it highlight the appropriate one,

210
00:10:50.162 --> 00:10:51.918
you'll get a little description here.

211
00:10:51.918 --> 00:10:55.684
You can view the details of it, go in, it
brings up purpose and feature, gives you

212
00:10:55.684 --> 00:10:59.628
a little bit more information about what
the template does, what you're able to do.

213
00:10:59.628 --> 00:11:03.027
It'll show things like websites and
database objects,

214
00:11:03.027 --> 00:11:07.010
if you do the line of business
web app versus a messaging app.

215
00:11:07.010 --> 00:11:11.460
Where we'll go in and
we'll be able to see all the messaging

216
00:11:11.460 --> 00:11:16.390
components like Exchange, Mail Stores,
DNS infrastructure, right,

217
00:11:16.390 --> 00:11:19.900
pretty standard messaging platform stuff,
we'd be able to diagram that out.

218
00:11:19.900 --> 00:11:23.530
So it's a question of what back end
application we're representing,

219
00:11:23.530 --> 00:11:26.340
remember we're not creating
the application here.

220
00:11:26.340 --> 00:11:29.140
We're creating a representation
of an existing app,

221
00:11:29.140 --> 00:11:30.715
not the real app itself, right,

222
00:11:30.715 --> 00:11:34.500
we're not about to create a messaging
system if we choose messaging template.

223

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their exploration of the Service Manager by looking at Queues, Groups, and Lists. They start by walking you through the creation of a Queue. Then they create a custom Role which can then leverage the newly created Queue. Finally they configure Service Offerings for a Cloud using the Service Manager Self-Service Portal.
episodes.title: Service Management in a Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam dive a bit deeper into the System Center Service Manager components including Activity Management, Workflows, and Change Management. They also look at the Service Catalog with its Request and Service Offerings.
episodes.title: Service Management in a Private Cloud Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam take a closer look at creating a Change Request. They take you from start to finish, looking at each of the available options, creating a Change Request. Then they look at working with a Change Request in the Change Management console. Finally, they do the same with Incident Management.
episodes.title: Service Management in a Private Cloud Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam finish their exploration of the Service Manager by looking at Queues, Groups, and Lists. They start by walking you through the creation of a Queue. Then they create a custom Role which can then leverage the newly created Queue. Finally they configure Service Offerings for a Cloud using the Service Manager Self-Service Portal.
episodes.title: Service Management in a Private Cloud Part 4

episodes.description: Cherokee and Adam break down a step-by-step demonstration to configure overrides. Tune in to learn how to use one of the many integrated overrides or create you own custom ones.
episodes.title: Configure Overrides

episodes.description: In this show, Adam walks through the steps ho use synthetic transaction monitoring to monitor a web site URL.
episodes.title: Synthetic Transaction Web Monitoring

topics.title: Operating and Extending Service Mgmt. in the Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore automating Incident creation, remediation, and change requests. They show you how to import Integration Packs and then connect them to the Runbook Server and/or Designer. Then they take you through integrating the Orchestrator with the Service Manager.
episodes.title: Automating Incidents

topics.title: Automating Incident Creation, Remediation, and Change Requests

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain the Problem Management system in System Center. They start by defining the difference between an Incident and a Problem. Then they look at a Problem Management Process Flow Chart which guides us through the problem management process. Finally they walk through creating a Problem Report(PR), linking an Incident Report(IR) to a PR, and generating a Change Request.
episodes.title: Problem Management

topics.title: Problem Management in the Private Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explain the function and use of the Windows Azure Pack. Here they will be defining what the Azure Pack is as well as some of its commonly used features and plugins and giving an overview of many powerful integrations that can be done.
episodes.title: Windows Azure Pack

topics.title: Operating a Self Service, Multi-Tenant Cloud with Windows Azure Pack

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore maintaining high availability, protection, and recovery using Microsoft System Center and Azure. They discuss at length the necessity of SQL Always-On, Hyper-V Replica, and Azure Site Recovery.
episodes.title: High Availability for the Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk you through configuring the Data Protection Manager(DPM) in System Center. Here they will show you how to view disk allocation information to review Storage Pool data as well as create Protection Group and add members client computers to that group.
episodes.title: Configure the Data Protection Manager

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam demonstrate implementing a Hyper-V replica. Here they show you how to prepare your system for the replica, manage the replication, and also look at understanding failover to the replica.
episodes.title: Implementing Hyper-V Replica

topics.title: High Availability, Protection, and Recovery for the Cloud

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk you through installing and configuring Windows Server Update Service(WSUS). They will take you from start to finish, explaining each step in detail along the way as well as helping you avoid any common stumbling blocks.
episodes.title: Optimizing Your Cloud Infrastructure
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:02.261
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.261 --> 00:00:08.256
[CROSSTALK]

3

>> You're watching ITProTv.

4
