>> Welcome to your monitoring and
operating a private cloud series.

5
00:00:14.965 --> 00:00:17.915
I'm your show host Cherokee Boose In
this episode we'll be

6
00:00:17.915 --> 00:00:20.880
looking at how to optimize
your cloud environment.

7
00:00:20.880 --> 00:00:23.910
And with us today we have
Mr Adam Gordon in studio.

8
00:00:23.910 --> 00:00:26.000
Thank you for joining us today, Adam.

9
00:00:26.000 --> 00:00:27.980
>> Good morning, hello everybody,
good afternoon, good day.

10
00:00:27.980 --> 00:00:29.887
>> Wherever you are.
>> Whatever you may be doing,

11
00:00:29.887 --> 00:00:32.500
wherever you are hopefully you're well.

12
00:00:32.500 --> 00:00:37.910
We're gonna continue talking here about
private cloud monitoring optimization.

13
00:00:37.910 --> 00:00:40.170
As Cherokee said is the name
of this particular discussion,

14
00:00:40.170 --> 00:00:43.360
meaning we're to take a look at a set
of technologies, different areas,

15
00:00:43.360 --> 00:00:45.680
different products,
different thought processes.

16
00:00:45.680 --> 00:00:48.110
But how we can tweak our
performance a little bit,

17
00:00:48.110 --> 00:00:51.670
make it that much better by doing
something, enabling something,

18
00:00:51.670 --> 00:00:57.270
setting something up, and or combining
our ability to monitor with another

19
00:00:57.270 --> 00:01:01.550
product's stream that allows us then to
engage in activities that make us better.

20
00:01:01.550 --> 00:01:02.670
Not just optimizing but

21
00:01:02.670 --> 00:01:05.385
also making sure we're up to date
from security patching stand point.

22
00:01:05.385 --> 00:01:08.585
And put on the talked about that whole
idea of WSUS, how we use that or

23
00:01:08.585 --> 00:01:14.365
immigrate that with the VMM and
also in system center

24
00:01:14.365 --> 00:01:18.687
config manager to be able to do patching
and patch management keep us up to date.

25
00:01:18.687 --> 00:01:22.767
On the host side as well as
on the virtual machine side,

26
00:01:22.767 --> 00:01:26.337
cuz we have to take a slightly different
tact and approach for patching in each

27
00:01:26.337 --> 00:01:29.147
area depending on what we're doing and
what product we're gonna patch through.

28
00:01:29.147 --> 00:01:32.417
So we'll talk through that, make sure you
guys are comfortable with that whole idea.

29
00:01:32.417 --> 00:01:37.147
So let's begin, if we can, by talking a
little bit about this idea of how we keep

30
00:01:37.147 --> 00:01:38.927

31
00:01:38.927 --> 00:01:41.447
This idea I was just talking
about of patch management,

32
00:01:41.447 --> 00:01:45.270
what we do, how we do it,
hopefully you're familiar with the idea

33
00:01:45.270 --> 00:01:49.460
of using the Windows Software Update
Service, what we just referred to as WSUS

34
00:01:49.460 --> 00:01:52.740
to be able to do patch management
generically in your infrastructure.

35
00:01:52.740 --> 00:01:55.130
Most of us I'm sure probably have one or

36
00:01:55.130 --> 00:01:59.180
more of these servers running
outside in our network somewhere,

37
00:01:59.180 --> 00:02:03.920
downloading patches from a central
repository that Microsoft maintains.

38
00:02:03.920 --> 00:02:06.340
And as a result of that,
then, sending them up, and

39
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:09.640
being able to use that as a launching pad,
a staging area for

40
00:02:09.640 --> 00:02:12.410
patching throughout the organization,
throughout the enterprise.

41
00:02:12.410 --> 00:02:16.060
And this is an ongoing thought process,
this happens on a monthly basis,

42
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:16.570
traditionally.

43
00:02:16.570 --> 00:02:19.320
We're probably all familiar

44
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:22.660
And the idea that Microsoft, and
all vendors, not just Microsoft, but

45
00:02:22.660 --> 00:02:26.590
we're here specifically talking about
Microsoft's infrastructure right now,

46
00:02:26.590 --> 00:02:28.510
VMware does this the same way.

47
00:02:28.510 --> 00:02:31.240
Cisco does this, Oracle does this.

48
00:02:31.240 --> 00:02:34.630
Any major vendor will
do something like this,

49
00:02:34.630 --> 00:02:39.595
where they are putting out patches on
a more or less regular announced schedule.

50
00:02:39.595 --> 00:02:42.685
We may be entering patches,
when there's an issue or a concern,

51
00:02:42.685 --> 00:02:47.175
you know a highly problematic or
very, very involved security issue.

52
00:02:47.175 --> 00:02:48.655
Make it an our of cycle patch, but

53
00:02:48.655 --> 00:02:51.965
traditionally we'll have some sort of
regulatory schedule we can rely on.

54
00:02:51.965 --> 00:02:56.325
We will download from one or more central
websites that we can than use to catalog

55
00:02:56.325 --> 00:02:59.935
and build up a library of updates,
and we'll than be able to

56
00:02:59.935 --> 00:03:02.745
send those updates out using a variety
of different technologies and

57
00:03:02.745 --> 00:03:05.780
methods to various endpoints
in our organization.

58
00:03:05.780 --> 00:03:08.250
And this is a process that's
been going on for years.

59
00:03:08.250 --> 00:03:10.470
And so hopefully that part's
not new to any of you.

60
00:03:10.470 --> 00:03:14.270

61
00:03:14.270 --> 00:03:17.650
in some upcoming episodes on the hands-on
pieces, we're gonna walk through

62
00:03:17.650 --> 00:03:22.130
how to set up WSUS, and show you, start
to finish how to stand up WSUS, install

63

it as a feature set, configure it, set

64

And then actually push deployments out,
so you'll get to see all of that, but

65
00:03:30.340 --> 00:03:31.970
you'll get to see that with a cloud twist.

66
00:03:31.970 --> 00:03:35.530
We are going to then link that
in to SCCM and bring that in so

67
00:03:35.530 --> 00:03:38.045
we can show you using
a software update point.

68
00:03:38.045 --> 00:03:41.555
how to do that integration to do patch
management for a managed endpoint.

69
00:03:41.555 --> 00:03:44.975
We're also going to
integrate it with SCVMM,

70
00:03:44.975 --> 00:03:48.555
System Center Virtual Machine Manager,
our cloud fabric manager for

71
00:03:48.555 --> 00:03:50.965
our private cloud that we've been
talking about in system center.

72
00:03:50.965 --> 00:03:53.475
We're going to integrate it there and
deal with and

73
00:03:53.475 --> 00:03:56.545
talk about how we do
the patching on the host side.

74
00:03:56.545 --> 00:03:58.615
VMM is really all about
taking care of the hosts,

75
00:03:58.615 --> 00:04:03.460
the underlying physical machines that
are providing the infrastructure for

76
00:04:03.460 --> 00:04:06.260
running our guest operating systems or
VMs.

77
00:04:06.260 --> 00:04:08.770
And ICCM is gonna be able to
deal with the guest OS' or

78
00:04:08.770 --> 00:04:11.360
VMs that are running on top of our host.

79
00:04:11.360 --> 00:04:13.720
So we're gonna split our
patching between those two and

80
00:04:13.720 --> 00:04:15.710

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam walk you through installing and configuring Windows Server Update Service(WSUS). They will take you from start to finish, explaining each step in detail along the way as well as helping you avoid any common stumbling blocks.
episodes.title: Install and Configure WSUS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue to walk you through installing and configuring Windows Server Update Service(WSUS). Here they are focusing more on post-configuration. This will cover creating WSUS computer groups, update approval, and connecting WSUS to System Center.
episodes.title: Install and Configure WSUS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue to walk you through installing and configuring Windows Server Update Service(WSUS). Here they are focusing on more post-installation configuration, specifically synchronizing WSUS with System Center as well as connecting WSUS with the System Center Virtual Machine Manager.
episodes.title: Install and Configure WSUS Part 3

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam explore configuring SLAs, Widgets, and Dashboards. They begin by creating a calendar item, SLA metrics, and SLOs. They also show you defining an SLO against an application and running a Service Level tracking report.
episodes.title: SLAs, Widgets and Dashboards

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Adam continue discussing and demonstrating SLAs, Widgets, and Dashboards. Here they show creating custom dashboards and widgets as well as  publishing to Visio, Sharepoint, and System Center analytics. Finally, they explain installing and configuring Service Reporting.
episodes.title: SLAs, Widgets and Dashboards Part 2
